content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												There is no getting around it, DMC being rebooted by a western studio is shocking. So shocking that a lot of fans cried foul and screamed blood murder. Was it for the best? Perhaps it was, DMC 4 was undoubtedly a step backwards after all. Capcom took a chance with outsourcing the IP and surprisingly it paid off.Meet DmC: Devil May Cry, a young fresh reboot by the team that brought you Heavenly Sword and Enslaved: Odyssey to the West. With a slick, stylized re-imagining of the world home to the Nephilim Dante. Born of the Angel Eva and Demon Sparda, he possesses the power of both. Hunted down by the Demon king Mundus, Dante is dragged into the parallel plane called Limbo at every turn.While the initial combat impression and the new look might seem jarring at first. After a few minutes you will find that DMC is very much alive under the hood. The intense high level combat gameplay is still there with some interesting new additions to mix things up a bit. Once mastered you will be able to perform the dazzling acrobatic slashing we all know and love with ease again. I say with ease but do not mistake this for the difficulty having eased up. The challenges are still very much there, though I would recommend people familiar with the series start on Hard.All in all the reboot manages to be fresh, engaging and most of all fun. It will be jarring to some but that is the case with any reboot. If you've enjoyed DMC in the past or enjoy action hack and slash games, give this a shot.

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Don't believe the haters. This is one of the best Devil May Cry games available. The criticism against it mostly centers on Capcom's decision to transform the iconic character of Dante. I promise, it's just a cosmetic change. No, he does not look like a gothic anime villain and he does not spend his time hunting demons in medieval castles. Aside from that, he's the same Dante he's been since DMC 3. Yes, he has attitude, but it's not as over-the-top as it used to be. DMC 3 let Dante perform ridiculous stunts like using a motorcycle to pulverize demons and wielding an electric, bat-shooting guitar, all while spouting off catchphrases straight from the Ninja Turtles. While that was campy and lots of fun, DMC shoots for a different tone. This is a serious game with a Dante that is more human than action hero. He's traded his anime garb for something along the lines of urban anarchist. But the game is GOOD. The combat is nearly flawless. Controls have been streamlined, so no more cycling through different fighting styles or trying to decide which weapon to take into battle. This isn't Resident Evil with swords anymore. It's a fully-fledged brawler and it can be legitimately challenging. The storyline is also a vast improvement over previous installments. The voice acting is no longer outrageous. Dante's demons don't haunt dark dungeons anymore. They live all around him: in the media, in junk food, in human lusts and appetites. These are the Seven Deadly Sins personified and Dante embodies them as much as he wants to destroy them. There is internal and external conflict going on, all blending seamlessly with brutal and satisfying combat. Dante's hits shake the earth. His enemies wield chainsaws and katanas. Fans of Nero will be happy to find that Dante's sword now has a grappling function to pull enemies close. Does it look like a Devil May Cry game? No. But all the familiar faces are there (including Vergil, whom you can control in the DLC); Dante's attitude hasn't changed, and there's a LOT to love here. Don't let the negative reviews discourage you. This is a truly phenomenal fighting game that pays homage to its predecessors. As someone who has played the heck out of every DMC game and even suffered through the terrible anime, I can say this is a worthy reboot of the franchise. 9/10.

												I waited with the review until I finish DMC4:SE, so I can see where the hate comes from and to be honest I still think that the hate is nonsense.+Diverse and beautiful level design!+Complex (but not as DMC4:SE) combat system+Diverse enemies+Many and actually good weapons+Very well done platforming+Finally a not annoying camera+Plain-spoken social criticism+Ok story+Top notch music (Noisia!!!!)+Quite well optimized+Final boss+Replay value (7 different difficulty settings!)-Devil trigger is useless (only looks cool)-No Definitive Edition contents (seriously tho, even if we had to pay for it, we would buy that)-Little bit short (~10hs)In overall: Although the DMC fanbase mostly hates this game for being slightly easier and not being anime (thanks god) it doesn't mean it's not a good game. I have no problem with anime, actually I even like it, BUT! older DMC games (especially 3) used anime very badly in their games (clichés or just simply trying to be cool in an anime way well...let's say unsuccessfully).

												Played, completed in about 10 hours, and started again in the new difficulty mode. Good replayability, once you're done with the story you just want to start from scratch and keep slaying demons, while collecting all of Dante's moves and powerups. The game runs with good graphics without fps issues even during the most violent battles. The combat system is very dynamic and enables for many combos and more moves can be unlocked while progressing in the game. By quickly changing Dante's weapons (and therefore combat style and moves) one can concatenate long and various combos. Wven though a bit too predictable the story is interesting enough, and Dante's  attitude sure helps. The scenery is always gorgeous: you can never be sure about what's going to happen once you're  dragged into the Limbo, except it's going to be exaggerated and fun. And what to say about the music... well... just perfect to go along with the quick and vicious fights offered. To concude, a must for any lover of  the genre.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I wanted to try this game out because one of my most anticipated games, Hellblade, is being made by the same creators of this game. I am very happy to say that there is so much fun to be had in this game. The gameplay is fast-paced, but rewards players for taking the time to study all the combos. The boss battles in this game are some of my favorite, and really do see who took the time to learn all the moves. It's also very fun to compare your score with friends after beating certain levels. Coming in, I wasn't expecting much from the story, but I was very pleasantly surprised by it. The game builds a very interesting world and concept, with character developement from both Dante and Virgil. It even has a great and shocking end bossfight which makes me hope that when the developers are done with Hellblade, they'll get to work on a sequel to DmC. Unfortunetly, the campaign is very short, but it'll make you want to replay levels again on higher difficulties to get the best possible score you can. Theres also a "Bloody Palace" mode that has you fight off against hordes of enemies, which can be fun and is a great time killer. The voice acting most of the time is good, but there are sometimes where it tends to get a bit sloppy. The music is also very fitting for the character of Dante and the situations he is in. You'll mostly be hearing Rock, Metal, and Dubstep. Something else I really liked about this game was the platforming. Platforming is fast and fun, but it isn't mindless. In the end, DmC Devil May Cry is a game that provides alot of fun especially if you know a friend who also owns the game and wants to compare scores, but the storyline is very short.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												DMC: Devil May Cry ReviewI never had the pleasure to play the previous Devil May Cry games. They came out during a time when I was not allowed to not even touch an M-Rated game. Once I was older, I never sought them out and soon forgot about them. I regret that...slightly.DMC is a prequel/reboot to the Devil May Cry series. It follows the spawn of an angel/demon relation as he tries to find out where he fits in this world and what a world it is! Ninja Theory may not be so subtle in their approach here, but it does go a long way to making DMC's world feel unique among its contemporaries. It's an entire satire on modern capitalism and political ideologies, but it's cool to see the developer have the guts to stick by its presentation and not skimp on it's more obvious satire of more popular people like the infamous Bill O' Reilly. The gameplay is immensely visceral and very complex albeit I believe not as much as previous entries. Nonetheless it's a good starter point for anyone interested in the series. The combos, while there might be many, end up becoming quite simple to memorize after a while since every weapon has the same combos with some slight variations. Overall, it's very refreshing to play a melee combat game that has a bigger move-set than it's contemporaries. Be warned, while this game is easier than previous Devil May Cry iterations, those iterations were known to be pretty difficult. This leads to Devil May Cry being a tougher game than usual and a game that requires your full attention at all times. This might be one game that you should be able to start on Easy instead of Medium without making you feel like you suck. Thankfully the game makes it simple for you to remember combos and times to dodge by using creative visual cues. The gameplay is the main reason to play DMC and trust me it does not disappoint in that department. As for the story of DMC, it ends up being kind of a mixed bag, but overall a much more compelling narrative than most titles released today. While sometimes you might wonder why the developers didn't just make a film, you'll quickly grow accustomed to the slick cinematography and intriguing story. Without giving any spoilers away, the game has some detours in the story that feel more like padding to artificially lengthen the game and ends up messing with the pacing of the story. The main bad guy is intriguing, but unfortunately is not given time to grow to feel like he is a menacing, credible threat. Towards the end a subplot is thrown in with very little flair and is never given enough time throughout the story to be believable. It makes the characters involved in this scene do things that are kind of uncharacteristic, and contradictory to their established personalities.  Overall the story is compelling, but is filled with many tropes and other maladies that bog it down a bit.You may be wondering if I like this game? I’ll tell you this much. I love this game, and while my critical eye is quick to catch where it falls short, as a new fan I must say that I loved being in this world and following the characters on their respective journeys. So it pains me to say that it is a damn shame that we may not be getting a sequel to this game. Being the lowest sold in the series, it makes the prospects of a sequel highly unlikely, which is really unfortunate. From the slick presentation, intriguing story, compelling characters, to engaging combat; DMC will alway remain on my mind as a what if. A series with great potential held back by mediocre sales. One thing's for sure though...I’m going to go back and see if I can play all the old Devil May Cry games. I need more Devil May Cry! 8.7/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												This Review focuses on DMC: Devil May Cry as in individual game, rather than one attached to the previous Devil May Cry series created by Capcom.Personally, I like the old series better, however I had to try my best to stay impartial when giving this game a review.Contains Spoilers!!If you want a short version of this review, please just skip down to the “Overall” section. If you want to read the in-depth information, feel free to read my whole reviewTechnicalI personally enjoyed the games updated graphics and texture features. The textures on the enemies and spawns fit the demonic theme of the enemies perfectly. The detail in the environment added to the overall emersion of the game and the missions, making the plot easier to get dragged into. My only argument about the graphics and textures is that in some points,  such as the fight with Mundus’ mistress , the backgrounds can be somewhat distracting and disorienting to the fight at hand.The mechanics fit the game quite nicely, however on a PC the controls were a little bit whacky. It is hard to make these types of controls for the PC, and I think the game creators did a good job of trying to make it so that you could access all of the skills and combinations for all of the weapons you acquire with this game. It can be hard to remember all the massive amounts of attack combos, but they make it so that the game doesn't require every single combo in order to succeed. Some of the combos are just clicking patterns with your mouse, but others require you to knock an enemy into the air.However, if you’re not good with aerial combos, the game creators made combos and chains on the ground that are just as strong. I know that I survived the game without even realizing that I was using certain combos that I’d unlocked. However, if you’re picky about combos and chain attacks, the game gives you plenty, if not almost too many, combos to practice and learn from, and the game doesn’t make you practice them in the middle of the story, and you are able to revisit them in training mode. Lastly, if you’re big on combos and chains, you can earn additional points toward your missions overall rating. (D-SSS), through your chains and combos.The addition of "style points" and rankings based on impressive chains and combos makes it a goal to hit combos, and not a necessity. I personally enjoy all the different chains and combos that they made possible with the game, even if they are tricky to remember. It gives the game a bit more flavor. The best part of this, in my opinion, is that the combos are optional, meaning that the game doesn’t make you learn and master every combo on a dummy a million times, to be able to continue with your game. You can do that on your own time.The unlocking of these skills and combos with rank-up points is also another thing I think that adds to the games flavor. Being able to unlock combos that you think you'll use, and the option to chose not to unlock ones that you don't think you'll use adds the feeling of customization to the game. Even though you'll probably need to unlock everything by the time you finish the game, there are several combos and skills that I didn't know I had prior to visiting the training area. The training area allows you to practice different combos and chains, and I like that as well about the game. It came in handy for me to figure out which set of skills works best with my fighting style, and which ones to avoid.The music choice was a bit edgy for my liking, however the old DMC games contained heavy music similar in style to that used in this game, so I can at least say that element is consistent with the previous series.Character/Plot DevelopmentThe character development for the main characters is solid, and you get to know the main characters the best-as in any game. However, the development of the supporting characters wasn’t as strong. (Such as Virgil, Dante’s brother. You get to know general information about Virgil, but there are still a lot of questions that players may have, assuming that you didn't play the older games.) The development of nemesis characters and boss characters is solid, in that you get to know why you’re trying to kill them, why they are against you, and how you get to the point of facing them. I think this is very important in a game and it’s character development, because why spend the time fighting a boss if it doesn’t have a purpose? In some games hordes all look the same, but some enemies are stronger than others with different skill sets and stats, and it’s important to make stronger Horde enemies stand out. DMC does a very good job with this. The horde enemies have different looks based on their attacks, and the stronger a Horde enemy is, the bigger and nastier the creators made it look. This made it easy for me to tell who to focus on first, and who to shred through at the end. The last aspect of the horde that I think that DMC did a good job of showing, is that each part of the horde is important. If you forget to kill something in the air, it will continue to hurt you and make itself noticeable to you until you get around to it. Nothing really goes unnoticed in the horde, and I appreciate that every enemy has a purpose.!Spoiler Alert! The development of Dante as a character (not related to the Dante used in previous games, but rather looking at him as a completely different person) made me very pleased. You’re as “in the dark” as he is about who is is, and what he is, at most points in the game. Personally, I just assumed that he was a full demon based on his portrayal in the opening scenes, but I was surprised to find out he was a nephilim, and I was pleased with the way that the story carried through with the information. The stories of Dante’s parents are told through several little hints and clues, but it all comes together nicely, and it fills in the blanks that many games tend to leave open. Flashbacks are properly used to portray Dante’s past, and they’re interactive. The makers used the idea of “limbo” in a great way in order to show Dante’s history.My one complaint however, would be the immaturity of his character. He seems like an attractive man♥♥♥♥♥ at the beginning, but we find out (or at least I did) that he's got the attitude of a 12 year old, which was a major turn-off for me. (I'm trying my best not to compare this DMC with the old ones, but if I had to say anything, old Dante is witty and cool and this one is edgy and annoying.)The development of other characters, such as Vergil and Kat, was a bit weaker, but you could see how they tied into Dante’s success. You learn about their history through working with them and their stories are revealed through little hints.OverallIn general, I give this game a positive rating, and on a scale of 1-5 I'd rate it a 4 as an individual game, but in comparison to the old DMC series, it would be a -1 (again, that's my bias talking).The mechanics fit the game, but can be tricky to master, and some mechanics must be mastered in order to complete the game. The game gives you some degree of customization with skills and perks, but since the main characters are set, the lack of player customization is appropriate. There are DLC packs and unlocking features that allow you to change the appearance of Dante and Vergil, however they don’t add much to the game, nor take away from it. The plot development is solid, but sweet and short, and I wouldn’t say this game has much replay value. There are a variety of difficulties, making it so that you could focus on the mechanics and battles, or the story. But in all game modes, if you can handle it, the story development is worth playing through. The main character development is solid, but the supporting character development is a bit

number of helpful: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Genre: Action-Adventure Platformer / Hack and SlashSub-Genre: Hardcore Hack and SlashAtmosphere: 10/10 - The scenery in this game is absolutely breathtaking with art visuals you could chew on for hours. Due to the nature of the gameplay, the background is consistently changing as you progress. This was no lazy task, my friend. The atmosphere immediately immerses you into the world of DMC the second you turn it on.Sound: 10/10 - Every slice, every shot, every dodge, & every grapple have their own unique sounds. I did not find one recycled sound track throughout the entire game. They are all loud, pronounced, and crisp.Gameplay: 11/10 - You have five weapons to play with and upgrade: A sword, an axe, a scythe, two guns, and a gauntlet. You have the power to switch these out seamlessly, connecting different weapons for different combos to decimate your enemies. It is fun and easy to get innovative. This game has new game plus, as well as seven difficulty settings to play through. On top of that, there is another game mode called Bloody Palace Mode where you fight hordes of enemies as long as you can, eventually facing each boss as long as you can survive. Points earned in that mode carry over to the normal campaign.You can compare this game to it's Eastern counterpart if you want to, but why butt heads just for the sake of butting heads?Ninja Theory took an already developed franchise - some argue not yet fully developed - and rebooted it.They changed the look, they changed the feel, they changed Dante - they changed Devil May Cry.Does that automatically make it bad? To some it does, and for those people they can negate it's existence all they want. But for the other curious brains out there I can tell you that whether you're a fan of the original or not, this is one solid hardcore hack and slash.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												     Definitely one of the coolest games I've ever played. I can see many people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about betrayal of the original series... But I think it is a step for the better. I've played through DMC IV before and only thing I found better there was much more complex Dante's gunplay. But apart from that, I've found this game to be better in every conceivable way: STORY:     Although Dante's attitude in DMC IV and I suppose the previous games was no doubt cool, I found it a little bit too much anime-y and cliché. In this prequel, Dante is younger, confident, straight-forward, care-free rebel, as lovable as the older himself and much more relatable, mostly because player is able to discover Dante as he discovers himself in the story. The story itself holds together beautifully despite being heavily varied, and story elements like demons, angels and Limbo not only make sense, but they add insane cool factor. Everything in the story works in favor of bringing you the best possible feeling, and that, ladies and gentlemen, is rare.      Character-wise, the cast is not by any means extensive. Besides Dante, his brother Vergil, Vergil's protegeé Kat and four or five antagonists you will sooner or later face as bosses, there is only Phineas, a pacifist blind demon with mechanical eye trapped in Limbo that will help Dante along the way. Other than those are just mindless demons to kill. But don't worry, those few are able to carry to story without any struggle.GAMEPLAY:     The core of the gameplay is of course the exquisite complex combat system. It is easy to handle, yet tricky to master. There are few basic actions that player controls, and then there are variables, such as timing, chaining combos, which angel or demon weapon is player currently using, which firearm... Player with enough skill can use this system to great depth. It may seem as too much at first, but as you get more and more acquainted with the system, the more sense it makes. You start developing different strategies for different enemies, and most importantly, you'll develop your own style of gameplay. The tools this game offers you can bring a great variety of approaches to defeating your enemies. Having said that, I must also mention that this applies mostly for the meelee weapons, since I felt that firearms were of little significance and power, and besides specific cases, I had no need to use them at all.      Another part of gameplay is platforming. Dante's controls are quite fluent and easy, so if there is any difficulty to platforming, i lies in design, not in controls. The platforming also benefits a great deal from tools such as Angel Lift and Demon Whip, which not only add variety, but also a new dynamic and occasionaly even logic elements, not to mention their use in combat.     When the combat and platforming clash together, a boss fight is born. Boss fights in DMC are a true testament to the gameplay mechanics. Not only are you forced to use a great variety of your skills to even survive them, but you also have to look for bosses' weak spots, come up with specific strategies and really put yourself into the fight.      DmC also relies heavily upon exploration and replayability. Although there is no open world and the way to reach the progression of the story is never more than one, the game offers many side tracks leading to items or challenges. You can also revisit all the locations after you acquire a new set of skills, and try to reach prizes that you were not able to before. A great deal of replayability lies it the many levels of difficulty you can replay the game on and test your skills. GRAPHICS:     DmC is one of the most beautiful games I, as a graphic designer by trade, ever played. It doesn't rely upon revolutionary, cutting-edge technology (Although its technological level is quite high as well), but rather on style. Majority of actual gameplay happens after Dante is pulled into Limbo, a twisted version of whatever setting he was currently in, where he can utilise all of his nephilim powers. And it is the idea Limbo that allowed the artists and developers of the game bring in the real twisted beauty DmC has to offer. Be it the city rotting under the rule of demons, night club reality changing to the beat of the music or old mansion where Dante and Vergil spent their early childhood, a great amount of detail and thought can be seen anywhere. And not only that, your surroundings can change at any given moment in the story, bringing you a new, breathtaking sight or often fast-paced platforming challenge.      Design of characters and enemies is equally thought out and accordingly twisted. Artists were able to avoid too much cliché in design, yet were able to preserve the feeling any given enemy or boss should emmit. If the Succubus is supposed to be disgusting, be well damn sure it looks disgusting as hell! SOUND:    The general coolness of the game of course wouldn't be complete without equally cool soundtrack, and it was delivered. Music selected fits the vibe of the game and really helps to increase the immersion. I have nothing more to say about that. Great work on the music.      In conclusion I'd say that DmC is truly a great game. It bring all its elements to nearly perfection. It is unapologetic, cool and action-packed, yet refined and masterfully executed. There are many fans of the original series that are hating the changes, but that is just how some fans are, narrow-minded and blindfolded by the things they love. There is no point in arguing, so don't waste time and rather go play one of the best games of 2013, DmC: Devil May Cry.9/10TIPS:     Learn how to use your weapons. Each of them is good for something else. Rebellion is universal, Osiris is great against groups of enemies and also for juggling them in the air, where most of them are helpless, Aquila is weaker than Osiris, but is great at crowd control, since it allows you to pull a number of enemies to you, stagger many enemies in one attack, trap them for a while and even transform dante into tornado of hits that carries enemies along. On the other hand, demon weapons are more fit for fighting single, strong enemies, since they shatter shields and knock back smaller ememies. Arbiter has heavy strikes, that can leave Dante exposed for quick attack if timed incorectly, but are devastating when they land. Also, Arbiter has some pretty powerful long distance attacks. Eryx is more complex than Arbiter, since timing is everything with it. It can be quicker than Arbiter, but at the same time weaker. The catch is that every attack is chargeable and has three levels of power, last one being among the most powerful moves you can perform in the game. It has also some area-of-effect moves that damage all the enemies about. The key to quick and cool destruction of your enemies is not only learning their weaknesses, but also forming combos with different weapons in quick succession. Every weapons has a moment after first two basic attacks, when if you wait until the weapons shines a little and then proceed with another basic attack, another combo starts that is more powerfull, more specific or has a different effect. The great thing about this that you can use to your advantage is that in the moment of waiting to start this different combo you can switch weapons and do the special combo of another weapon. For instance, you can do two quick slashes with Rebellion or Osiris and the swich to Arbiter's special combo, Trinity Smash, which does thrice the damage as Arbiter's usual last attack, and you can achieve this devastation in much shorter time that using the two slow initial attacks of Arbiter.       I also have to recommend downloading the Bloody Palace addon. It's free, it's easy way to learn how to use weapons and fight enemies, also to earn orbs, and, most importantly, it's fun, especially if you are in mood for some DmC action right away.

												I have not played the previous DMC games, for whatever that is worth or not worth to some people, but I have thoroughly enjoyed this reboot.Things might start out a bit slow in the beginning when you haven't yet unlocked all the goodies and combos, but it's a nice way to pass the time once things get rolling, which is greatly supplemented by the free "Bloody Palace" DLC, which basically puts you in a survival mode of sorts, going up against tougher baddies, bosses, as well as the tougher versions of the tougher baddies, for as long as your heart desires - something I felt sorely missing in MGR: Revengenana.In fact, the only gripe I really have with the game are the weapon- or, rather, color-specific demons, which can break the flow of the combat early on, though this is less noticable later, when you've upgraded said weapons.If you sometimes want to slice♥♥♥♥♥♥up for a couple of hours, then this might just be the game for you. Especially if you can get it on sale. Seriously - Bloody Palace. Try it.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												I'm pretty late with this, considering that I bought the game a week after its release, because I had to look at DmC with quite an ambivalence.After giving it some thought now I decided it's time for my take:This game is for you if:-you like the devil may cry franchise and are not offended by this being a reboot-you can stomach juvenile personalities and  a not-so-ambitious story about a "...schizophrenic world that is being continuously corrupted by the corporate big boss and his lackeys, where you play as the cool guy with super powers that tries to save the world with his fancy weapons and never misses the opportunity for a witty(?) comment."-you actually know what this game's story and characters are like and don't mind/care-you like fast paced action, a lot of room for creating cool combos and all that with fancy graphics (they really are fancy)-you like to squeeze every last drop out of the provided gameplay mechanics and spend hours and hours to master the game AND feel rewarded for it-you just want to hop into a game, not having to care about anything that is being said, and simply unload on monsters-you like combichrist and noisia (or that type of music in general)-you played the other DMCs and had issues with their difficulty (this game is VERY forgiving)This game is NOT for you if:-you hate NinjaTheory (and their disrespect towards the fans of the franchise that were not a 100% convinced that this game is/was the second coming) and this seems like a compelling argument to you-you really care about a well written, original story/characters/dialogues  -  feels like a stereotypical teenager's take on DMC-challenging boss fights are a must for you (there are 6ish bosses that feel like recoloured/textured versions of another - except for the very last one, that one is really good)-you expect a similar skill cap to DMC 3/4 and combo variety of that level - DmC is infinitely easier and the difference between 100 hours and 1000 hours of gameplay/practice is marginal -you want a built-in turbo mode (there is a mod for this tho)For a diehard DMC fan like me it was really difficult to give this game a proper review.I mean, look at how awkward it is, even after all this time.I've spent more than a thousand hours on DMC 3/4 on multiple platforms and versions and have yet to master them. DmC has nothing left to show me after the 100+ hours I put into it - good 100+ hours I admit.Unlike with the former two games, I'm done with this one.Conclusion:This game is good and you should buy it.Do not expect D'M'C, this is DmC - keep that in mind and you will have a great time.

												Despite Dantes radical new look I can safely say that Ninja theory has satisfied me (a hardcore DMC fan). I was incredibly sceptical going into this revamp of the franchise as would any fan of a series if the main caracter got a facelift but after playing through the entire story 3 times I have several things to say:- Gameplay was both familiar yet edgy, the new weapon switching system flowed faster and as hard as it sounds made the combat even more engaging.- Story, The story was great if you put aside your complaints about his looks Dante acts no different to any other DMC with his smartass comments and his edgy moves and if you hardcore fans can make it to the end you will be pleasantly suprised.- The art style was different and if you actually notice the HD options in the menu (sadly I only found it on my second play through) you can clearly see that it is not just a simple conole port. content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Probably a more beginner-friendly DMC game than DMC 4, but you can still crank up the difficulty to get a more hardcore, challenging, and rewarding experience just like you can get with DMC 4. PROS:+Cool and spectacular visuals and level altering effects in each stage+Music by Noisia (if you're a fan of them)+In DMC 4 I found the controls to be a little bit clunky compared to DmC, but you could also argue that it just adds a layer of mechanical execution that enhances the challenge and feeling of mastery. In DmC, though, they provided what I thought to be a really clever and usable way to switch weapons on-the-fly and mid-combo (making use of both triggers to let you use "demon" or "angel" weapons without having to reach over to the D pad). Makes it easier to come up with combos that span multiple weapons.+Dante's dialogue and behavior is so over-the-top and irreverent that you kinda have to stop taking it seriosly and just laugh at it.+Ability to play at higher difficulty levels to experience the challenge you may have felt when playing earlier DMC games+Ranking system and leaderboards to encourage you to develop skill and mastery (absolutely necessary for this sort of game to be any fun)CONS-In DMC 4, you had a lot of different enemy types and it seemed you could mostly hit all of them with whatever weapons you wanted. In DmC, some enemies have an "element", meaning you can only damage them with one type of weapon. I found this to be kind of annoying. You might say that it adds a layer of challenge for high-level play that wasn't present in earlier DMC games, though.-Some of the platform sections feel like they go on for too long and can get boring.Overall, veterans of DMC will probably prefer sinking more hours into DMC 4. I'd recommend this for newcomers to this series or to hack and slash games in general. If you have a Wii U, though, and you're looking for an excellent hack and slash, I'd recommend Bayonetta 2 over this.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												I fully understand that this reboot "divided" the DMC fanbase and that some absolutely hate the new version of Dante. But as a dude who's played all the Devil May Cry games (my favorite is the third), I can't lie - I actually REALLY liked this. I think it might be one of the best action games I've played in recent memory. If that makes me not a "real" Devil May Cry fan, then so be it. For me, the combat just feels so GOOD. Some people say that it's too easy or not as deep as the older games, which is possibly true, seeing that I regularly get SS or SSS ranks in DmC and rarely did in DMC4. But switching between sword, angelic scythe, devil axe, fiery gauntlets, heaven ninja stars and three different types of gun is such seamless fun, and I love the smooth way that Dante controls and the slightly simplified button inputs. This plus the fact that for once in a Devil May Cry I have almost complete control over the camera is just a dream to me, and a sign of what the old games could have achieved if they didn't have fixed camera angles. (Some people like fixed cameras; I kinda don't, especially when I'm trying to juggle an enemy and the dang view changes on me in mid-air.) There's plenty of other solid stuff in DmC if you're willing to give it a chance - the game's colorful, with bright levels that change on you and some fun environmental traversal aspects that reminded me a little of Prince of Persia and Castlevania, since Dante's got a whip he can use to latch onto platforms. The story kept me engaged more than all other DMC games with the exception of DMC3, but I've seen some folks saying that they absolutely abhorred it, so your enjoyment may vary. Dante isn't as much of an "emo edgelord" as they say he is; he's really more of a punk than anything else, and by the end of the game he becomes more like the old Dante we know and love. (Yes, his hair turns white.) Vergil is quite different; he was your typical silent anime assassin badass in the past and they made him into more of a Julian Assange-sorta character here. I think a lot of people probably hate how much he talks in the game, but hey, he controls awesomely in his DLC epilogue.In short, I dug DmC. I can completely understand why people despised it, since Capcom sprung this reboot on a fanbase that didn't think restarting the whole franchise was necessary. But IMHO, this has ended up as my second-favorite Devil May Cry, and I think it's a shame that we're unlikely to see a DmC 2 after the mixed reception this got. (Maybe I'm wrong. I hope so!)

So I believe that anyone can read without fear of receiving any compromising information, however, should this occur notify me in the comments and it will be changed."DmC: Devil May Cry" this is a Reboot (Maybe not so true that it is a reboot, after all it is an alternate reality, or even part of the story and tells how it happened before the "DMC3 ") of consecrated franchise" Devil May Cry ", which was produced and only developed by CAPCOM, however this new development project was given by the" Ninja Theory "she being supervised by it. The game was released in its final version on January 24, 2013.A whole reimagining was proposed: characters, settings as well as throughout history, have been completely redesigned and given a Western perspective in contrast to the other background games (or predecessors) of the franchise.Two things were kept and that all give a special touch to the game is its incredibly fluid gameplay and its heavy songs that dictate the pace of the game, being frantic as all other franchise. Something has changed and I particularly liked a lot was the fact that Dante not be the son of a devil with a human, but the son of a devil with an angel making him a "Nephilim" .  Unfortunately this change has changed the transformation and become something which was actually just a frenzy mode and not really a transformation. Fortunately with this exchange brought other functions, including the use of specific weapons for each character so leaving everything more dynamic, more than in other games.“DmC: Devil May Cry - Which Devil Trigger Looks The Best? ” - All Transformations


YouTube™ Video: DmC: Devil May Cry - Which Devil Trigger Looks The Best?

On the gameplay, portray that is so defined as in other games in the franchise. The MODE 1 transitions, 2 & 3 may be made temporarily by pressing a button while making combos or even permanently, where just push a button will make the change and it will remain so until the player decides.The style meter can stimulate very well the player to show all their potential, as well as the game. After all to get better scores is necessary to make long combos and using various weapons, this is a great way to stimulate the purchase of upgrades for all weapons and not just those most adapted, as this may not be enough to have RANK high : Dirty, Cruel, Brutal, Anarchic, Savage, SSadistic & SSSensational.Combos with the secrets discovered phase, the more time gameplay give a certain score with RANK by respective multipliers. consumed items and deaths have negatively to your score, and item equals - x points and deaths equals - x% of points received. Find all the secrets ensures RANK permanent SSS on the stage, however for this is not so simple, because even in the early stages are inaccessible locations and which can only be discovered when the advance further in the game, getting the necessary upgrades, return those phases and repeat all the way.The game has several game modes, the first with 3 levels and the rest of modes, including Bloody Palace will only be unlocked after completing the game the first time.Something that pleased me a lot is that all modes are connected, by that I mean that no matter what stage you choose all your upgrades will be available, regardless of your game mode and it makes a huge difference.About the extras each time complete the game again is received images and skins as a bonus, other items can be unlocked as well.Plot summary: The story is set in Limbo City, a modern city secretly controlled by demons, manipulating humanity through the comforts of life, with demons living in a parallel plan - Limbo. Living on the margins of society and out of the brainwashing is Dante, a young man in conflict with the demons that constantly try to kill him, and the civilian authorities that control them. Dante is warned by Kat who is in danger and she with her psychic can help him escape from Limbo which was sucked there. After this time he is invited to meet the head of "The Order." After being aware about the organization and about your goal. Dante finds out about his past and his connection with the head of the organization. In the course of events the three characters follow the goal of ridding the world of demons, going after the major cause of all corruption. Things that caught my attention in particular:- Excellent Soundtrack.- Great gameplay, despite the available arsenal numberless.- Story surroundings.DmC: Devil May Cry received mixed reviews, both by changes in character as for thinking that there would be changes in gameplay, such as if he had the rebellion the person would not play and the like. This was, as already mentioned, because the very CAPCOM wanted to give a new look, so much so that if it were not so the Ninja Theory have worked the new designer in the old character. However that look based on "The Dark Knight" was great. Even with all the changes the game has not lost its characteristics as many have pointed out, I say this as someone who played their other versions for PS2, this fantastic and well fluid. His songs are so good and its replay factor is as big as the other versions. His story despite trying a touch of reality to the game remains interesting and certainly the game is worth.Some of the links used as reference in the analysis of the construction:https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/DmC:_Devil_May_Cryhttp://www.saraivaconteudo.com.br/Materias/Post/49917http://www.arkade.com.br/devil-may-cry-ganhara-reboot-novo-jogo-trailer/ https://eugostodejogar.wordpress.com/2013/01/22/dmc-o-reboot-da-serie-devil-may-cry/ For similar Steamified Reviews and Giveaways, please visit  steamified [steamified.com]. content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This is an Amazing game. A true spectacle and a must-have for anybody who loves Hack'n'Slash Platformers!Don't be discouraged from getting the game by people who hate on it just because it isn't exactly the same like a previous installment of DmC. This game is unique and a completely different retelling of the story, but that does not mean it is bad!If you enjoy slaying hordes of enemies and huge, actually fun bosses, as well as a challenge (altho you might need to go through the game a few times before you can actually unlock higher difficulties, which is really not much of  a problem since the game has excellent replayability and tons of secrets), this will be a real treat for you!Make sure you get the Vergil's Downfall DLC if you want the full Experience of the game, it lets you play as Vergil and continues the story of the original game, with new enemies, weapons, secrets and more!A really, really underrated game. As you complete the game you will not only get access to more difficulties, but also new costumes you can use for your character, and none of the points you've collected during gameplay will ever get lost! If you start a new game at any difficulty, you will still have all your Upgrades and points, meaning the game has tremendous replay value!

												played all the original devil may cry games as a kid/teenager, loved them to bits, but only picked this up recently in humble bundle capcom. i'll start with CONS first because there's not many- 30 fps locked cinematics (i play at 144 hz so it rips me out of the atmosphere of the game completely)- wierd menus with no mouse or advanced graphics options- Dante is a hipser in an alternate british inspired universe that isn't conanical to the originals (big annoyance for me)- Not enough weapon upgrades to spend hoarding skill points on.PROS THOUGH! - lives up to the franchise in attitude, combat, style- beautiful visuals- new and creative enemies that include air combat a LOT more than the original games- FLUID AS ♥♥♥♥ combat, with the toggle switching weapon system, it's a lot more dynamic.- Grappling hooks- QT 3.14 female sidekick- plays surprisingly well on keyboard and mouse, if you're unable to fetch a controller8/10 so far, really enjoying it.

												overall a great reboot to the series and highly recommended to old and new playersthe good:- the combat is great and fluid, mixing between weapons is awesome - great graphics and very amazing and creative art style. - killer soundtrack, a mix between electronic and industrial metal - the story is good yet predictable but unfolds in a great way.- all the modes from dmc 4 are here ( heaven and hell, hell or hell, DmD..etc)the bad:- the platforming sections are boring and takes away from the fun - the last few missions are way less fun than the others (too much platforming and less combat) even the story takes a dip too- boss battles, very easy even on the harder difficulties.the neutral: (bad for me but might be good to others)- the game is on the easy side, Much easier than 3.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												This game has been sat, uninstalled, for a long time in my library.As an avid fan of the original series I must admit I was dubious about this reboot.Having said that I very much enjoyed this game and below I will try to cover it in detail why.There were definately issues with the narrative & Ninja Theory were obviously trying to suggest a political undertone relating to today but the story was at least unique & it managed to keep me enaged for the duration. 'New Dante' is a common problem I see reported online & though he may be a little jarring to fans of the old titles, he did grow on me.I won't comment on the graphics at this point in time as I had to resort to an old GPU not long into my gameplay.I very much enjoyed the music in the old games, the combination of metal & classical scores suited the gothic theme they were trying to portray. This is not what you will find in this new iteration, but the new mix of heavy rock and drum & bass definately suits the new narrative.The one area I think this game really shines is combat mechanics. The way you can switch between weapons & continue combo's is fluid & very satisfying. Ninja Theory did a great job of making the weapons feel unique & have impact when attacking enemies. They have very much captured the feel of the original 'hack & slash' series & in all honestly have improved on the gameplay of the old games.In summary if you're a fan of the original series then this game is definately worth a purchase, if you're a little unsure then maybe wait for a sale. Either way if you're a fan of this genre of game then it isn't worth missing!One final note: Having completed the title, could I see new Dante become original Dante?.....Sure....now you want to give it a try right?!

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This is a really excellent character action game that didn't overstay its welcome.  It has an involved and complicated combat system - much more so that the Batman games which are basically "press A for awesome".  Even as a newcomer to the series and relatively inexperienced character action gamer, the combat was intuitive and rewarding to master.The plot was somewhat standard but was done well even so.  The game is beautiful and has a great deal of variety in enemy design, combat scenarios, and bosses.  I kept thinking I would put it down, but I ended up finishing it in 2 settings.  The difficulty gradually increases but does so in a more or less fair manner.  It has all the nice Steam features (cloud, trading cards, etc).Really an excellent game all around and well worth the (discounted) price I paid.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Before you read this review, you should keep in-mind that I've never played a Devil May Cry game before so I don't know how it compares to past games. With that said, DmC: Devil May Cry is a pretty great game with enjoyable gameplay and a surprisingly good story. THE PROS: Surpisingly good story that has a mix of seriousness and jokes.Fun gameplay that has a "Stylish" system -- you earn more points by doing combos that uses a variety of different attacks, and not just the same moves over and over again.As the story progresses, you see Dante go from "not caring" about anything to actually caring about everything.Great level design full of secrets.You unlock new weapons/abilties as you progress.Weapons and abilities can be upgraded with skill points -- or even new abilities can be unlocked with skill points.Beating the game on higher difficulties will unlock even higher diffculties multiple times, encouraging multiple play-throughs.Some cool unlockable skins.Practice mode.Around 10 hours until you beat the game. THE MIXED: Some may find the game kinda repetitive.Some may also find the game too "try hard" and/or cheesy for their taste.And of course, some may not like Dante's new design (however, I am personally fine with it). THE CONS: I personally found the final boss fight and ending to be kinda dissapointing.Some fights are more annoying/tedious than fun. THE VERDICT:  8.5/10 "Between Great and Amazing" DmC: Devil May Cry really is a great game, and I do recommend it. If you get the game, play it on the Nephilim (hard) diffculty, as it will provide a more challenging and rewarding gameplay experience than the other starting difficulties.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I had heard of this franchise over the years, but I hadn’t ever played it myself before. DmC – Devil May Cry is an action adventure platformer from Ninja Theory and Capcom. Let’s get rocking.The GoodThe first thing that really struck me about DmC was how good the graphics looked. I was playing on lower graphical settings (for the sake of performance) and the game still looked better than a good handful of games that are brand new. They were seriously well done.After gawking at the graphics, I next came to the actual animations. Everything is incredibly fluid: combat, walking, jumping, everything. Even if you’re the laziest, most pathetic mortal on the face of the planet, you can’t help but to feel badass while you’re playing this game. That is just how good the animations make everything look.The next thing that I came to that just impressed the hell right out of me, was the upgrade system. While you are in the store upgrading your abilities or your weapons, I discovered the best upgrade system I had ever seen in a game like this. First of all there is an option for you to try out the upgrade before you commit points to it. That’s right. The game let’s you try out the ability or upgrade before you buy it. Secondly, once you’ve purchased the ability/upgrade, if you end up finding out that you don’t like it or you don’t ever use it you can take the points out (free of charge) and immediately put them into something else. Every game should have this.The music is pretty good. I recall seeing Combichrist being mentioned in the credits and another band, but I can’t remember who. That being said, Combichrist was an excellent choice for this game as their contributions to the soundtrack really went well with all the action.Enemy design was pretty cool. Normally, when I think about demons, I’m thinking about big, fleshy, horned monsters that run amok and torment everyone in their path. This was not even close to the case in DmC however. Demons (while some do have fleshy bits) are mostly made from what looks like metal, ceramics, and bone. It was a very interesting take on demonic entities (and, albeit, a refreshing one).Boss design (with the exception of Mundus) was also really cool. Let’s just say that the Succubus is not going to look like your expectations in the slightest.The BadDmC started out with a great story. There were great cutscenes, dialogue, a giant Hunter Demon with a ridiculously cool voice. However, as the game went on, the quality of the dialogue and the story went steadily downhill. By the end of the game things had become so predictable that I felt like I was watching some edgy 90’s teen movie.The MehThe game is pretty short. I blazed through it in right around seven hours.There is a marked lack of gore in most of the game. I suppose this makes sense as (I mentioned above) most of the demons you fight are made from materials other than flesh and blood.Verdict: YeaDmC is a great game and a great addition to any collection. If you’re a fan of the franchise, you’ll no doubt love it. If you’re new to the franchise, I’m pretty sure that you’ll love it all the same. It has a bit of a steep price tag (especially for how short it is), but, if it went on sale, I’d most certainly snag a copy. As always, thanks for reading.

Posted: December 24, 2016
												This, unlike the third game, is a very well done PC port. I played it a long time ago and just noticed I forgot to recommend it!+ the graphics are quite awesome considering the system requirements aren't set that high+ the combat (flow): Out of all Devil May Cry games I've played, this one has the second best flowing combat (right after DMC3). If you played DMC4 you probably remember that some enemies were really badly designed: either extremely annoying to beat in a group or designed to only be attackable when they show a weakness, which takes away from combat flow. Do you remember? Well, good news and bad news: it's not as bad as it was in DMC4, but it still is restrictive in this edition of the game for some enemies that can only be attacked by a specific type of weapon. In the definitive edition of this game they changed this but, alas, definitive edition is not available on PC. ♥♥♥♥ me, right? I'm still giving the game a plus for this because they improved it from DMC4. It's really not bad.+ the combat (animations): really nothing to criticize here. Dante tears the enemies apart with an elegance and smoothness I've not seen before in this series. I like the combat animations very much.+ the combat (ease of use): the combat is user friendly. Very minor weapon spoilers here, it shouldn't ruin your experience but I'm putting a spoiler tag anyway: There are 2 angelic weapons and 2 demonic ones (and 3 guns), switching between them is quicker than in other games since they come in pairs. You'll know what I mean after little time in the game.. There are not THAT many combos for each weapon but you can combo one weapon into another (by switching weapon DURING a combo), allowing for more combo depth.+/- The story is not that exciting+/- The depth/personality of the characters is okay/meh, depending on taste.- Combat depth, a minor point for me. I know I mentioned above in a POSITIVE point that the combat is easy to learn and easier to master than in, say, DMC4 (Dante) or DMC3. But while I don't care about this much, they simplified the combat somewhat by taking things like style switching away which raised the skill ceiling by a lot. Again, it's not that much of a negative point for me, but it objectively reduces combat depth somewhat so I only find it fair to mention it here.- Combat controls. Most of them feel fine, but I had an issue with two of them on my Xbox360 pad. One was the special gun move for which you have to press A and X at the same time, and the second the devil trigger for which you have to press both L3 and R3 at the same time. Half of the time I wouldn't press them at the exact same time leading to me failing to do what I was intending to do and instead doing some other move that messes the combat up. Instead of using one of the shoulder buttons for, say, the special gun move, BOTH shoulder buttons actually have the same function...WHY!? You CAN rebind those moves, so it is not a problem for me anymore BUT: for some reason, you cannot rebind the devil trigger key in the ingame config. You have to do it manually in the config file, and I see no reason for this to be necessary. Minor negative point for inconvenience.- I'm not a fan of the devil trigger mechanic. It is powerful, yes, but I don't like it. Basically, you use it less often than in other DMC since it takes longer to charge, but it about doubles your damage and makes all (non-boss) enemies unable to act or defend themselves. It should feel powerful, yes, but DMC3/4 had plenty powerful devil triggers that still wouldn't save you from getting beaten up if you perform badly.- I like the cheeky Dante from the other parts in the series more. This one is more rebellious and more of a "♥♥♥♥ you" guy than the cheeky, taunting Dante I know.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I haven't played the others, but as a standalone this is a really good game.The combat is super fun, it's not just spamming. Theres interesting combos that you unlock and different weapons you hold a key to use, similar to God of War, but less inconvieniant. It doesn't just throw health at you either which keeps it from being too easy.The levels are good to explore, really nicely designed. The collectables in the environment attract you to them in a really unique way, and fit perfectly with the art style.The platforming sections aren't exactly challenging but they're entertaining enough. The fast paced sections really keep the action flowing so long as you know what you're doing. I find alot of games never quite get a good balance, though this one is leaning towards the easy side.The art style suits the game and the cinematography complements it brilliantly. The music (which is actually the reason I bought the game) also matches really well and makes the experiance a whole lot more fun. The animations flow really well with both the environment and enemies. Final kill shots, using your last attack on the last enemy, always seem to look great. The characters (which I thought were terrible at first) each quickly show they aren't♥♥♥♥♥♥ Even with the cool guy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the start and that occasionally surfaces, Dante's a pretty cool guy that doesn't afraid of anything. Oh and the facial models and animations are pretty flawless I'd say, not quite HL2 but better than any AssCreed.I am so pleasantly suprised with this game, fun as ♥♥♥♥/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												This review will have SPOILERS! I absolutley recommend this game! All those salty O.G. fan boys that are upset cause Dante doesn't have white hair are just that, salty fan boys. This is a REBOOT! It's supposed to be different! This game is an incredible hack and slash adventure with a pretty great stroy. I genuinely bought all of the characters and the chemistry they all shared. The combos are easy enough to learn but difficult to master which makes multiple playthroughs of levels to get better ratings something you'll do often. But let's go step by step through the game.SPOILER: Dante does infact get white hair for real at the end of the game. Not just an alternate outfit but his character actually has it. When you selct an alternate costume or weapon skin, STANDARD is thw rod used to describe the things dante has and looks like in the beginning. After you BEAT THE GAME, standard is used for a WHITE HAIRED, PAILER Dante, because he used his Devil Trigger and it gave him white hair. IT WAS A BRILLIANT MOVE BY THE DEVELOPERS AT NINJA THEORY. He get's it when he uses his Devil Trigger to defeat Vergil so anyone HATING this game for the lack of white hair CLEARLY DID NOT PLAY THE GAME TO COMPLETION.Story:8/10Short Version: Very god story for a reboot and to me, more engaging than the original Devil May Cry (the first one not the full series) Dante finds Vergil, fights Satan, and tries to save the world. the game ends on a perfect note and sets up a sequel the right way! Long Version: So like I said, this is a reboot and Dante has no idea he is half angel and half demon (even though his sword has obvioulsy materialized from nothing before and he's been to Limbo multiple times according to him.) So we open with a nightclub party and Dante taking girls to his trailor on the pier. A Hunter demon shows up and Kat, the new love interest, shows up in Limbo to warn Dante that the demons have finally found him. He follows and finds the group known as the Order that she works for. His brother, Vergil, is actually the leader of this group and shows Dante who he really is. Dante agrees to help fight back against Mundus who is essentially the Devil. Hack and slash, platforming, and running around ensues as you fight back against the Demons. The Demons have essentially taken over Earth by taking control of the media and a soft drink with demon chemicals in it. Dante takes down both problems and fights Mundus with his brother. Vergil has alterior motives and wants to take over the world but not for evil purposes, just to protect the humans becuase he beleives they are unable to do it themselves. Dante fights him and Vergil dissapears and the credits roll.Gameplay:7/10No lock on function makes aiming a pain if you can't see very well. I never had a single issue during my ENTIRE playthrough without a lock on, but I can see why some may find that annoying. Very fun and fluid combat! Easy combos to learn but more difficult to master. Yes, the S ranking are easier to get than previous DMC games but that doesn't mean they are just given to you. Especially on some groups of enemies. You get multiple wweapons to choose from and some are clearly better than others. Ebony and Ivory aren't even the best gun of the 3 you can choose form which is sort of a let down, but Rebellion is still absolutley insane. Platforming is a blast and the camera hardly gets in your way or fights against you. Generally, you'll use blue (Angel) weapons on blue enemies and red (Devil) weapons on red enemies which makes switching things up in combat a challenge and something you need to do. Devil Trigger is Dante's special ability and it sends every enemy on screen floating and frozen helplessly in the air where you can combo to your heart's content. While I do wish that it just froze time or maybe made Dante faster and stronger, the floating enemies aren't to annoying to hit even when the camera tries to focus away from the one you are hitting.Controls: 9/10Everything you do with this game feels natural. All the buttons are mapped in an amazing way that makes everything feel simple, even through you are balancing 12 weapons at once. I felt myslef utilizing every button on the controller and not even in a clunky way. I can't express enough how great a job Ninja Theory did with getting these controls right. It only misses out on a 10/10 for the controls cause there is 1 button that doesn't get used, the left stick click. The right stick click is used to re-center the camera like most games of this type, but the left stick does nothing. The game lacks a LOCK ON function and they couldn't think to put it on the button they hadn't used yet?Difficulty:6/10Not very challenging on anything below Son of Sparda. Multiple difficulties to play on with some of he higher ones switching up enemie waves and placements for a pretty much completely new playthrough. Fortunately, unlike most games, you only have to beat the game twice to unlock every difficulty rather than having to beat the game on one difficulty to unlock the one above that and so on. Graphics:6/10Not the best looking game on the market and even modest builds could handle it. Just your average, everyday console port!Length:5/104-6 Hours depending on how much you grab along the way. I probably spent a little over an hour total through my run on just checking every corner but a speed run could easily be less than 4 hours. Rather short game but for the genre it isn't unbearable. I wish it would have been longer but that is only because I wanted to play more! Pros:Ease of entry to the series and genreStoryCombat SystemCharacter DevelopmentCons:GraphicsLengthLack of a lock on funtionFinal Verdict: 7/10While the graphics aren't mindblowing and the length leaves you wanting way more, the game does everything else absolutley brilliantly. The character develpoment is on point and, like i said, they set up a sequel with class and it becomes a rebooted franchise that could possibly be better than the original. Still one of the most fun games I have played in a very long time and if you are looking for an amazingly fun time, this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Well, DmCDevil may Cry was a reboot of the fabulous, beloved and awesome Devil May Cry Series, courtesy of Ninja Theory and  CAPCOM. It retells the story of the origins of Dante, Vergil, Sparda and the iconic Eva, in a twist that breaks the cadre of the story from the previous Devil may Cry series.Review: The story was a (bit) half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character development was shallow, and as such, the previous touch and flair that Dante is known for ( Balls, bravery, awesomeness, cool dude) and Vergil's nature ( Loyalty, skill, distaste for firearms, etc) have neen washed away and in their place, are shallow, under-developed and uninspiring characters for whom no fan of devil may Cry series can connect to easily. The fabled Sparda, and his legend is gone. So if you're looking to reconnect to the awesomeness that Devil may Cry used to be, this is not it. It may feel a bit insulting to the series' die-hard fans.Gameplay: Acceotable. Fluid mechanics,  and the camera can get glitchy at times. For the love of all thats' awesome, why did they leave out Lock On to targets out of a hack and slash game? This makes combat cumbersome, especially in Boss Fights (Mundus, anyone? ). The game also has a short learning curve, and as such, new players to the series will be at ease hacking and slashing demons at the comfort of their seats.Graphics: Pretty average. Nothing spectacular. Runs in DirectX9, powered by the Unreal Engine 3. If you're on catalyst (Running an AMD/ATI GPU/APU), ensure you're using the latest driver. The game is known for being glitchy with old versions of AMD Catalyst, and micro-stutter is  relatively common in CrossFire-based systems. Your mileage may vary.The music is great,m if you're into industrial metal. Noisia and CombiChrist worked up quite the charm here, so you'll be in for a blast if its' your kind of thing.Overall rating: 88% in my personal opinion. Despite its shortcomings, this is a great game with excellent gameplay and many hours of fun, especially when you throw in the Vergil's Downfall DLC and the other mode similar to Devil may Cry's 4 Bloody Palace. Again, your mileage may vary. This is a personal opinion and as such, is subject to personal bias.Play the game, and be the judge.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												This is my first Devil May Cry game, so all the criticism it's gotten from old-school fans regarding the "new" Dante are irrelevant to me :)  The game itself is a lot of fun.  Graphics are very good with everything set to "ultra".  Frames never dipped below 60 (check my PC specs in my profile).  The story is interesting, and the dialogues are pretty cool.  Gameplay is very good, combining a ton of weapons, abilities, and moves.  It takes a while to get used to switching between all of them to fit different monsters and environment interactions.  Finding items and collectibles is also fun, although to gain 100% completion you need to go back and replay levels because you won't have every ability needed the first time you tackle most levels.  I'm not into playing games twice (Skyrim and Mass Effect are sole exceptions), but if you do, this game has replayability value.  Finished in 13 hours and gets an A in my book.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												(I previously only played DMC1 and 2)Graphics: The game has probably the best art direction I have ever seen for any action slasher. Great twisted take on modern city settings and very unique environments. All this and it runs smooth like butter on my modest PC.Story/Plot: Mostly meh, only some bright moments like Raptor New Network. The Vergil thing at the end was random and illogical.Mechanics: Very solid mechanics and combos. You can switch between weapon types seamlessly and execute a huge variety of combos and setups. Movement has real weight and there are animation transitions between abilities. Attacks are meaty and controls are responsive. Only complaint is that grappling hook spots can just refuse to trigger even though you are clearly in range, leaving you desperately flailing in midair before falling.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Before you read this review, you should keep in-mind that I've never played a Devil May Cry game before so I don't know how it compares to past games. With that said, DmC: Devil May Cry is a pretty great game with enjoyable gameplay and a surprisingly good story. THE PROS: Surpisingly good story that has a mix of seriousness and jokes.Fun gameplay that has a "Stylish" system -- you earn more points by doing combos that uses a variety of different attacks, and not just the same moves over and over again.As the story progresses, you see Dante go from "not caring" about anything to actually caring about everything.Great level design full of secrets.You unlock new weapons/abilties as you progress.Weapons and abilities can be upgraded with skill points -- or even new abilities can be unlocked with skill points.Beating the game on higher difficulties will unlock even higher diffculties multiple times, encouraging multiple play-throughs.Some cool unlockable skins.Practice mode.Around 10 hours until you beat the game. THE MIXED: Some may find the game kinda repetitive.Some may also find the game too "try hard" and/or cheesy for their taste.And of course, some may not like Dante's new design (however, I am personally fine with it). THE CONS: I personally found the final boss fight and ending to be kinda dissapointing.Some fights are more annoying/tedious than fun. THE VERDICT:  8.5/10 "Between Great and Amazing" DmC: Devil May Cry really is a great game, and I do recommend it. If you get the game, play it on the Nephilim (hard) diffculty, as it will provide a more challenging and rewarding gameplay experience than the other starting difficulties.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I had heard of this franchise over the years, but I hadn’t ever played it myself before. DmC – Devil May Cry is an action adventure platformer from Ninja Theory and Capcom. Let’s get rocking.The GoodThe first thing that really struck me about DmC was how good the graphics looked. I was playing on lower graphical settings (for the sake of performance) and the game still looked better than a good handful of games that are brand new. They were seriously well done.After gawking at the graphics, I next came to the actual animations. Everything is incredibly fluid: combat, walking, jumping, everything. Even if you’re the laziest, most pathetic mortal on the face of the planet, you can’t help but to feel badass while you’re playing this game. That is just how good the animations make everything look.The next thing that I came to that just impressed the hell right out of me, was the upgrade system. While you are in the store upgrading your abilities or your weapons, I discovered the best upgrade system I had ever seen in a game like this. First of all there is an option for you to try out the upgrade before you commit points to it. That’s right. The game let’s you try out the ability or upgrade before you buy it. Secondly, once you’ve purchased the ability/upgrade, if you end up finding out that you don’t like it or you don’t ever use it you can take the points out (free of charge) and immediately put them into something else. Every game should have this.The music is pretty good. I recall seeing Combichrist being mentioned in the credits and another band, but I can’t remember who. That being said, Combichrist was an excellent choice for this game as their contributions to the soundtrack really went well with all the action.Enemy design was pretty cool. Normally, when I think about demons, I’m thinking about big, fleshy, horned monsters that run amok and torment everyone in their path. This was not even close to the case in DmC however. Demons (while some do have fleshy bits) are mostly made from what looks like metal, ceramics, and bone. It was a very interesting take on demonic entities (and, albeit, a refreshing one).Boss design (with the exception of Mundus) was also really cool. Let’s just say that the Succubus is not going to look like your expectations in the slightest.The BadDmC started out with a great story. There were great cutscenes, dialogue, a giant Hunter Demon with a ridiculously cool voice. However, as the game went on, the quality of the dialogue and the story went steadily downhill. By the end of the game things had become so predictable that I felt like I was watching some edgy 90’s teen movie.The MehThe game is pretty short. I blazed through it in right around seven hours.There is a marked lack of gore in most of the game. I suppose this makes sense as (I mentioned above) most of the demons you fight are made from materials other than flesh and blood.Verdict: YeaDmC is a great game and a great addition to any collection. If you’re a fan of the franchise, you’ll no doubt love it. If you’re new to the franchise, I’m pretty sure that you’ll love it all the same. It has a bit of a steep price tag (especially for how short it is), but, if it went on sale, I’d most certainly snag a copy. As always, thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I had heard of this franchise over the years, but I hadn’t ever played it myself before. DmC – Devil May Cry is an action adventure platformer from Ninja Theory and Capcom. Let’s get rocking.The GoodThe first thing that really struck me about DmC was how good the graphics looked. I was playing on lower graphical settings (for the sake of performance) and the game still looked better than a good handful of games that are brand new. They were seriously well done.After gawking at the graphics, I next came to the actual animations. Everything is incredibly fluid: combat, walking, jumping, everything. Even if you’re the laziest, most pathetic mortal on the face of the planet, you can’t help but to feel badass while you’re playing this game. That is just how good the animations make everything look.The next thing that I came to that just impressed the hell right out of me, was the upgrade system. While you are in the store upgrading your abilities or your weapons, I discovered the best upgrade system I had ever seen in a game like this. First of all there is an option for you to try out the upgrade before you commit points to it. That’s right. The game let’s you try out the ability or upgrade before you buy it. Secondly, once you’ve purchased the ability/upgrade, if you end up finding out that you don’t like it or you don’t ever use it you can take the points out (free of charge) and immediately put them into something else. Every game should have this.The music is pretty good. I recall seeing Combichrist being mentioned in the credits and another band, but I can’t remember who. That being said, Combichrist was an excellent choice for this game as their contributions to the soundtrack really went well with all the action.Enemy design was pretty cool. Normally, when I think about demons, I’m thinking about big, fleshy, horned monsters that run amok and torment everyone in their path. This was not even close to the case in DmC however. Demons (while some do have fleshy bits) are mostly made from what looks like metal, ceramics, and bone. I blazed through it in right around seven hours.There is a marked lack of gore in most of the game. I suppose this makes sense as (I mentioned above) most of the demons you fight are made from materials other than flesh and blood.Verdict: YeaDmC is a great game and a great addition to any collection. If you’re a fan of the franchise, you’ll no doubt love it. If you’re new to the franchise, I’m pretty sure that you’ll love it all the same.
