number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												Upon completion of this game.All I have to say is that it's amazing.  I really enjoyed the pacing of the game from start to finish.There was never a moment where it felt really slow.  And most missions as in the original DMC series can be revisited in second playthoughs.While it's very hard to gauge this game since it's on it's own spin.I was one of many who outcried due to the change in Dante and after finishing up this I feel that he's something that I've grown used to.This game very well does parallel the personalities albeit Dante kinda is weird at the beginning of the game. But anyone who's ever really followed the series from 1st game should understand that Dante is the 'rebel' between his twin Vergil.At first it seemed as this game heading towards a very stupid plot but later on as the game unravels you start to witness the polar opposite personalities between Dante and Vergil.  They do bring back the nolstagia, the sense of rivalry betweeen the two and what they stand for which makes it a great game.  Maybe, comparable to DMC3 which is a classic and also my fave DMC game.  And this DmC however does beat out DMC4, as DMC4 had a very lackluster plot and very little character development.  In DmC though, I never encountered or felt the game was very haphazard in the sense that it didn't feel like .. "oh this, is the part where I play Dante.." which was a weird cut-off in the original series.  This game however doesn't do that.  It transitions cutscenes, combat and characters all in one.  It's a very smooth, very wonderful experience.  Almost every character in this game get their time to shine in their own spotlight.  Which didn't go too well on DMC4.Now, on to the gameplay.  Yes, this game does carry on elements from the previous titles and then some.  It does it in some ways better than others.  Having Dante being able to use a multitude of weapons which do have their lineage in playstyle (*helm breaker*etc.) makes for a variety of choice on fighting your enemies.  They even introduce certain enemeis that are only vulnerable to certain types of weapons as well.  The greatest thing about this game though is the non-existent Nero. Of which I very much despised in DMC4.  Because this game carries the grab/grapple moves into Dante's kit. So there's never a need for a Nero.  Which is something I wish they implemented instead in DMC4 for Dante rather than shoe horning an unpleasant character to play as. I'm not ragging DMC4 in any way, loved the game but this DmC fixes everything that was wrong in DMC4 and delivers in a very fluid, dynamic and then some. The music is awesome it definitely delivers in that department.  I love industrial music and they way they mixed dubsteps in certain fights (bosses included) made battles feel funny and enjoyable.But seriously if you're a hardcore DMC fan like I am I suggest picking this up.  Even if it's just on a steam sale, you won't regret it. But opinions are opinions .. I mean I picked it up expecting to hate it.  In the end the whole just took me by surprise.  Vergil's cold, egotistical yet primmed ego is very well existent in this game.  Felt good to have that opposing ego to Dante's more punk♥♥♥♥♥attitude. Overall, feels like a DMC game. 10/10tl;dr this game is about Two Brothers .. Two Brothers!SPOILER: Dante's hair turns all white at the end.  ALL OF IT! so stop crying already!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												The music alone justifies this purchase if you ask me. Particularly the Noisia stuff, although some of Combichrist is also pretty good. The opening music of your first combat scene is Combichrist - Never surrender, it's just freaking epic. Sometimes i will still play lillith's club or another theme (hunter, barbas, poison) even after all this time because it's just that good.The gameplay was delightfully smooth. It's a lot easier to switch between weapons for a sick combo than it was in DMC 4 which is the only other DMC i had previously played. You get the hang of the battle system infinitely faster than in DMC 4, personally i find this a good thing although some fellow gamers seem to disagree.I loved DMC 4 so much i pre-ordered this title (i wasn't dissapointed although now i would advise against this anytime btw) and found it worth every penny. The replay value is excellent as the better you get the more enjoyable the battles become.If this game ever get's on sale, I'd recommend you to give it a go even if you never played a hack and slash game before. DMC is pretty easy to get the hang of and the feeling for and the journey with Dante is insanely cool.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I haven't played the others, but as a standalone this is a really good game.The combat is super fun, it's not just spamming. Theres interesting combos that you unlock and different weapons you hold a key to use, similar to God of War, but less inconvieniant. It doesn't just throw health at you either which keeps it from being too easy.The levels are good to explore, really nicely designed. The collectables in the environment attract you to them in a really unique way, and fit perfectly with the art style.The platforming sections aren't exactly challenging but they're entertaining enough. The fast paced sections really keep the action flowing so long as you know what you're doing. I find alot of games never quite get a good balance, though this one is leaning towards the easy side.The art style suits the game and the cinematography complements it brilliantly. The music (which is actually the reason I bought the game) also matches really well and makes the experiance a whole lot more fun. The animations flow really well with both the environment and enemies. Final kill shots, using your last attack on the last enemy, always seem to look great. The characters (which I thought were terrible at first) each quickly show they aren't♥♥♥♥♥♥ Even with the cool guy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the start and that occasionally surfaces, Dante's a pretty cool guy that doesn't afraid of anything. Oh and the facial models and animations are pretty flawless I'd say, not quite HL2 but better than any AssCreed.I am so pleasantly suprised with this game, fun as ♥♥♥♥/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												This is my first Devil May Cry game, so all the criticism it's gotten from old-school fans regarding the "new" Dante are irrelevant to me :)  The game itself is a lot of fun.  Graphics are very good with everything set to "ultra".  Frames never dipped below 60 (check my PC specs in my profile).  The story is interesting, and the dialogues are pretty cool.  Gameplay is very good, combining a ton of weapons, abilities, and moves.  It takes a while to get used to switching between all of them to fit different monsters and environment interactions.  Finding items and collectibles is also fun, although to gain 100% completion you need to go back and replay levels because you won't have every ability needed the first time you tackle most levels.  I'm not into playing games twice (Skyrim and Mass Effect are sole exceptions), but if you do, this game has replayability value.  Finished in 13 hours and gets an A in my book.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Well, DmCDevil may Cry was a reboot of the fabulous, beloved and awesome Devil May Cry Series, courtesy of Ninja Theory and  CAPCOM. It retells the story of the origins of Dante, Vergil, Sparda and the iconic Eva, in a twist that breaks the cadre of the story from the previous Devil may Cry series.Review: The story was a (bit) half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ character development was shallow, and as such, the previous touch and flair that Dante is known for ( Balls, bravery, awesomeness, cool dude) and Vergil's nature ( Loyalty, skill, distaste for firearms, etc) have neen washed away and in their place, are shallow, under-developed and uninspiring characters for whom no fan of devil may Cry series can connect to easily. The fabled Sparda, and his legend is gone. So if you're looking to reconnect to the awesomeness that Devil may Cry used to be, this is not it. It may feel a bit insulting to the series' die-hard fans.Gameplay: Acceotable. Fluid mechanics,  and the camera can get glitchy at times. For the love of all thats' awesome, why did they leave out Lock On to targets out of a hack and slash game? This makes combat cumbersome, especially in Boss Fights (Mundus, anyone? ). The game also has a short learning curve, and as such, new players to the series will be at ease hacking and slashing demons at the comfort of their seats.Graphics: Pretty average. Nothing spectacular. Runs in DirectX9, powered by the Unreal Engine 3. If you're on catalyst (Running an AMD/ATI GPU/APU), ensure you're using the latest driver. The game is known for being glitchy with old versions of AMD Catalyst, and micro-stutter is  relatively common in CrossFire-based systems. Your mileage may vary.The music is great,m if you're into industrial metal. Noisia and CombiChrist worked up quite the charm here, so you'll be in for a blast if its' your kind of thing.Overall rating: 88% in my personal opinion. Despite its shortcomings, this is a great game with excellent gameplay and many hours of fun, especially when you throw in the Vergil's Downfall DLC and the other mode similar to Devil may Cry's 4 Bloody Palace. Again, your mileage may vary. This is a personal opinion and as such, is subject to personal bias.Play the game, and be the judge.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												As someone playing a DmC game for the first time, I really enjoyed this game. It had a few shortcomings but overall I thought it was a good, fun hack and slash game.Pros:- Fast paced, varied hack and slash combat. Wide variety of moves to keep the game play fresh.- Excellent level design and unique visuals.- Plenty of replay value. Each level has hidden keys, gates and lost souls to find. You'll need to revist earlier levels once you've unlocked all your abilities to get them all.- Well optimized PC port with support for ultrawide resolutions.Cons:- Story and characters are a little under developed, not bad by any means.- Inital play through is rather short, between 10-12 hours. Countered by strong replay value.

content:
Posted: February 24
												Awesome game with great sound, graphics, and art direction. One of the most creative and cool looking games ever. Great story and script and great voice acting. The soundtrack is absolutely slamming heavy metal that fits right in when you are going bananas and wiping the floor with enemies left and right, but it is the type of music that is purely best heard while playing the game. I have tried listening to the soundtrack outside of the game and it oddly enough sounds like crap without the game to go with it. The controls are tight and very responsive with zero delay and quick, brutal gameplay. Basically it is a healthy combination of jumping and dodge rolling to avoid attacks, and power moves and grappling and aerial moves. Not all of the moves are needed either unless you are someone who wants to mix things up wildly and get a perfect score of SS on each level. I can usually get an A on every level, and often a S and sometimes a SS. The only downsides I found with the game are the last two boss fights being huge letdowns. Mundis is extremely easy then when I fought the real last boss on mission 20 (I won't spoil who it is) I could not figure out exactly how to finish him off. I had to google how to do it.One of the few games I have ever played where I do not have any real complaints because it does not have any serious flaws. A lot of time and care went into this game and it shows. It is bad to the bone and you get to be a complete badass and go ape♥♥♥♥♥♥and mow down demons mercilessly. Brutal, hard-core fighting at its best, 8/10

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												I have only a few hours on the PC version, but I have beaten the 360 version 3 times. So far, the silky smooth 60 fps and high resolution are enhancing the experience even further.An excellent, genuinely underrated game. While I don't like this incarnation of Dante as much due to his lack of clever dialogue (opting for more of an in-your-face, "♥♥♥♥ you" type speech than 1-4's more snide and humorous banter) I think pretty much every aspect is equal to or better than the main series. The art style is an absolute pleasure to look at, with carefully chosen colors and architecture. Limbo is a very unique setting and feels very oppressive, which is what they were going for.The music is very high on my list of best ost's, though it's definitely not for everyone. It is a mixture of Combichrist's aggrotech/death metal and Noisia's bass-heavy electronic music (Dunno exactly what genre, but it ranges from Drum 'n' Bass to Dubstep). A testament to the ost's quality (and to the quality of the musicians composing it) is that I actually am not a fan of the genres in general. All in all, it feels very appropriate to the gameplay and pumps you up as you lay down some sick combos.Which brings me to the gameplay. Some criticize it for being less "free" than the originals, and I see where they're coming from. DMC4 in particular has quite a lot of stylish freedom in what you can do, and you can perform a buttload of crazy combos with cancelling and tech and all that. However, the grappling system and the ease of switching weapons in the heat of battle make it a very smooth and skill-intensive experience. The multiple melee weapons allow you to tailor your approach to battle on the fly, using a scythe or shurikens to take out a mob of easy enemies, an axe or knuckles to deal some heavy damage to high profile targets, or your trusty sword which is good in any situation. But the thing that makes combat so ♥♥♥♥ing fun is the aformentioned grappling hook. Depending on whether you have angel or devil weapons equipped (by holding the left and right trigger, respectively) you can either pull yourself toward the enemy or pull him to you. This opens up all sorts of "CUHRAYZEE" juggling shenanigans.And the bosses. Oh, the bosses! While they are somewhat easy, they are extremely fun encounters with unique mechanics. I don't want to spoil anything, but they're some of the highlights of the game.And so, I wholeheartedly reccomend this game. If you like hack 'n' slash games, this is one you should definitely try out!9.5 out of 10. If the dialogue were a little bit more reminiscent of the originals, I'd give it a 10. Too bad the fanboys killed a chance of a sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												SUMMARYThis game is one hell of a ride (pun intended). Has a few issues but otherwise it's well worth the purchase. I've had a great time with this game so far and I'm sure I'll be coming back to it in the futurePROS- So much fun to play- You get to shoot Alex Jones right in the f**king face- Combat is intricate while remaining accessible to new-comers- Has an amazing style that shows heavy goth and punk roots- You get to blow up Mountain Dew HQ- Facial animations are amazing and do a great job of showing the characters' emotions- There's a surprisngly deep lore hidden in this game for those willing to look- Characters are entertaining and fun to interact with- Boss battles are epic and do a great job of testing your skills- Soundtrack is fantastic- The Vergil DLC is just as fun as the main game- Did I mention you get to shoot the f**k out of Alex Jones and Mountain Dew?CONS- Camera can get annoying, keeps locking on to enemies even when you're trying to navigate- Really short story - finished entire game in an afternoon- The price of healing items increases after each purchase which means it's next to impossible to buy any near the end of the game when you need them the most- Playing with a keyboard is... difficult. Strongly recommend using a controller instead

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												This is outstanding fast-paced hack and slash combat. Forget what the haters ♥♥♥♥♥ about.  The core components of what made the Devil May Cry series revolutionise action-games is here in the new DMC; just a diffrent coat of paint because Ninja Theory was asked by Capcom to set it up that way.  In many instances movement and attacks are more fluid and fit roles better.  No more having too many weapons that you may not use half of them (my friends and I had that problem with lucifer from DMC4).  Ninja Theory did a good job with the combat, story, and mood.  Truth is they improved quite a bit.  Yes it is (slightly) diffrent than what it was before, but I'm a fan of the old DMC and I really like this one as well.  Personally I would like to see more out of both timelines.Dont worry about the limited movesets and protagonist being a jerk at the begining.  Soon Dante finds something to fight for and has an impressive array of weapons and moves to go with it.  Some of the dialog made me cringe, but the old DMC made me do that too.YES the game is easier (someomes much easier) than the previous DMC series.  Keep in mind that DMC3 in perticular had a reputation for being extreamly unforgiving....also the ending was kind of a WTF moment that needs some type of DLC or follow up to explain itself, but I'm not sure when that will happen.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												新鬼泣在画面上和制作上都与前作有很大的区别，可以说新鬼泣本身就不能算是鬼泣的正统续作（本来也不是），但是流畅的动作与出色的打击感配合鬼泣的招牌还是吸引了不少ACT游戏粉的捧场。新鬼泣在操作上比起鬼泣4要简单不少，可以用很容易的操作打出很好的舞台效果，刷分也很好刷，DMD难度想打出12S也不是很难的事情，双闪避的加入让新鬼泣的难度大幅度下降（尤其是天使闪避，就算瞎按也可以躲避攻击+提升华丽度）。如果没有接触过鬼泣系列的玩家可以从新鬼泣起手熟悉之后再尝试DMC4一类的游戏。画面配乐都是上乘，手残党也可以轻松打出的高分华丽特效，配合还算完整的故事结构这部DMC鬼泣可以给10/10.再说说DLC维吉尔，其实操作更简便了。维吉尔的JC用手柄也可以轻松练出来，还有两个大威力低延迟的FS技能。很多人说维吉尔练好FS便可以轻松12S我赞同这种说法。不过幻影剑的使用还是维吉尔玩家好坏区分的标志吧，毕竟熟练运用幻影剑可以打出非常不错的舞台效果。

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Incredible game.  Fantastic art direction, locations, and music.  Some of the zones (I don't want to give spoilers) were such a pleasant surprise for their design.  Tight controls, fair upgrade system (doesn't punish player for experimenting with builds, and you can try any move in a "training move" mini-game anytime!) make it a pleasure to play with.  Logically placed checkpoints allow for quick drop and pickup play when I need to stop or start (I have kids, so this can make or break a game).  It is actually hard for me to think of anything I would really want them to do differently ... pausable cutscenes?  You can alt-tab, though, to pause them, but it's better to have a non-workaround way to pause the cutscenes without skipping them.My lack of beef with the game really does mean a lot.  I am surprised how good it was.  Definitely buying the next one too for sure when it comes along!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												新鬼泣在画面上和制作上都与前作有很大的区别，可以说新鬼泣本身就不能算是鬼泣的正统续作（本来也不是），但是流畅的动作与出色的打击感配合鬼泣的招牌还是吸引了不少ACT游戏粉的捧场。新鬼泣在操作上比起鬼泣4要简单不少，可以用很容易的操作打出很好的舞台效果，刷分也很好刷，DMD难度想打出12S也不是很难的事情，双闪避的加入让新鬼泣的难度大幅度下降（尤其是天使闪避，就算瞎按也可以躲避攻击+提升华丽度）。如果没有接触过鬼泣系列的玩家可以从新鬼泣起手熟悉之后再尝试DMC4一类的游戏。画面配乐都是上乘，手残党也可以轻松打出的高分华丽特效，配合还算完整的故事结构这部DMC鬼泣可以给10/10.再说说DLC维吉尔，其实操作更简便了。维吉尔的JC用手柄也可以轻松练出来，还有两个大威力低延迟的FS技能。很多人说维吉尔练好FS便可以轻松12S我赞同这种说法。不过幻影剑的使用还是维吉尔玩家好坏区分的标志吧，毕竟熟练运用幻影剑可以打出非常不错的舞台效果。

												As a fan of the Devil May Cry series, I wouldn't reccommend this game particularly. It strays from the original storyline and characters in a way that is rather uncomfortable to original fans. The modernized characters are rather lacking in the 'unique' area. Dante has a cliche bad attitude and there are more crude sex jokes and just outright swearing instead of funny quips, etc. The female character, Kat, is basically useless and only there to be the mary-sue love interest. And I'll just stop there...STORY ISSUES ASIDE:If you can play this game without comparisons to the original series; then you'll find the game play is actually really fun, the weapons are great, and the stages are interesting! The soundtrack is also on point! Bad for the original Devil May Cry series, but good as a separate game!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												DmC is an awesome spectacle fighter with a killer soundtrack by Combichrist, amongst others. The fighting feels smooth and looks pretty darn awesome, with lots of interesting weapons and abilities, and enemies that require different approaches, especially when the waves begin to mix and match the types you face. The level design is impressive, and the boss battles are pure bliss. But, and there is a but... that only applies for a little bit more than half the game. Just a bit after the half way point, the game suddenly grows monotonous. You've seen everything there is to see by then, and everything from then on is just more of the same with a few variations. The most major flaw the game has is that it relies overly on stamina challenges, by which I mean long enduring fights with no breaks between stages, whereupon you will have to start from the very beginning of the challenge should you fail one stage. These fights are way too common and are there for no reason save to make you loose focus until you make a mistake and have to start over again. They are padding. They are not complicated, as they consists of waves upon waves of the same enemies that you've seen over and over again, they just task your endurance and your focus. There is nothing interesting about these fights. The game also has a major flaw when it comes to non-interactive cutscenes; there are a lot of them and they tend to go on and on. In the beginning they are short and far enough between that they don't distract from the fights, just a breather inbetween the action, but towards the end, they are long as hell and the writing takes a turn for the dramatic rather than the cheese. The cheesy writing is the game's only saving grace when it comes to storytelling, and they cannot write dramatic nor can they deliver it. Despite all of this, I'd recommend the game if you could pick it up cheap (and I mean really cheap), as it is cheesy fun for half the game, despite being dull as dishwater for the other half. Hell, I'd recommend picking it up for the cheese alone. But be warned, it will eventually become a drag. I had to force myself to finish the game when the game ran out of "new" and just started to repeat itself.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I'll be clear to start out with.As a Devil May Cry game, this sucks ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.As an Action game though. It's really good.Now this was my entry into the Devil May Cry series, followed after by DMC4:SE. As an intro and reboot, the game makes it as a stepping stone to dip your toes in the water before diving in.While I'd suggest playing this game first before other DMC games... The other DMC games are far superior. Even if aged a little. This game is a lot of fun and is hilarious in it's own right. But it defecates on the rest of the series and well... it's just got the wrong tone after the other games.Now to technicalities.The game is utterly mindblowing in it's visuals. The gameplay is pretty solid although jumping is solidly a ♥♥♥♥♥.The humour is relatively crass and surface level but has a harshness and ferocity I kind of enjoy. Each and every boss fight feels unique and individual and stands out clearly from the rest even if the levels can blur together a little. The story is ok and passable for an action game but outright wrong or weak for Devil May Cry. The DLC is spectacular and a MUST HAVE addition to the game. In all the game is decent, dare I say good. But with a grain of salt it doesn't carry the same spirit of Devil May Cry before it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Devil May Cry was always an awesome series but the combat in this one put the others to shame. Story was a bit iffy but funny none the less, Dante still has his "Shut up and let's fight already." attitude still. I didn't really like the fact that a lot of the weapons from the previous DMC's were becoming short-handed. You only really get 2 Angel/Demon Weapon's and 2 Guns through the entire game and Rebellion it'self. You can also get a "SSS" rating combat rating fairly easy as long as you group up a bunch of enemies and AoE's. Had gotten "SSS" on all mission on Hell and Hell mode on Vergil's Downfall DLC which was fairly short, only 6 missions to where Vergil goes mad for more power. But even with all this, the story was like a mix of DMC 1 &3 combined. Bunch of action and gore as usual and Dante's witty comments had me still going and interested. Oh and if your thinking the guns are useless because of the trailer, your highly mistaken. The guns in the game will cause a fairly decent amount of damage and can be implemented in numerous combo's if done correctly. They are also your best friends on Heaven or Hell Mode.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												This is 3rd person, hack and slash, action spectacle fighter where you go through the story and fight hordes of demon spawn on the way.I'll start off by saying that combat system is very fluid. You wield different kinds of melee and ranged weapons, that you can combo very effectively. Basically after executing attacks on enemy, you get different kind of score depending on how fluid your attacks and defense was. Score will award you with points you can spend on leveling your skills and abilities to unlock even more moves, combos and increase the power of already learned moves. Throughout the game you will unlock many melee and ranged weapons that are useful not just for bashing skulls, but also to get into secret places, defeat special enemies, etc.Not going to spoil the story, basically it follows very young Dante who is uncovering his past and learning more about who he really is. Dante is same "old" yet younger self, still arrogant and hot headed like always. I found that for me, story in this game was much more enjoyable than in 4th DmC.Game uses good, old Unreal Engine, yet for such recent release it looks somewhat outdated graphically. Non the less game looks good, with uniquely crazy DmC environments, a lot of low resolution textures, good motion capture and facial animation, great voice acting and challenging combat. Not much of eye candy in this one, than in DmC 4, but still great spectacle fighter with awesome yet evil story. Though who am I kidding, it's supposed to be evil. Enjoy.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2013
												What a ridiculously enjoyable game. I have played the whole Devil May Cry series, and this game is an exceptional entry into the series. It does away with having to pick your weapon/gun load-out before each mission. All unlocked weapons are usable in combat.  Also, the Styles (Swordmaster, Gunslinger, etc.) have been phased out. All the styles have now been incorporated into the new Dante's combat system. Instead of Royal Guard, they added a demon dodge ability, which rewards you  with increased damage and style points for dodging enemy attacks at the exact moment. You also now have a standard weapon, hell weapon, and a heaven weapon. The hell weapon is for straight up damage, while the heaven arms specialize in crowd control. Also, some enemies can only be damaged by their respective colored weapons (red=hell, blue=heaven). That can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥because it gets in the way of fluid combat, but it keeps things interesting. Ninja Theory has presented a great take on the DMC storyline. The game itself is beautiful. Environments are colorful and diverse. Dialogue is a huge step up from previous games. All cutscenes and voices are very well done. The new Dante is great. I never once felt like I hated his character. He comes complete with smart remarks and attitude. It takes about 10 hours to complete the game on your first playthrough. I went on to replay it 2 more times to get all the collectibles and beat the Nephilim difficulty. There are 4 more difficulties above that if you feel up to it. Dante and his weapons have unlockable skins (the weapons only have skins if you preordered from gamestop or something). There is upcoming dlc for a challenge mode and for an extension to the story with Vergil as a playable character.  Steam achieves are a plus!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												DAMN. Just finished playing. Let me start by saying that I'm a newbie for Hack n Slash games and the Devil May Cry franchise, so my review might end being highly subjective. 'Cause being an ignoramus on hack and slash games, it's a challenge to write a good and an objective review. But overall, this was just an awesome game, I enjoyed it very much, and I would reccomend it to someone who's completely new to the genre.For me, the controls were a bit complex and it may have taken hours for me to get the hang of playing the game right.But in the end, I think the controls were well designed and so were the combos that were difficult to execute at times because I'm an impatient person. The upgrade system didn't add much to the game for me, except for some essential combos and a few damage boosts. I think I wasn't looking enough for the variety the game would have offered. Probably because it was already complex enough and I kept on forgetting most of the combos constantly. So I played the game in a quite basic way, in the normal difficulty setting. Wasn't that hard, but a few bosses proved a satisfying challenge.The atmosphere the game created was AMAZING. The game jumped immediately to a dark and intriguing cinematic experience. And after the first cutscene the action started right away, and with awesome music composed by Combichrist that just fit perfectly. The dialogues were cheesy and edgy on purpose but with some dark humor to lighten it up a bit. And one more thing I wanted to add about the music design is how well the transitions between running around, entering combat and finishing combat was made. The immersion never broke down.The characters might have been a bit "one dimensional", except for Kat who you'll meet when you play the game :). The story was mediocre, but the atmosphere revolving around the story and the setting made it feel better than it was.I also liked the wide variety of enemy castes, and I saw how essential it was for the variety of combat itself. I bet half of the development time of this game went for the designing of these enemies.The game had its usual average length of 9 hours but they tried to add some replayability by adding gameplay modes that remix the combat scenes and difficulty, which can be unlocked after completing the game.Pros:+Awesome music.+Good bosses and gameplay overall.+Immersion never broke down.Cons:-One dimensional story and characters.TL;DR:"being an ignoramus on hack and slash games, it's a challenge to write a good and an objective review. But overall, this was just an awesome game, I enjoyed it very much, and I would reccomend it to anyone who's completely new to the genre."EDIT: For much easier and smoother gameplay, use a gamepad! In my case, an Xbox 360 controller.

content:
Posted: March 30
												This game gets more hate than I think it deserves. Yeah, the writing is pretty lacking (but coming from a series that has never been known for Shakespearean writing, it's forgivable), the combat is nowhere near as deep as DMC3 or 4 and the aesthetic is very hit-or-miss, but is DmC a bad game? Absolutely not. There's still a lot of depth here, and it actually manages to do some things better than the original series, particularly platforming. The weapon system isn't nearly as deep or open-ended as 3 or 4, but on the flipside, everything is readily accessible, and I never had any issues holding the triggers to switch melee weapons on the fly- it's very flexible and intuitive.Most of the minor gameplay flaws- the lack of lock-on, the stupid color-coded enemies, the broken style meter, and having to collect different arbitrary types of keys to unlock missions- were fixed in the Definitive Edition, but Ninja Theory never made a PC port of that, and two years removed from its release, it doesn't look like we'll be getting it any time soon, which is a damn shame. If you have a PS4 or Xbone, that version is the way to go. It is to this game what the Special Editions were to 3 and 4.As for the audio, the soundtrack is actually pretty okay. It doesn't beat the nu-metal flavorings of 3 or 4, but the Nine Inch Nails and Deadmau5 knockoffs on this game's OST are pretty catchy, and this is coming from someone who doesn't care for dubstep and the like.All in all, DmC is an underappreciated game that is totally worth checking out regardless of your opinions on the rest of the series.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												DmC Devil May Cry is a reboot of the popular game series which eventually had an anime based off of it. I thought it was the other way around since I watched a couple episodes of the anime a few years ago.  It’s a good thing that the game is a reboot since I probably never would have bought the game if it was #5 in a series. (I’ve never played the old Tomb Raider games either and I loved Tomb Raider 2013). It’s my understanding that the previous Devil May Cry games were known for their high difficulty but fortunately for me, DmC Devil May Cry wasn’t too hard at all (at normal difficulty).The game world is a little hard to explain since there are various “layers” to consider. There’s a Heaven and Hell which you never see (kind of like Darksiders). The whole story takes place in the “real world” and in Limbo, which is sort of a “twisted copy” of the real world infested with demons. All the game’s combat takes place in Limbo. Powerful demons attempting to attack you will pull you into Limbo for the fight, and you can also go in through magical rituals (only happens as part of the story). You play the part of Dante, a loner with mysterious combat abilities and powerful weapons, working to take down the demon king Mundus. Mundus has sort of taken over the city (possibly the whole world) through various evil ways and the humans don’t even realize there are demons among them. Dante teams up with his long lost brother Vergil and begins killing Mundus’ allies one by one in awesome boss battles.DmC is a hack and slash game with anime physics. This means for example that you can knock around a bunch of enemies with a single swing of your sword or launch them into the air and follow them upwards with a 20 hit combo. Like the game Darksiders, you unlock various “moves” by buying them with orbs that dead enemies drop. There’s a lot of platforming involved in the game as well, where you need to get from one area to another by double jumping around and using your 2 grappling hooks (one to pull yourself to a target, and another to pull the target to you). Fortunately there aren’t many puzzles, though there are quite a few secret items to be found. The reason I said earlier that DmC wasn’t too hard is because if you don’t care about your score, you can just keep “continuing from checkpoint” until you win. I believe your score will get chopped in half for every time you die. The same goes for using purchased healing items in the game, your score goes down. The game is broken up into missions, and you get a score at the end of each mission based on your time, secrets found, style (combos), and whether or not you used items/died. Keyboard and mouse controls are very intuitive and worked well for me, but I expect people who are used to controllers would enjoy that more. Pros:+Feel like a badass smacking a room full of demons around with combos and magic weapons.+Very nice graphics including huge demonic bosses. I’m a fan of Angel vs Demon artwork too.+You can beat the game pretty easily if you don’t care about your score.+A lot of humor in this game. Dante doesn’t take♥♥♥♥♥♥from anyone and you get in some insult matches.Cons:-The game is still rather pricy despite being close to 2 years old. I think $12.50 is the lowest historical price.-There are maybe 1 or 2 times in the game where you might get lost in a large level. The platforming is three dimensional so there are a lot of places to go. The game doesn’t have a waypoint system or map so it’s possible to get turned around. The levels are mostly straightforward though.-That’s about it actually, the game is very polished despite being a console port.Overall DmC Devil May Cry is definitely recommended. If you enjoy hack / slash games like Darksiders, you will appreciate the flow of combat in DmC. You don’t have to worry about missing collectables in the game since you don’t necessarily need the upgrades. The story is told through gameplay and cutscenes, and more or less makes sense to people who haven’t seen the anime or played the previous games. Wait for the price to drop, then buy the game!

content:
Posted: January 3
												DmC: Devil May Cry featuring Donte™ from the terrible abomination of a remake of a fantastic action series.Let's start with the """positives""".+ Gameplay is quite fun purely as a normal everyday action game.+ Switching your sword's mode quickly with the Triggers feels pretty good in the midst of combat.+ The level design has neat platforming segments where everything twists and turns and it's actually kinda cool.+ It's a lot easier to upgrade and aquire new moves.+ The Bob Barbas boss fight is the most genuinely cool moment in the game.Now let's get to the absolutely irredeemable and completely degenerate negatives.- This game is a b*stardization of the Devil May Cry series, if you are a fan you will absolutely despise playing this.- The story is some of the worst sh*t I've ever seen in a game. It's so generic, predictable, cringy, EDGY, and horrible.- Donte is an unlikable edgy d-bag fuccboi who only appeals to 14 year old troglodites who actually think he's cool. From his juvenile potty mouth dialog to his weak and unsure sword swing animations, it all just paints him as weak and inferior to good ol' Uncle Dante.- Vergil is a literal fedora trenchcoat wearing, weeb katana weilding, anonymous revolutionary piece of sh*t who is absolutely nothing like his original character.- Kat is completely useless compared to female characters like Lady or even TRISH.- The gameplay is literally dumbed down Devil May Cry gameplay where there's not even a lock-on where instead of analog stick inputs, it's reduced to lazy button combos.- The Style Meter is now ranked on damage instead of, ya know, STYLE.- Devil Trigger is so unsatisfying to use.- Every single weapon except the Ax, from the sword to the F*CKING WEAK SHOTGUN is so unsatisfying.- The mission ranks mean absolutely nothing in that it gives out S's and SSS's like candy when in previous DMC games, you'd only get an S rank for no damage and impressive style. This game rewards lazy play.- The final boss is SO INFERIOR TO PREVIOUS DMC FINAL BOSSES.6/10. The game itself is fun as an action game can be, but I cannot recommend this game when it's nothing more than an inferior version of much much MUCH better games. Please just go buy DMC3 or DMC4 instead of this edgy piece of sh*t. Save yourself.

content:
Posted: March 1
												7/10 game overall.+Stages and music are extremely well designed.+Very well optimized PC port (ran it at 144 fps with zero issues, specs are on my profile).+Enemy/boss design is top notch.+Difficulty levels are very well balanced.+-Streamlined combat compared to the original DMC titles. If you're a fan of DMC3 or 4 and have sunk a good bit of time into either game, you'll feel extremely limited in this one. The combo depth of Style Switcher DMC3 Dante or DMC4SE Dante/Vergil just isn't possible in DmC with the weapons you're given.+-Significantly easier to obtain and hold a SSS rank combo than previous titles.-Character designs. I don't even know where to start here. Dante was never intended to be a serious character, but in the originals, he was overly sarcastic and had a lot of well placed witty one liners. This iteration of Dante, while not terrible visually, just has some of the absolute WORST voice lines in a modern video game. (see: ♥♥♥♥ YOU on YouTube) Also, Vergil unironically wears a fedora.-Color coded enemies. This is an absolutely horrendous choice for a spectacle fighter that is combo based, because several of Dante's "new" weapons in this game have little to no combo potential or cancelling mechanic. Older DMC games featured enemies that would take less damage from certain attacks, but not outright invulnerable. Red weapons (the "heavy" weapons, if you will) in particular feel absolutely useless, and when the game spawns red-coded enemies that will NOT take any damage from any non-red weapon, it's more or less a giant middle finger to having fun.-One of the worst, most anticlimactic final bosses I've ever fought in a video game.-Vergil's DLC, while being a really interesting plot concept, is incredibly short and feels like it was rushed in development.tl;dr it's a very good spectacle fighter, but it's a bad DMC game. It's a good buy on sale.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Not a completely terrible game. Better than Devil May Cry 2, but that is damning with faint praise.Definitely a PRETTY game, and if it had been unrelated to the DMC series, it would probably have been better received. As it is, it is not the worst, but it is far, far from the best.As an origin story, and to contrast both Dante and Vergil, DMC3 does it MUCH better, showing the differences in attitude between the characters even in their playstyle (it is a shame that the PC version of DMC 3 is such a mess, since that is an incredible game). If this was meant to be a retcon or a modernization of it, it misses the mark severely, since the basic story of the sibling rivalry had been done MUCH BETTER in a previous entry. As a brawler, it is not bad at all, but it is nowhere as fun, polished, or well realized as DMC4, which  is uglier and feels half-done at times since  you DO go through the same levels with both characters, but the weapon, enemy and encounter design in it is so much better than what this pulls.DmC: Devil May Cry is a ridiculously pretty game, top notch visuals for sure, great level decoration, but bad combat design (color coded enemies? Really? That destroys the flow) as well as the worst ranking system in the series (not based on variety, but on damage dealt) make it a, well, honestly decent brawler, but a bad DMC game.Go and get DMC4 Special Edition instead of this.

number of helpful: 32 of 63 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												I’m new to the DMC series, and as an outsider I’ve always viewed the old DMCs as hokey and full of cheesy acting by unrelatable characters. Therefore, DmC astounded me with its intelligent combat system, engrossing story, hyper-stylish mood, vibrant visuals, and virtually flawless execution.DmC is just an incredibly well-made game. DmC is so compelling that I started a new playthrough immediately, which is the obvious intention of the developers what with four (four!) unlockable higher difficulties.All cutscenes are skippable, although the acting is so good I find myself rewatching most the cutscenes. Death is very forgiving, and the pacing never bogs down. I didn’t encounter a single glitch, and the HD textures make for a crisp, elegant world. The sound design is superb as well.Basically DmC is a brilliant game that will last 20-30 hours if you desire to find all secrets and fully upgrade Dante. In my opinion Ninja Theory has taken DMC from niche-bizarro status to universal appeal through sheer quality of design. After 40 hours of play, I must conclude DmC is the greatest action game ever made.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												I REALLY wish I got around to playing this sooner. This is a fantastic reboot of Devil May Cry, and despite a really mediocre first 6-7 chapters, the game unleashes everything it has in store after that one chapter after another. The combat has been simplified without losing any of subtlety the previous games in the series have had, and while it's no where near as technically deep as DMC3 or 4, you can still unleash ridiculous combos that require a deeper understanding of the game's mechanics and weapon types. It's late, but if you were at all hesitant to play this because you didn't like the new design for Dante (a younger Dante, so it's fitting), I highly recommend you overlook that because Ninja Theory has proven they can handle the franchise.And I don't want to spoil some of the later level design, but ♥♥♥♥, they are *so* good. *SO* good.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2013
												In my opinion this game is nothing short of brilliant. The level design is spectacular with Limbo feeling like a character itself, the story is engaging and keeps the action going, and the combat rewards those who put in time and effort to understand it. Not to mention the killer soundtrack that backs up the visceral combat. Its campaign is on the short side with a length of 6-8 hours, but the replay value is high and you will continue playing for many hours after.This is a game worth buying if not only for the sole purpose of letting the game industry know that innovation and creativity is welcome and that gamers are open to new concepts.

number of helpful: 54 of 107 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Being new to the Devil May Cry franchise, I can`t speak for classic fans. But as far as Ninja Theory`s, DMC is concerned I must say it was absolutely awesome the entire way through. I am definitely not normally into the fighting genre of video games, but I must say the story and world this game twisted and turned you through was action packed, and had me so hooked I actually had to go look up the plots from the original DMC`s. As far as the combat goes the battles are beautifully fluid and almost make you feel like you`re in a movie, perfectly stringing together maneuvers. Throughout the entire game you encounter new Demons to go up against leaving you never bored. In addition, pretty much till the last few missions you will be constantly unlocking new weapons, whether it be ranged or melee. Also earning upgrades is satisfying, allowing you to unlock new abilities and moves with your weapons.  As well as increasing maximum health.  Even with all that the gameplay has more to offer; I would most definitely consider this game a platformer with the amount of climbing, jumping, and swinging that occurs. Where this game shines in my opinion is it`s one of a kind world and story. Most combat will happen once you have been dragged into “Limbo,” a city controlled entirely by Demons. The artwork in this game, (especially in Limbo) is stunning and refreshing, often having vibrant colors and offering a unique look. The demons also look like serious creatures, but still leaving enough room for the game`s dark comedic tendencies. The plot I suppose is more personal opinion but I simply couldn’t get enough! The thought of exploring the afterlife and the backstory of Dante was really cool, and the three protagonists (Dante, Kat, and Virgil) all have their reasons for what make them to me, strong characters. In particular, Dante.  Plus the thought that the world we inhabit could have far more going on than meets the eye. The voice acting in this game is nothing but the best, every moment there was dialogue I always found myself drawn. Overall this game is a must purchase, the world is one of a kind and the plot and characters were extremely engaging. DMC is on Steam right now for only $24.99, which is a steal! Just to back up my recommendation Metacritic gave this game an 85/100, IGN rated it an 8.5 also stating “This is exactly what the Devil May Cry franchise needed,” and Destructoid rated it an 9/10. These are the reasons why I give Devil May Cry a very strong recommendation! (And mission 20 is badass.)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												I've completed this game yesterday, and the first thought that occured to me after this was: "I need to write a review about this". So, here I am :)The game is brilliant, and there are a few reasons for me to say that.The first one is that the game is visually stunning. And it's not an overestimation. Almost all of the game's action takes place in the world which is parallel to our own, Limbo. And in this world, everything you look at is beautiful. Rich colors, walls and buildings floating in the air, beautiful sky, words appearing on the floor and on the walls... These things grant you mind-blowing visual experience. And yeah, about the words... As far as I understand that, those words belong to the demon, one of the final bosses of the game, Demon King Mundus. Usually, some words appear on the floor or on the walls and a harsh voice reads them. My all-time favorite words are "♥♥♥♥ you, Dante!" xD I laughed a lot on that one.The second reason is the game's plot. The plot is surprisingly good for a slasher! You don't expect a great plot in such a game, just because usually slashers aren't about the plot at all. However, in DmC, you won't find the best plot in the world, but it's a solid (or even more than that) storyline, it's quite intriguing and the characters are great. And of course, the best character is Dante. He's one of my favorite characters in games, mainly because of his sense of humour and his indifferent attitude to things. He knows he's the best and he behaves as one. However, this is a reboot of the old Devil May Cry series, and Dante... He's still the same. He's younger, he's impudent, he's strong and he doesn't care. If you love this character, just go on and play this game. Dante deserves it :)The most important part in slashers is the game's mechanics. Every fight is spectacular, you have A LOT of weapons and moves to choose from, and even if you're not an experienced slasher player, you'll still be able to destroy hordes of demons in any way you like. And when the fight is over, you feel the need to start another one, just to chop some more demons into mincemeat. Because chopping them is really fun in that game!Also, the soundtrack is perfect for that game. Fast extreme metal with growl vocals adds so much drive to that game, and to be honest, I don't think any other kind of music would fit for the slasher game.The only flow I'd like to underline is that the game itself is really short. I clearly understand I completed it on the easiest difficulty level (human), however I managed to complete the game in 7-8 hours. This doesn't make the game worse or anything, but I expected 25-30 hours of gameplay, something like Darksiders, you know... Oh well, the game is amazing, and that's the most important thing.Overall, if you like good slashers, or if you like stunning visual experiences, the game is totally for you. I loved it.My personal rating: 8.4 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												While I haven't been following the whole Devil May Cry series, I really enjoyed the fourth game when it first came out for PC and fell in love with the visual style, the cheesy character dialogues and the Japanese story.So when I saw the first few images and videos of the DMC reboot I was... disappointed. Just like many others.But having finished the game now, I can stay rested. This game is not just an evolution of the series, it's a major improvement in every single area, with easy-to-grasp combat systems that are also difficult to master, charming characters that grow up on you and, most impressively, level design that rates among the top ones I've ever seen in a game.The levels keep dynamically changing around you in a way that makes the Limbo world where you play in most of the time a living, breathing place, which is ironic considering that it's the demon world. Some of the levels are such visual feasts that it makes you wonder how much time it took developer Ninja Theory to put those together. And the game just keeps throwing new material at you so that you never get bored too quickly of one environment.The gameplay is as fast-paced as a Devil May Cry game should be. The only issue I have with it is that sometimes you end up aiming at the wrong enemy because of the lack of a proper lock-on system. And with most of the fights consiting of multiple enemies of different kinds surrounding you, some of them that need to be attacked with specific weapons, this quickly becomes an issue.Otherwise the game makes you really feel that if you die, it was your fault, and not some cheap death artficially created by the developer to make the game harder.All in all, a must buy if you liked the previous games, and a very recommended title for those looking for a fast-paced action game.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												7 out of 10 stars. First off, Devil May Cry is a great hack and slash title. It has tongue-in-cheek humor and compelling characters. The story in DmC was original in its own right. Sure it was good Vs evil, save the world, save the girl. But it had elements only a devil may cry title could pull off. The game NOT ending in a romantic kiss was also a nice refreshing sight. Level design and the music composed was just fantastic. I loved the night club mission. I could play it over and over, Lilith's domain was by far the best. DmC did not get all 10 stars because of the repetitive enemies. By mission 3 the enemies are already dull and boring, sure new ones are always introduced but even they are already carbon copies; once you find a way to exploit them, the fights become easy.Also the combat system is rather janky, sometimes Dante would move, dodge, or jump out of time or there would a delay. No game is without its bugs so I will not fault the developers on this. However it is something players will have to simply deal with as they play through the game. Despite the flaws, the game is over all worth playing whehter casually or hardcore and fully clearing each level. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys blood and anarchy.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												DmC Devil May Cry is an excellent edition to the library of anyone looking for an adreneline pumping action title with silky smooth combat.  The best part of the game for me was the combat, the likes of which I had never before experienced (yes this   is my first DMC game).  The transitions between combos are so fluid you will forget about them.  The combat will eventually become second nature and you won't even need to look up combos (although this may be partially caused by the fact that there are not a lot of combo options available).  Speeking of combos, one of the funnest parts of the game was experimenting with the continuity of different combos.  Since the game does not directly state, "use combo A then combo B to deal a lot of damage" the player is made to experiment to see which order of not only attacks but combos was the most efficient, which again I found to be extremely enjoyable.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Buy? Yes.I found Dmc to be a very solid and competent revival of the series. At first glance Dante looks a bit of a cross between an emo teen and a Jersey Shore reject, but I don't really get that vibe out of the character, other than his "Sexual deviousness". The gameplay is very solid and unlike the other DMCs, pretty damn fair - I've never got killed because something was attacking me off screen. In fact, it looks like some enemies don't attack you when you're off camera, so you aren't always constantly managing your camera while trying to survive and fight stylistically according to the standard Capcom "We must judge your skill level and style" grading system that came with many of their PS2 era games. This doesn't mean that there isn't a challenge, though, this is honestly the only DMC I have finished, so it's much easier and I think more reasonable than prior games, but unlockable difficulties makes things harder by changing the way enemies spawn (I guess different enemies than what they are scripted in the normal games, so you have to be on your toes instead of memorizing spawns). The game encouranges (Read: forces) mutliple playthroughs if you want to get 100% completion, as some early game obstacles can only be passed with later game items. Thankfully, it appears you can play any mission you have already completed during intermissions. Like many of these linear "console style games, you may be looking for a secret around the map, but there are two to three paths and what often happens is that you will pass a "checkpoint" or enter an arean that ends in the typical YOU CAN'T GO BACK THERE annoying game mechanics, which makes it feel like Capcom is judging you for not knowing where you were supposed to go, forcing you to look outside the game to know where to go. Yes, NINJA THEORY developed the game, not Capcom, but it's has that typical Capcom level design that pisses me off.I probably won't 100% this game, but only due to the fact that I'm trying to clear out my backlog. I find a very solid game that is probably my favorite in the series (though, I'm not sure I'm a fan as I didn't Finish 1, hated 2, and got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked in 3, so  I didn't bother with 4). The game is missing some of the original style of the original games, which will be a problem for some fans - while there is definitely the good old spectacle of this genre, much of the "Hey, look, I'm always doing something cool and showing off, Look at my style and bad assness!" is lost in this reimagining, but we had four games to do that, so I'm perfectly fine with this. If you had any reservations about the game and like spectacle fighters, I don't see much reason to not get it beyond price.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I should start out by saying I am pretty new to games, so I am just going to explain how I enjoyed it from the perspectiveOverall, the game was a lot of fun. It starts out pretty easy, explaining all the basics and letting you learn without much hand-holding, before it begins to get difficult. The most important part, is how fun the combat is. And I have to say, it was a lot of fun.The controls were perfect, and it was a lot of fun trying new combos out on different baddies. All the demons are unique and fun to kill in their own way. It is stylish, enjoyable, and you want to get more and more points in hopes of hitting that SSS ranking. It took about 8 hours to play through all 20 missions, and I haven't even gotten into the famous NG+ content. I played through on Nephilim, or what would be hard. The graphics were pretty good, and the atmosphere was amazing. One of the best parts was the music. Ninja Theory did a great part on that, getting both Noisia and Combichrist to make some killer songs for it once again.The only two complaints I have are the cutscenes and bosses. The cutscenes, while having great voice acting, were very stiff, and didn't really look up to date compared to the rest of the game. The second problem was that the bosses were really easy. At of all of them, only one really gave me trouble, and it wasn't even the final boss. They all seemed really easy to deal with, even for a beginner like me. Now, I know I wasn't on the hardest difficulty, but I doubt everyone will play through three more times to get the rest of the difficulties unlocked.Either way, this was still a great game, and I would pick it up for the price it is at.I give it a 8.5/10

content:
Posted: February 28, 2013
												The PS3 demo is a clunky mess, and a horrible representation of new Dante, and of this game. Do yourself a favor, and get the PC version, which runs at the standard 60 FPS, and allows the game to look as visually stunning as it should. Don't cheat yourself by playing the console version with this one.Dante (or Dante In Name Only, if you prefer) is a simply obnoxious character, for the first hour or so of the game. However, this quickly changes over the course of the story, which yes, this game has. Is it a great story? Maybe, maybe not, but much like Assassin's Creed 2, the main protagonist starts off as an obnoxious, overgrown teenager, and slowly matures over the course of the game, and while I submit that this game doesn't pull it off as well for me as AC2 or DMC3 did, I didn't find myself wanting to strangle the main character for 40+ hours. Can the gameplay carry itself well for that long? For the average, "beating-the-game-on-DMD-is-good-enough" crowd, yes. TrueStyle Tournament levels of depth? Not really, but fancy enough to be fun. Completely braindead easy? Only if you allow it to be.Love it or hate it, don't dismiss it. It's something to be checked out. Give it a chance if you love the Devil May Cry series. If the series hasn't appealed to you yet, perhaps consider giving this one a shot.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												DmC: Devil May Cry gets some flak from long time fans because it does some things worse than other DMC games. However, it does several things better, as well. The story is about as good as you'd expect: It's nothing extraordinary, but it won't make you sick, either. Dante is young and immature and this is the basically the story of him reaching that level of maturity you're used to seeing in other games. Don't be upset when he's kind of a punk, because that's the point.But this is also a great game for those just interested in exploring Devil May Cry for the first time because the story is a prequel and you won't have expectations set by the other games. In other words, you won't be missing anything and you won't have to know what you're missing.Pros:Some of the best keyboard and mouse controls to ever grace this genre. Powerful, satisfying sense of impact and flair in fights. Top-level combos have less to do with tiny enemy step exploits (like in previous games) and have a more normalized flow. Skill upgrades are tied to XP, not currency, and can be respecced any time between (or sometimes in the middle of) levels. The unlockable content is good, and bloody palace mode is fantastic free DLC. One of the boss fights is really creative and entertaining, but describing it would be a spoiler.Cons:Certain action-less sections of the game are unskippable and become a chore during subsequent playthoughs. Devil trigger has been reduced from an integral part of combat to a 5-10 second invulnerability button. Dante Must Die mode is significantly easier than in previous games. Enemies that can only be hurt while in demon mode or angel mode greatly reduce your combo options and suck all of the fun out of a battle. One of the bosses takes way too long to beat for the amount of variety in the fight (none).

												I like to keep my reviews short and sweet, and I'll keep to that. DMC is a game with a pretty simple, but likeable story, decent characters and development, a good twist, excellent writing, and incredible combat. content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												7 out of 10 stars. First off, Devil May Cry is a great hack and slash title. It has tongue-in-cheek humor and compelling characters. The story in DmC was original in its own right. Sure it was good Vs evil, save the world, save the girl. But it had elements only a devil may cry title could pull off. The game NOT ending in a romantic kiss was also a nice refreshing sight. Level design and the music composed was just fantastic. I loved the night club mission. I could play it over and over, Lilith's domain was by far the best. DmC did not get all 10 stars because of the repetitive enemies. By mission 3 the enemies are already dull and boring, sure new ones are always introduced but even they are already carbon copies; once you find a way to exploit them, the fights become easy.Also the combat system is rather janky, sometimes Dante would move, dodge, or jump out of time or there would a delay. No game is without its bugs so I will not fault the developers on this. However it is something players will have to simply deal with as they play through the game. Despite the flaws, the game is over all worth playing whehter casually or hardcore and fully clearing each level. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys blood and anarchy.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												DmC is a good game. Like many tough men I typed a lot of♥♥♥♥♥♥about this game and Ninja Theory. Well, they are due an apology because DmC is not garbage. Dante controls very well. The weapons are fun to use and provide good variety for doing combos. Grappling enemies is stolen from DMC4 and is as fun here as it was in that game. Wrangling monsters is oddly satisfying. Someone should make an entire game about just that. Framerate is very good on my old as dirt PC. The game looks great, too. Ninja Theory is one of those developers known for great looking games and I think DmC is a good example of that. Technically it doesn't seem to do anything outrageous but the art is neat, what effects exist are used well and overall it's a pretty game. Enemies are fun to fight. They respond well to getting hit and dragged all over the place by grappling hooks. Many enemies are color coded and only vulnerable to one set of Dante's weapons. This mechanic is dumb and I don't like being forced to use certain weapons.Bosses are straight garbage. Probably the biggest flaw in the game. Every boss is right out of the Zelda/God of War school. Two or three very telegraphed, very slow attacks repeated over and over while their weak spot gets beaten up. After doing enough damage the boss gets visibly hurt, the attacks patterns speed up or very slightly change, and after another couple cycles the boss is dead. One boss is very neat looking. He's basically a demonic combination of Bill O'Reilly' and Max Headroom. The last boss is the coolest but the trick to beating him is foolish. I don't like it when a boss is completely invulnerable except for one specific thing, and especially when that thing isn't obvious. (At least, it wasn't obvious to me; maybe I am too dumb for Ninja Theory's boss fight designers.)Finally, my understanding is that NT was given this chance to revitalize the DmC brand and one area they were expected to excel was story telling. Well, they ♥♥♥♥ed that up spectacularly. The story in DmC isn't bad but it is every part as dumb, nonsensical and populated with oddball characters and off pitch characterization as every previous DmC. Why would Capcom expect any different? Devil May Cry has an insane premise and trying to present the narrative as anything but outrageous camp is doomed to fail. NT didn't make a great Devil May Cry but they made in my estimation the best Western action game of the entire HD generation. That's not saying much and Bayonetta, Ninja Gaiden 2 and of course Devil May Cry 4 are all better games. That doesn't mean DmC is worthless to Japanese action game fans. Go in with tempered expectations and I think you'll agree this is a promising step forward for Western action game development.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2013
												DMC series has always been a fast paced hack n slash like no other in the genre and ninja theory's version maintains that legacy. The combat is responsive and quick. There are a lot of combinations possible using the moves given . They can be chained as the player desires. Although some hardcore fans might not be happy about seeing the beloved Dante's look changed. If you can look past it or want to get in the series this is the right game. The Story is average and quite linear and character do develop by the end, especially the relatioship of Dante and Vergil. Level design is amazing. Overall the game maintains the Stylish!!!! fast paced combat which the franchise is known for.The DLC of bloody palace and Vergil's downfall are good value for money. Vergil although isnt as op as in DMC3 is still quick and is fun to play with. The only thing which I felt was lacking was the boss fights werent as challenging as compared to previous DMC titles and personally i dont like the lock on been removed, it sometime is irritating when ou are trying to do a sequence of moves and the Dante or Vergil might just go to someone other enemy entirely mid combo. But other then that Overall the game is good and solid gamelay. With a lt of replayability factor.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												Took about 10 hours to complete the main story on the next to hardest difficulty. tried it out with both mouse & keyboard aswell as with an xbox controller. The controller was to be preferred but that is expected. However, the mouse and keyboard work surprisingly well for this game.   This is also one of the best ports I've ever played. I cranked everything as high as it could go and still ran at a solid 200fps+ which is more than you can say about most ports these days.   I've always been a fan of spectacle fighters and I enjoyed this one alot. It is one of the better ones in recent time for sure. However, some hardcore fans of the earlier DmC games might disagree. But if you're a PC guy like me and want a solid spectacle fighter - This is where its at.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												I’ll answer the big question right off the bat and save some time. That question being is this a good DMC game? The answer to that is no it is not. Does that make it a bad game? Not at all, in fact it is a great game and I loved it. As a result I feel that amount of backlash and hate it got was mostly unjustified. With that said I would recommend it to anyone on the fence about buying it. Whether you are an advent DMC player like me or someone who is looking for a new experience. Overall it’s an 8.5/10Below are more detailed reviews for those who want to know more. ___________________________________________________________________For those new to the series:This game is a reboot to the series, not a continuation from DMC 4 or any other game. If you try to go back in the series expecting to see edgy Dante you are going to be horribly lost. Even though I do recommend this game I strongly recommend starting with DMC 3 or 4.Pros:>Visually stunning graphics and levels> Fluid game mechanics and combo system that is extremely satisfying when fighting> Variety of weapons and gadgets for stringing together combos or just fooling around (personal favorite is using the sticky dart to mess with low rank enemies)> The concept of demons integrating into modern society and controlling mankind through media and soft drinks is a funny and refreshing idea to the series.>Moves can be practiced in the item shop before being purchased and can be refunded for new moves. Allowing for a high level of customization freedom.> Great amount of enemy variety> Has a good degree of replay value. > You can punch Bill O’Reilly in the face.For those returning:>	The combat feels similar to past installments >	Guns are more viable during combat with a wider range of upgrades>	Weapon and character upgrades are now dependent on your overall rating during gameplay making it all the more rewarding to get that SSS ranking during combos (They aren’t given out like candy but given in moderation).>	Secret missions can be accessed from the mission menu when they are unlocked. Cons:>	The story is horrible and feels like it was ripped of fanfic.net>	The humor is overly ribald and unnecessary.>	Boss battles are pretty simplistic and too easy.>	Color coded enemies become frustrating and interrupt combos frequently>	The game glitches at times and causes Dante to get stuck in either angel weapon mode or devil weapon mode forcing the player to restart from a checkpoint. >	Voice acting is subpar with the exception of Vergil’s voice actor.>	The ophion weapon whips can be unresponsive at times during platform sections.>	There is no lock on button meaning that Dante will be stuck fighting the first thing he sees.For those returning:>      Chances are if you're coming off from a past installment you'll be dropping your combos often.>	Characters feel out of place and don’t do their predecessors justice. >	Combo system and boss battles feel extremely dumbed down. >	Devil trigger feels like a slap in the face as Dante doesn’t turn into a demon but rather a white haired version of himself. >	In order to do secret missions we now need keys to open the doors that hold them. >	Bloody palace has to be downloaded separately.The biggest complaint I have as a returning players is that the reboot was unnecessary and that the concept and mechanics could have been implemented in a sequel instead with original dante or even nero.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2013
												This game was just awesome. DMC takes place in a modern world that is ruled by demons without us even knowing it. It centers around the character Dante and his brother who are the only ones who can end the demon's rule. The game is a reboot of the Devil May Cry series and I have to say, this is BY FAR the best Devil May Cry game yet. The game offers some of the best combat systems in a hack n' slash game EVER. I don't think I have ever played a game like this that had such a smooth, responsive, and intense combat system. The game is well optimized so most systems will be able to run this game at a smooth 60 FPS with the games nice visuals which does nothing but help the fun of the game. The port of the game was well done but I can't say how the game works on mouse and keyboard but for the most part hack n' slash games work best on controllers so I would recommend you plug in a Suxbox Threefixme controller into your PC for this game. The storyline in this game is good and enjoyable but if you played the other DMC games you will already know how it all turns out. The game is fairly long compared to other hack n' slash games clocking in at about 6-10 hours depending on how much you explore and how fast you are with the combat. New Game + is supported in this game and it should be in more games. The difficulty in this game is fantastic and has some different difficulties you can play once you finish the game once for those hardcore fans. I loved this game and I would recommend it to any gamer looking for a great hack n' slash game and to any fans of the earlier Devil May Cry games. 95/100

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												Ok let me start this off by saying I LOVE the original Devil May Cry series (except 2). Over the top action, cool weapons and ridiculousness abounded in each game, getting more crazy as the series progressed. This, unfortunately, is an exception. While the gameplay is fun, and some of the puzzles are kinda clever, the overall feel is...well hollow. One of the things that made the previous games entertaining was the way Dante acted, causal and laid back. Here? Teen angst to the max, complete lack of reason, and the version just comes off as a complete jerk. Other classic characters from the series share very little with their original counterparts, and the story felt too toned down. I get that Capcom is trying to appeal to this generation's audience, but I feel like more effort could have been put into this game. This is not to say, however, that the game is complete mess. The new weapons and abilities feel very DMC and the idea of the environment being your enemy is a cool concept; but its execution falls disappointingly short. Overall, the game isn't complete garbage, but it feels like a half-done idea rushed into production. Better luck next time, Capcom.Final Grade: D-

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												TL:DR - 7.5/10 for fun action gameplay, easy mechanics, and an okay storyline. Worth it if on sale, up to you at full price.I have just finished my playthrough of both the base game and the DLC Fall of Vergil gameplay on Devil Hunter difficulty. DMC has the humor and I feel they got Dante's cocky demeanor down to perfection. The story was pretty good, if not predictable at times but you don't really play games like these for stories, you play them to feel like a badass. In this case, the game delivers. The game is kind of short, as I have beaten the base game in 8 hours and the DLC in about 2.Dante is given his trusty Ebony and Ivory, his sword Rebellion, and four other types of weapons. Two of them being more power based and the other two being more speed based. You can switch between the four extra weapons seamlessly for some pretty awesome combos. I found it pretty easy to get at least an S rating on combos once I got the controls down and I got them down really quickly. It's easy to understand how each weapon works and you're pretty much limited by your creativity when it comes down to putting combos together. Since I played the game on Devil Hunter (normal), it wasn't that hard to beat but still challenging enough to feel satisfied when you get an SSS combo score. No doubt the harder difficulties will provide some fun and frustration.Fall of Vergil really pales in comparison. I know it's a DLC so it won't have as much content but will Vergil you're only given Yamato and his Illusion powers. Don't get me wrong, Vergil's a badass and it was rewarding to kick♥♥♥♥♥with him once I got used to him. The difference is that while Dante has an arsenal of weapons that allow him to handle multiple enemies at once allowing you to be a powerhouse, Vergil was more limited and I felt you have to be more evasive and strike more precisely. That said, his demon form is pretty cool and is a little more dynamic than Dante. Still it doesn't beat being able to switch multiple weapons and going to town on those demons.The only way this game could have been better is a longer game and more interesting characters.Do I recommend this game at full price? As cheap as I am, I would say no. But I feel I'm an outlier of the average consumer when it comes to assessing the worth of games. I'm incredibly cheap and I only ever really buy during sales. That said, I bought this game during the Summer Sale and by that I would absolutely recommend getting this game.I say wait for a sale and then get it. But that's my personal opinion.
