content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												Whether you're an oldschool DMC fan and haven't tried this one because of Dante's hair or the new story, or new to the series completely, you're in FOR A TREAT. The game's combat can be insanely fun and challenging, with quite a decent amount abilities to unlock and slice waves of demons with. Lots of combo variety that you're gonna have to master in order to get those delicious SSS ranks. Combichrist and Noisia are providing you with sick demon killing fuel music in the background with industrial metal riffs that will be stuck in your head for weeks. The game's story can feel a little dry or silly at times but still retains a lot of elements from the older DMC games and wraps up nicely. The only other con for me are the boss fights, who could have had a little bit more complexity to them, but are still fun and decently challenging.The higher difficulties just take the cake for me.Worth every cent.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2013
												Considering this is my first game in the DMC series, I guess I don't really have much to go by, but without a doubt, this was one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time.  Qualms about Dante's character aside (though I actually found Dante quite likeable as his character developed), the visual style and art direction are fantastic.  The world of Limbo crawls alive around Dante, often begging you to stop and look out into the distance.  Yet before you earn this respite to enjoy the view, you'll often find yourself engrossed in combat with the various monsters that'll be thrown at you.  By far the strongest and most important aspect of the game (besides the divvying up of angel and demon monsters), DMC's combat feels tight, fluid, and (though apparently simpler than previous games) feels very much streamlined.  Though there are no huge combo strings to learn (thank god) attacks flow seamlessly into each other, each weapon with its own rhythm and set of attacks.  DMC combat appears simple, but still feels incredibly satisfying when self-made combos can be pulled off.Vergil's Downfall (which I also ended up buying after I beat the main game) is satisfying in its own right.  Though it lacks the fantastical environments of the main game, playing as Vergil and seeing an "end" to his story has its own unique yet highly enjoyable feel.

												Unlike common opinion due to the controversy for the new look of the franchise, I think this game is pretty good, awesome visual style, awesome soundtrack, groundbreaking level design (quite literally), really well balanced gameplay and combat based more on skill and reflexes than just memorizing attack patterns, the weakest part would be the fairly average story, but it's completely compensated by all its strengths.Some people say it's too easy for hardcore people, but I believe there's a thin line between a fair challenge, and just stupid impossible, this game has a difficulty for real casual players and for those who seek a true challenge, and playing on the hardest difficulties will always keep you on edge.This game is worth every single pennie if you give it a chance, for those who are still mad for the new Dante, it can be at least a good way to release stress hacking and slashing.

If you're a die-hard Devil May Cry fan, you may take issue with the change of style and pace. However, as a new player to the series, I found this entry not only extremely accessible, but fun and challenging as well!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Short and Detailed review. Don't vote if you don't bother to read.PROS: Jawdropping level design and audio-visual experience. Reworked but still great combat with some creative enemies. Fantastic narrative and rather simple but very enjoyable plot with great character progression and drama (especially if you know what these rebooted versions of the characters are supposed to be like). Surprisingly intellectual social-criticism which is the last thing I have expected. Online leaderboards for everything as a welcome addition for professional DMC players, supporting the well known series of higher than higher than high difficulty levels. High replay value, and longer playtime than any other DMCs, added tiny things that help the professionals keep track of their progress.CONS: You really have to force yourself through tolerating Dante's personality early on. Alternative costumes, traditionally unlocked by succes on higher difficulties are cut out paid DLC (some remain free). PC version feels abandoned by devs. Context: it is a freaking good PC version, have no doubt. Technically even far superior and better optimized than it's console counterparts. It just pisses me off that despite paying for Vergil's Downfall DLC, and basicly every DLC for full price just because well, fanatism, the later relased nextgen version gets additional content such as a different, new Bloody Palace mode for Vergil, turbo mode and alternative controls by getting the focus system added back. Hell I'd even pay for the Definite Edition full price, as stupid as this is, to have those on PC. Sadly, we don't. There are no cool weapon acquisition cutscenes. Vergil's hat. What were they thinking?Detailed review:First of all: before it's relase, I really hated DmC. It directly spits on everything that defined the franchise, it's characters and design and goes straight to the opposite direction, in a way maybe 10 year olds think it is cool. Continous needless swearing and primitive talk, antisocial irritating skinny toughguy behaviour from the main character (who -by accident for sure- just happend to look exactly the same as the dev company's boss until the early fan outrage that thankfully forced changes before relase) disgusting things, replaced all the sort-of japanese high fantasy / gothic looks and the classy, elegant characters - and some of the cutscenes directly mock players like "yeah you liked the old one? **** you then, this is better!", among others the white hair scene early on.Despite all the hate I had towards DmC before it's relase, I've seen a really good trailer for it and decided to give it a chance - and I did not regret it. Oh boy, quite the opposite. Dante's new personality sometimes still makes me want to let him die on every corner, but looking at the greater picture the having his early personality like.. what it is, early on is a genius. Not because I like any of it, but because it adds marvelously executed, meaningful character progression to the story. It makes the lead character hated by the play, and by the end achieves the same character to be liked by the same player. And that's a big thing. Without spoilers, you cannot compare to what Dante becomes by the end of the story to what he used to be at the start of it. And there are a lot tiny details hidden though the plot that slowly changes him to a very likeable character who stands up for the weak he literally "doesn't give a **** about" before.The stage design is jawdropping. The oversatured colors really work well in limbo as a contrast to reality's empty greyness which we also live in. The on the fly transforming levels and the "They Live" movielike hidden messages or I could even say direct references spread out through the whole city combines to a never before and I risk to say it nowhere else to be seen experience. Overall it is unique visual experience with hardly any competitor because simply there is nothing like it, especially looking at triple A relases (for the picky ones, yes, as a matter of fact it's possible I overlooked some nobodyheardofit indie title that is similar). The visuals are supported with adrenaline pumping heartbeat accelerating aggrotech music by Combichrist and drum n' base / dubstep / breakbeat / whatever they are NOISIA. First is responsible for painting a badass audio layer on the chaos of limbo during combat and certain cutscenes (with even the song's titles adding thoughts and tiny details to story, such as "Empty" for the last mission), second has done many electronic background music for stages that sometimes even change and transform matching the music's tempo. Just like other aspects of the game, I also didn't really like it before relase but quicky grew to be one of my favourite.The gameplay has gone through significant changes aswell compared to the original series. Most of Dante's moves still remain (altho' named slightly differently and it kind of gives away a pathetic feeling how the devs really want to send a message about "ours is better!" to the fans of the original series. Like million stab became trillion stab, and pretty much everywhere they just want to say "bigger" than the source material they worked from). Controls are really different because  there is no focus system and it rarely but can be problematic when you try to focus some airborne enemies with ground enemies below them, but for those who aren't looking forward to play the extreme on top of extreme difficulty levels, just ignore what I said, it really won't matter. Combat design shifted from difficult executions and frame-cancelling to smarter positioning and isolating, making the tougher fights actually tactical and control based far more than hightech player execution lockdown damage nuking. The gameplay is still as fast as before, or even faster, only the controls required to play it fast got a lower requirement which makes this entry of the series a very user friendly one, unlike the others before, and at the same time still keeps the challanging and hightech execution aspect for those who look for it, on higher difficulties.As a huge fan of the original DMC, as I said I really hated DmC at first. But it succeeded in exceeding my expectations continously over and over on every aspect that defines a game (gameplay, story and it's narrative on it's own, actually meaningful character drama and relationships, audiovisual experience). Yes, it is significantly different than it's predecessors. Yes, characters are nothing like the old ones, one of Vergil's moves somewhere in the middle of the story still bothers me, and I still cannot help but hate D--ch-bag Dante early on in the story. But give it a thought after you finished the game and look back, and you'll see the big picture I see, and it makes the game a damn well done masterpiece, on top of a very enjoyable journey as the first playthrough. And after DMC3SE, a dream came true that I could live to see Dante and Vergil work together as brothers through an entire game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												I'm not fresh on the old games. So this review might not contain the angst of the diehard fans, that being said it will be as objective I could give. When I first saw the teaser for this game and Dante's new look, I was in the outraged group of people. I remember swearing not to play this game and yet here I am. The main part of this game I feel will be remembered is its aesthetics. It's beautiful. And that's ultimately what's captured my interest after the failure that was the my introduction to this game. Distinct aesthetics mean good direction, and direction is what most games lack. But i digress. Despite the game's gorgeous looks, and this product being a port, the optimization is quite decent. It's not ideal, but it's more than passable. And the port itself was made not in a money-grubbing way. There are some problems here and there, but they do not really interfere with your experience. Production is really hit and miss. For example Dante and Vergil are voiced by one actor, and sometimes it really shows, breaking the immersion. Sometimes they even look too much the same and it doesn't help. Brothers don't really work that way. But then there are some props like graffiti art that warmed my heart and really did help with immersion. So that's up to you. In the process of the game you can unlock cool concept art too. But they show all of it in credits roll, so i did not really get that. Music is much the same techno sounding metal stuff, as in the last few titles, if a bit modernized, it felt fitting to this game overall. Gameplay wise there is not really much to tell. It's hack and slash, it's enjoyable. Honestly, i can understand the new looks too. It's not the long-haired flannel wearing grunge kids that are today's youth, right? Overall it's a must play. I haven't had this much fun in a while. I don't know about DLC, though. Production values are lower, most everything is rehashed. If you really enjoyed the original game maybe try the DLC. I wouldn't reccomend, though.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												"THIS IS HARD HITTING NEWS BOB!"First it has to be said - don't listen to the DMC fanboys who hated on this game since the reveal trailer. They hate the game no matter what, and their oinions can't be taken seriously.How do you know if they're a biased fanboy? Telltale signs include called Dante 'Donte', and outright hatred and vitriol towards the games existance.Now that we have that out of the way and the baggage of a much loved franchise is put aside, is this game good or not? The answer is yes, it's a very good game, in fact it's one of the best action games I've ever played.Devil May Cry 1 was an instant classic, it was my first PS2 game and is still my favourite DMC game. I've played every game in the series, including the terrible sequel, and in my opinion DmC is easily the second best game in the series. Arguably it's the best. Note that many consider DMC3 to be the best, and that's perfectly agreeable, I ultimately prefer 1 because of the atmosphere, and Dante in DMC3 was a little too over the top, OK a LOT over the top.DmC has the best combat and platforming in the series, the most well told and interesting story (it fleshed out the characters in a way that the entire tetralogy never did), and it also has one of the most striking and interesting visual designs I've seen in a AAA game.Ultimately this game is pure fun, as with most straight up action games, you know what you're getting - linear level design, fast and furious combat, in your face characters and a rocking soundtrack. I've played all major franchises in this genre - DMC, God of War, Bayonetta and Ninja Gaiden; DmC is easily the best of the genre available on PC.The goal of these games is to make you feel like an all-powerful badass, and have fun while you do it, DmC delivers.Get it, have fun, kick♥♥♥♥♥- win.P.S. Make sure to get Vergil's Downfall, truly a great little piece of DLC that completes a fan favourite character's arc to the dark side.

Posted: March 13, 2014
												A wonderful game of a great series.DMC is for all those who love the stylish fast paced multi button combos.Gamepad is heavily recommended as one gets 7 weapons in total each with different buttons for combos,so switching between them is made easy with gamepad.Death is forgiving and the difficulty unlocks are very good,making sure the DMC hardcore fans have a lot to play for .The boss fights are a bit disappointing compared to DMC 4 ,which had a lot of bosses.But apart from this, a lof of emphasis has been made to normal units ,many of which are unique and have different powers .Going up in the difficulty ladder gives a different set of enemies in the same environment , which will need different strategies to ensure a smooth progression to the next level.All in all, a good game and would recommend it to the DMC fans .

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												Bought this game a while back, and i gotta say, it's no way a devil may cry game. (mostly just similar hack and slash combat system) But it's quite fun. Aside from all the non canon plot and backstory, there were acouple things i just didn't like: The story was mediocre at best, mostly predictable ending and plot points; how the game has times where it really plays its self; the distinct lack of puzzles, heck, i started the game hating the rebooted characters, espically dante, but over time, i grew to put all that behind me, that's only because i looked at this like like a different franchise all together. This game was actually challenging on average difficultly, which makes the many difficulties that more terrifying.Some of the things i really liked about this game:-The Music: the music in this game was all produced by one group, which gave it consistantcy. The music in the game really does a great job blending from combat music to ambience. But along with that, the music really did fit the style of the game, a little bit of edm, mixed with some metal. All the bosses had their own music, and the repeated music is really enjoyable. It really makes you want to take on every demon spawn that comes your way!-The level design/overall art style: if theres one thing i love the most about this game, it's the levels, so much work went into this world (espically when you get to the tv place). It really feels like a unique experience every level, which was something a few of the original dmc games lacked. The artstyle was the real cherry on top, they really didn't try for realism in this game (original artstyle is one of my favorite things) they had a comicbook/western animation style, and stuch with it.-satisfying gameplay and combat: this game was well cared for in the combat mechanics department, it feels so great to slash and bash enemies, and the combos are much easier to obtain (unlike in previous installments in the series) The weapons in this game are also compelling, from powerfists to shurikens, you'll be wanting to use all of the weapons to get as high of a hit score as possible, and with a simple weapon switching system, you can pull of alot of diverse combos, and feel like a badass the whole time.sure, some of the enemies are annoying.. but that just makes it all the more satisfying when you kill the last one and get that slow-mo money shot.Overall: if you're a die-hard dante fan, maybe don't play this one (unless you're openminded) but if you like hack and slash games, like beyonetta, or god of war, that means you don't really give a damn about plot, and this game is for you.If you really want to get started with this genre of video game, I absolutely recommend this game

content:
Posted: February 12, 2013
												DMC series has always been a fast paced hack n slash like no other in the genre and ninja theory's version maintains that legacy. The combat is responsive and quick. There are a lot of combinations possible using the moves given . They can be chained as the player desires. Although some hardcore fans might not be happy about seeing the beloved Dante's look changed. If you can look past it or want to get in the series this is the right game. The Story is average and quite linear and character do develop by the end, especially the relatioship of Dante and Vergil. Level design is amazing. Overall the game maintains the Stylish!!!! fast paced combat which the franchise is known for.The DLC of bloody palace and Vergil's downfall are good value for money. Vergil although isnt as op as in DMC3 is still quick and is fun to play with. The only thing which I felt was lacking was the boss fights werent as challenging as compared to previous DMC titles and personally i dont like the lock on been removed, it sometime is irritating when ou are trying to do a sequence of moves and the Dante or Vergil might just go to someone other enemy entirely mid combo. But other then that Overall the game is good and solid gamelay. With a lt of replayability factor.

												Unlike common opinion due to the controversy for the new look of the franchise, I think this game is pretty good, awesome visual style, awesome soundtrack, groundbreaking level design (quite literally), really well balanced gameplay and combat based more on skill and reflexes than just memorizing attack patterns, the weakest part would be the fairly average story, but it's completely compensated by all its strengths.Some people say it's too easy for hardcore people, but I believe there's a thin line between a fair challenge, and just stupid impossible, this game has a difficulty for real casual players and for those who seek a true challenge, and playing on the hardest difficulties will always keep you on edge.This game is worth every single pennie if you give it a chance, for those who are still mad for the new Dante, it can be at least a good way to release stress hacking and slashing.

Telltale signs include called Dante 'Donte', and outright hatred and vitriol towards the games existance.Now that we have that out of the way and the baggage of a much loved franchise is put aside, is this game good or not? The answer is yes, it's a very good game, in fact it's one of the best action games I've ever played.Devil May Cry 1 was an instant classic, it was my first PS2 game and is still my favourite DMC game. I've played every game in the series, including the terrible sequel, and in my opinion DmC is easily the second best game in the series. Arguably it's the best. Note that many consider DMC3 to be the best, and that's perfectly agreeable, I ultimately prefer 1 because of the atmosphere, and Dante in DMC3 was a little too over the top, OK a LOT over the top.DmC has the best combat and platforming in the series, the most well told and interesting story (it fleshed out the characters in a way that the entire tetralogy never did), and it also has one of the most striking and interesting visual designs I've seen in a AAA game.Ultimately this game is pure fun, as with most straight up action games, you know what you're getting - linear level design, fast and furious combat, in your face characters and a rocking soundtrack. I've played all major franchises in this genre - DMC, God of War, Bayonetta and Ninja Gaiden; DmC is easily the best of the genre available on PC.The goal of these games is to make you feel like an all-powerful badass, and have fun while you do it, DmC delivers.Get it, have fun, kick♥♥♥♥♥- win.P.S. Make sure to get Vergil's Downfall, truly a great little piece of DLC that completes a fan favourite character's arc to the dark side.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I hated the new character design when it was first shown.. There, I said it!DMC as a franchise is something I've always held close to my heart growing up. It was the first tv-ad I can remember showcasing a mature PS2 title and with a badass looking character. I got the game, loved it! Granted the sequel was vastly inferior but after that it seems Capcom has done well with the franchise. The one thing that's always been off with the series has been the lack of story. Much like Mortal Kombat, they actually went back and tried to fix that aspect in the reboot. Is it for the better or for the worse?Better! With DMC4 they obv tried something more but it was for a character we were never attached to, one that never got well recieved and the story overall was a clusterfu*k!This reboot completely re-establishes the DMC universe with interest and for the first time in the series it finally feels right. Gameplay has always been fun but the story was never too much for discussion. I'm thankful Ninja Theory took over this project.Dante is back! Nero wasn't Dante, this one is for sure. The cockiness and attitude is back, the feel of DMC3 with a younger version of himself is at hand and we get to experience what made the character so great in the first place. Everything comes in place with this game. The best thing is, it feels natural and not forced!Minor spoilers ahead:So it's explained Dante is a hybrid and offspring of the love between a demon and an angel, as such he can wield powers between the two races. This is something I cant remember have been explained prior in any of the previous games, BUT it feels so obvious that it should have been! I never gave much thought about it before but now I can't understand how this wasn't part of the old universe! Ninja Theory got me hooked by mission 2 and I've never felt this excited going through the game for the story parts!Gameplay is fine as expected as well, not even worth stating the obvious.Final word from an old-school DMC fan?Yes again the look, hated it when it was first released.. It does however fit with his younger self perfectly and honestly it felt natural within the first 3 missions or so. I have to say that if you're unsure because of the idea of the new design and reboot - TRY IT! I'd be surprised if you cant get attached to this amazing persona and gameplay.This is handsdown the best game of the franchise yet with the exception of DMC3Bosses aren't as memorable and overall the game feels easier despite me being rusty for not playing DMC4 in 5 years. I keep getting A-S ranks in first atempts thus far.ALSO there's some random crashes here and there but its not destroying the game experience since theres now checkpoints during stage progress.Overall I'd give this a pretty solid 4/5 - I hope this isn't the final entry as I want more of this greatness!

content:
Posted: February 12, 2013
												DMC series has always been a fast paced hack n slash like no other in the genre and ninja theory's version maintains that legacy. The combat is responsive and quick. There are a lot of combinations possible using the moves given . They can be chained as the player desires. Although some hardcore fans might not be happy about seeing the beloved Dante's look changed. If you can look past it or want to get in the series this is the right game. The Story is average and quite linear and character do develop by the end, especially the relatioship of Dante and Vergil. Level design is amazing. Overall the game maintains the Stylish!!!! fast paced combat which the franchise is known for.The DLC of bloody palace and Vergil's downfall are good value for money. Vergil although isnt as op as in DMC3 is still quick and is fun to play with. The only thing which I felt was lacking was the boss fights werent as challenging as compared to previous DMC titles and personally i dont like the lock on been removed, it sometime is irritating when ou are trying to do a sequence of moves and the Dante or Vergil might just go to someone other enemy entirely mid combo. But other then that Overall the game is good and solid gamelay. With a lt of replayability factor.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												For someone who is now a huge fan of DMC 3 and 4, I don't see where all the hate comes from in regards to DmC: Devil May Cry. My best guess in most cases is due to the fact that fans desperately wanted DMC5 (which I totally understand) and didn't receive what they'd been hoping for.DmC retains the same fast paced combat and stylish combos from the previous game, but has undergone some changes which make it distinct and quite different. Combat is much faster this time around, and arguably a ton more fluid. It looks great on the unreal engine and has what I consider to be an interesting artistic design. A newly composed soundtrack in combination with the quick and flashy combat makes for a lot of fun. Honestly, it made me feel 'cool'.Anyways, this is a solid game in its own right, but not a solid DMC game in the traditional sense. It's very similar, but it's different and changed in ways that hardcore fans of the originals will not appreciate. That being said, if you're fairly open to having fun and enjoying an actiony hack and slash type game, then I'd recommend giving this a go. It's not as replayable or skill based as previous DMC games, but it will give you a solid couple hours of fun. The DLC with Vergil is a nice challenge, and entertaining due to giving a new playstyle.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												I will preface this with a statement: I wouldn't call myself an avid DmC fan. I have the other games. I've played them, and they were fun. Heard varying opinions of this game and got it on sale to see for myself. First off, a lot of the people saying its horrible and the spawn of Satan and the like are wrong. Kinda. It has its good points, it has its bad points, and it has quite a few just plain mediocre points, so I'll try and be as fair as I can here.(Warning. Warning. A new Wall of Text approaches.)First off, how does it play? Decently. Combat is nice and smooth, flows really well, but... it's not at all that difficult. Some of it just gets kind of silly too. Once the grab mechanics got introduced, I almost immediately figured out how to just return to my home planet without much difficulty at all. While things like this are usually possible, in this game it seems rather hilariously simple to discover and then spam them to your heart's content. Also, Dante's devil trigger is kind of silly. He freezes time, which would normally have me :D'ing, but then he flings everyone up into the air where they are annoying to hit, invalidating every single ground combo I have, basically. Anyway, I didn't find quite as much depth or challenge to the fighting mechanics as I would nessecarily like, but this is coming from a guy who loves Dark Souls and plays everything on the hardest difficulty he can, so my definition of challenge is a bit different from most casual players. Aside from being somewhat more simplistic than I expected, however, there isn't much of anything you can call a fault in the combat. It's pretty looking, very smooth, and kind of mediocre, really.Plot? Look, let's be honest here, no one plays the original DMC games for the plot. That was one of the many mistakes they made with 2, in fact. That said, unlike the original games, which were trying harder to be entertaining that tell a really detailed story, this one has one. A rather large one that I'm not really a fan of. However, all matters of opinion aside for the most unbiased review, it's mostly another "Eh" from me. Despite usually being an obsessive gamer who watches every cutscene and searches for all the little details etc. I just wasn't that interested in the plot. It's there, yes. Is the writing horrible? No. Is it fatastic? No. Looking at it as a whole, I can't really say there is anything about it that ever goes above average. Some is below, most is right on the line, and none of it really gets very much further than that.Next we have DmC Dante. Gonna say it straight out. I think he sucks. I don't find him funny or entertaining in any way, shape or form. This is without comparing him to the old Dante at all. had I never played another DMC in my life, I would still get a headache almost every time he opens his mouth. I have laughed at literally none of his jokes, I have completely failed to care about any of his actions at every turn, and in general just been unamused by his existence. He is whiny, thinks he is so cool for being a punk, blah blah blah blah I don't even want to listen to him any more. It seems from where I'm standing that the writers just went with any uninspired bit of excessive vulgarity they could come up with to make him seem "cool" and then went to lunch. That isn't me being a prude. What with all the time I spend online I'd probably have an aneurysm by now if I was. However, all of the teenage-class stupid that spews forth from his every orofice has gotten mindbogglingly old, so unless you giggle at "dirty words" there isn't much there that could possibly be called humor. Once in a while, he makes some comment that gets my hopes up and I think "Is this actually going to be witty and intelligent?" and then he finishes what he was saying and it all comes crashing back down to dull. And do I even need to bring up the infamous "**** YOU!" "NO, **** YOU!" exchage? he is absolutely the worst part of the game, as far as I'm concerned, and it says a lot that my feelings about any game can be summed up with "The main character is the worst thing about it."Music... is really another matter of personal taste, I suppose. In my opinion, the main game's soundtrack sucks, but that's just because I hate most of that genre to begin with. That said, it suits the character just fine, so if that's what they were going for, great success! Considering that the Vergil's Downfall DLC switches to a totally different theme, it probably was what they intended. (That music is a little eh, too, though. It's there, it doesn't sound out of place, but it isn't stellar for the most part either. Maybe I haven't payed enough attention to it, but that it can't grab my attention does say quite a bit.)With all said and done, my final opinion on this game is mostly just "Meh". If I had never bought it, I would be perfectly content with my life. If I had bought it full price, I would probably regret it a bit. It runs well, plays decently, and I can't say I wasted the time I spent on it any more than it would have been wasted on another game, but I still find the combat lacking the challenge I looked for, and the new Dante spent a good portion of the game giving me a headache before I just ragequit to play Vergil's Downfall for a while instead. My statements that the combat lacks depth should still be taken with a grain of salt, as the combat will probably be perfectly acceptable to most casual players, but if you are looking for all sorts of tricky shenanigans like in certain other games in this genre, you probably won't find a ton of them here. The plot was uninteresting, at least to me, and way too full of dropping anvils (That's TvTropes speak, for those uninitiated in that specific internet timesink) for me to take it seriously, and as characters I find the new cast bland at best and generally annoying at worst. As far as I'm concerned, if it's on sale and you feel like it, sure, go ahead and get it, I suppose, but if I had a choice between this and DMC3 or 4, I'd leave this one sitting in my games library collecting digital dust, which I can say with complete certainty, because that would be what is happening this very instant, and will probably still be happening whenever you, whoever you are, come by this little corner of the web and read this particular post. However, since there is no button that says "Meh" and displays a shrugging stick figure, I guess I'll just say reccomended, with the imaginary caveat of "When it's on sale".

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												First, let me just say that this is my first Devil May Cry game. That being said, I thought this game was GREAT.Story:I don't know much about the original story, but I definitely liked this "modernized version". It's not a very complicated story: Dante wants revenge on the demon who killed his mother (and who is pretty much controlling the world). But honestly, that's enough for me. I really liked the look of the game and how the world was portrayed - especially "limbo", the hidden "demon world" around us.Looking through the other reviews it seems like some people think that Dante is too "cool", and yes, he sure is confident and maybe a bit smug, but honestly, I liked him. Despited his "flaws" he seems like a good person, and he made me laugh several times throughout the game. And yes, he is cool.My favorite character was probably Kat, a human who helps you out on your missions. I really wish we could have gotten to know a bit more about her, but sadly we probably never will as a sequel doesn't seem to be coming any time soon.Vergil, Dante's brother... He is the smarter sibling, while Dante is the stronger one(?). I knew before starting the game that some things would happen between them, but I don't want to give away too many spoilers.Then there is Mundus, the demon god. Decent bad guy although I would have liked to know more about him as well. Especially regarding his relationship to Dante's father.Gameplay:I can't remember the last time I had this much fun fighting in a video game. The fighting feels fast, smooth and kick♥♥♥♥♥ All of the weapons are really strong in their own way, and while it is easy to get into the game it takes some practice to slash and bash through legions of mobs without getting a chainsaw in your back.Apparently this game is quite a bit easier than the previous Devil May Cry games, and I agree that putting a check point before every fight was a bit too much. It sometimes felt like, especially on the harder difficulties towards the end of the game, instead of starting a fight with 10% health you might as well just suicide and respawn with full health (at the cost of a lower score, of course). It doesn't really give you that "I gotta try my best to survive!"-feeling. On the positive side, having check points before each fight means you can try to chain attacks and pull of amazing combos evey fight without worrying too much about screwing up.The only part of the game that I didn't really enjoy was when you have to run around helping people in the real world, since you aren't really able to fight while doing this. Luckily most of the game takes place in limbo, which is where the fun happens.Graphics:The game looks good to me. I really liked the style of the game, and although the game is fairly linear, the world around you changes all the time, making it feel like you are actually part of something more open and bigger. The first time you move around in limbo you will most likely have a blast.Music:The music in the game is heavy metal/heavy rock-ish(?) stuff, which is not really my type of music, but it sure makes you feel like a badass when you fight through hordes of enemies with that music playing in the background. It really suits the mood of the game, and the fights would feel way less epic without this great soundtrack.I also really liked the voices of the different characters. In my opinion, pretty much all the voices were spot on. The one liners from Dante were perfectly delivered, making even the bad jokes funny. Well done.Overall:Again, this was my first Devil May Cry game, and it seems like most of the negative reviews are from people who have played the previous games. For me, this was a great introduction to the series, and I'm definitely going to play the originals as well. If you want a really good fighting game with a decent story that looks and sounds great then look no further. This is the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 17
												Finally went back and finished this after it had been in my backlog for a long time. DmC Devil May Cry, the remake done by Ninja Theory back in 2013 is a badass package. Screw the haters, this is without question the best Devil May Cry game ever. Great level design, creative and wicked intense boss battles, smooth and more user-friendly gameplay, good sense of humor, and an awesome story. The game also isn't as punishingly difficult as previous entries, making it easier to get in and enjoy the game without having to memorize a million combos and maneuvers to survive. My only real complaint is that the main game is pretty short (only 20 missions which can take anywhere from 2 to 15 minutes to complete) but there are plenty of unlockable bonus missions and difficulties. I hope Ninja Theory gets a second shot at the series, cause I had a blast from beginning to end with DmC.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												DmC manages a fantastic balancing act between accessibility and depth -- the first time through, weapons, moves, and enemies are introduced at a measured enough pace to make it possible to keep up with them, but there's still a massive scope for building your skills and racking up massive scores with SSS combos in battles that used to be a struggle just to survive, just by mastering the systems and weapons. Different weapons are swapped in instantaneously using the triggers as a modifier, and it results in a really wide toolbox of attacks that can be strung together in very satisfying ways.The combat is the real reason to play, but this is also a fantastic-looking game, particularly in terms of the imaginative environments, which make heavy use of ripped and distorted versions of real-world locations. And being on PC running 60 fps helps a lot too. The story and dialogue is a bit less successful -- it has enjoyable moments, but is on the heavy-handed side in terms of its satire.Despite going into this with no expectations or background in the series or genre, I liked it enough to play through the game and the DLC on four consecutive difficulty settings, going up to Dante Must Die, and would name it my Game of the Year for 2013. It also inspired me to seek out more in this genre, which I had mostly ignored previously.

The combat is fine, though a little boring, probably because of the lack of different combos, the weapons are okay, but a little generic (they have the exact same combos as your sword, one is just heavy and hits hard, and the other is fast and AoE), and you're forced to use certain weapons on certain enemies, but that's acceptable I guess. The thing that really turns me off about this game is the huge amount of platforming sections in a game that's supposed to be focused on combat, the jump doens't feel great, the airglide doens't feel great, and half the time there's a fixed camera angle that makes the platforming more tedious than fun. Overall this game is probably fine for someone who isn't farmilliar with the genre, and has some interest in it, but playing this game after playing Bayonetta, this feels like baby's first character action game.

												Well, first of all I play in Nephilim (hard mode) and the AI is so poor they wait you kill their friends to start come in the melee too, it makes fights sleepy and lacking of intensity since you almost don't have to escape, and well, if you die, who cares? Décors are poor, the one of the nighclub level will ask you to play without sound and with sunglasses.Some items are useless like half of the weapons, and fact Dante became a half-angel/half-demon, well why not but charm was justly he was half demon only but this is not the problem. So far, the story could be interesting, taking in, but gameplay really makes regret former Devil May Cry 4 and the others, Dante's character is very well done, Vergil is a pleasure to see in another side but this game lack of greatness. We are fighting the demon king and we have to break in poor places like a nightclub, underground bases...It's sad they aimed for 12-15y old people cause despite some ideas are nice : demons controls medias and junks to sleep us but the boss are very easy to fight and you don't feel yourself like in a war against demons, just again a little mafia boss somewhere in the city ruling few clubs with a system of move that makes looks princes of persias like oversmooth games. They tried to make it in a fashion period where devils had to be hyped, modernized like the Castlevania 2 hard fail, but it just doesn't work or as a cover, until it brings you in a real big game with decorums, darkness and cynism.Ok, nowadays it looks cool to say some game is nice just because of the name especially helped trough bad games journalists, but this one is honnestly too much unfinished and badly done (one level decor is only colored cube you jump one, making looks like mgs ps1 training session for sober and well made) to be really granted as a good game despite some good ideas. I liked Tomb raider 2013 reboot but this one is really not a good thing.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Fantastic!I hadn't ever played the original Devil May Cry games (but I did pick up 4 recently) but this was amazing!If you haven't played the games, you're in luck. From what I've now read, this doesn't follow the original story so it's a great place to pick up.In this game you play as Dante, a half demon, half angel creature who is battling a world completely controlled by a demonic ruler, Mundus. Your goal is to hack and slash your way to victory with the help from the small resistance (super small, actually... just two other people).The game is a spectacle fighter. All of your sword moves are massive and sweeping. It's just as much fun to watch since it all plays out as more of a flashy dance with swords than a brawler. By the end of the game Dante can seemlessly switch between eight weapons all in a single combo. You may start your attack with a dash to the toughest enemy, launching him into the air with your battle axe. Then spin around and throw some ninja stars at the weaker enemies to keep them off your back while jumping into the air and laying on more attacks with your angelic scythe before bringing it all home with your lava-covered boxing gloves.You also have the ability to turn your swords into grapplehooks (either pulling you towards enemies or enemies towards you). This makes for very fast traversal around the arenas and lets you keep the pressure on.The levels and areas in this game are incredible. I've never seen anything like it. Also though a lot of the story takes place in the "real world" the missions mostly play out in the parallel dimension, Limbo. Both worlds are tightly coupled and the giant monsters that destroy the Limbo world also cause chaos back in reality.All that to say, buy this. I played it with a gamepad and it was amazing. A+12 hours to complete

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Over the years I read much criticism and even hate about DmC, and, not being a fan of the older Devil May Cry games, I stayed away from it. Seeing how good the game actually is, left me shaking my head about the untruths written about it on the internet.There is even one review on Steam that writes "This is a casual game". As someone once said "Two Things Are Infinite: the Universe and Human Stupidity".DmC is also a rare example of a Western game achieving in style and design (aesthetic): The game looks beautiful, in motion and in pictures.Combat — 4/5Attacks and dodges felt a bit sluggish: In an Action-RPG, like Dark Souls e.g., I expect that every button prompt gets queued instead of being performed by my virtual character immediately, not so in an Action game with the tag Spectacle Fighter. Also, a lack of powerful special-attacks proved to be rather disappointing. All you have to work with are combos and more variations of them, which can be boring after a while.Characters — 4/5Dante is, without a doubt, the strongest character of the cast: Well-written, relatable, and at times, even funny and authentic. Virgil closely follows as the aloof and distant brother who stays true to his motivation to rule the world. Kat (or however her name is written) is by far the weakest and least convincing character and needs some rewriting, or a complete reset, for an eventual sequel. While there are worse characters out there for similar games, she did not add to the overall story, or game, with her presence.Story — 3/5The story takes a different route to most Western games by embracing a confrontational approach regarding modern media, society and, a tiny bit, religion. Luckily, it avoids being too confrontational by making statements that could offend or annoy potential consumers. Edgy, snarky, and cynical, but always within what is widely acceptable.Enemies — 2/5The first boss of the game created appetite for more but the bitter truth was that he remained one of the few highlights in the entire game. The enemies lacked variety and creativity, some were terribly bland and straight copies of previous enemies with added HP and changed colors. Standing out positively were some boss fights, while one boss (the Baby) provided the worst moment of the game by requiring the gamer to deliver huge DPS attacks, over and over, without giving him the right tools to do so, which created a grating and annoying experience.Graphics — 4/5Short loading times, fluid animations, beautiful colors and well crafted designs, there is not much, if anything, to hate about the graphics of DmC. The final boss fight in particular provided beautiful scenery, imagery and colors, which, to some extent, invoked memories of fighting Wesker in Resident Evil 5. With that being said, there were almost no wow, or whoa, moments and most of what the developers served, via means of the Unreal Engine, will be easily forgotten once experienced.Good Game Overall — 7/10

content:
Posted: April 17
												Finally went back and finished this after it had been in my backlog for a long time. DmC Devil May Cry, the remake done by Ninja Theory back in 2013 is a badass package. Screw the haters, this is without question the best Devil May Cry game ever. Great level design, creative and wicked intense boss battles, smooth and more user-friendly gameplay, good sense of humor, and an awesome story. The game also isn't as punishingly difficult as previous entries, making it easier to get in and enjoy the game without having to memorize a million combos and maneuvers to survive. My only real complaint is that the main game is pretty short (only 20 missions which can take anywhere from 2 to 15 minutes to complete) but there are plenty of unlockable bonus missions and difficulties. I hope Ninja Theory gets a second shot at the series, cause I had a blast from beginning to end with DmC.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2013
												I actually dislike most of the action (adventure) games like God Of War and Devil May Cry. They're usually all about the combat, which becomes a boring aspect for me a few hours into the game. And yes, they have great visuals most of the times, but visuals isn't a key aspect for me. Then again; they do help to pull the player into the game world. Anyway, DmC managed to surprise me because of it's environments, fluent combat and, maybe even more important for me; short campaign. You read correctly, a short campaign. It will take a player somewhere between 7,5-12 hours to fully complete one playthrough, which is a decent length and for me long enough to not become boring or overstay its welcome.The new Dante starts off as an annoying, run-of-the-mill character. But along the way I started caring for him. He grew more mature it seemed.Dante will start the game with some basic weaponry and will get new moves and weapons until late in the game, which keeps the combat fresh. Obviously, all weapons and moves can be upgraded. And there really are some amazing moves in there. Using a controller I was able to pull off some of the hardest combos. I'll admit, there was some button mashing involved, but most of the times I actually knew what I was doing.The environments steal the show though. Rarely have I seen environments this brilliant. The TV show (including boss fight) and nightclub levels are some of the best levels I've ever seen in a game. DmC uses a variety of bright colors, while still having a certain gothic feel to it. It's exceptional.You can tell they put some real love into the PC version since it will never dip below 60FPS. On Ultra settings things look (mostly) sharp and seeing the game in motion is a real treat, especially during the acrobatic (non-)combat sequences. The voice acting is top notch, but, unfortunately, the story is a bit on the light side.Time to wrap things up: I had a great time with this game and I would gladly recommend it to all serious gamers out there.[Rating: 80/100]

Summary I like this game but it could have been so much better as a child of the DMC franchise.My RantThis game would have been much better served by being a stand alone title rather than attaching itself to the DMC franchise.The game itself is great in most areas, I hated the colour coded enemies, they really brought the combat to a halt.The stylish ratings felt too easy to obtain aswell (this is due to my experience with the previous titles).I loved the new ways of getting around and the angel/demon crossover theme, however the angels were somewhat unexplained as new additions to the franchise.Overall, this game was ruined for me by being devil may cry (and by having a total tosser for a protaganist). content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I had mixed feelings when I bought this game. I saw many reviews saying how bad it was yet I saw some saying it was good. I would like to say that DmC: Devil May Cry is my favourite game of 2013 and in my top 3 games of all time. The graphics instantly hit you when you load with their many colours and what seems to be some of the most realistic graphics I've seen in a video game. The combat system is very easy to use, besides a few late registrations. The new and improved Dante is a blend of "Super-model pornstar" and "Popular comedian" with a slight hint of mystery to him. The variety of enemies to kill and weapons to kill them with is even better with the huge number of combo moves that you can unlock. The collectables are easy to find and a challenge to get to, yet very satisfying when you get them. The secret side challenges are amazing, ranging from easy to hellishly hard.Pros:- Dante has been highly improved- Funny and subtle hints to previous games get you ammused instantly- Easy controls- High number of enemies and weapons- Large number of combo moves to unlock- Side challenges to do when you want a rest- Amazing stroyline- Jaw dropping graphicsCons:- Some minor glitchesIf you have some spare cash lying around, I would highly recommend this. You will not be disappointed.Overall, I would give this game a well earned 10/10!

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015



YouTube™ Video: DMC: Devil May Cry Review 

			Views: 321		

			We take a look at the newest entry in the franchise that gave birth to the Extreme Combat subgenre. http://noobsthatplaygames.com/		

DMC Devil May Cry has certainly been the victim to a bunch of hate, some of it warranted, but most of it just nitpicky and unnecessary. If you go into this game with an open mind and are aware that is a reboot and a reimagining of the tale of Dante then you will be more than able to thoroughly enjoy yourself, However if you go into it expecting Devil May Cry 5 then you will be sadly disappointed.The game still focuses on the stringing together fast paced, brutal combos in an action-oriented combat that system that were so prominent in the previous entries. And the game still offers the style ranking system based on how well you perform in combat. But while the game still focuses heavily on the two key components that made the franchise famous…It does make them incredibly more “accessible” to players who have never played any of the previous entries, which wouldn’t be a bad thing seeing as the game offers seven different difficulty levels, However only three are unlocked from the start of the game and all three are simple enough where you can easily breeze through and get “Savage” or better on most levels. So unless you truly want to get some form of challenge from the game you’ll have to do a few play-throughs of the game before you really find yourself struggling to chain together a good enough combo to actually feel proud of yourself when you hear the omnipresent announcer proclaim “Savage!”. The oversimplification isn’t all bad, the game does offer incredibly streamlined controls that allow for lengthy combos to be chained together while swapping through all 8 weapons and both grappling hooks on the fly without any obstructive interface or item swapping. The natural feel provided from the streamlined controls is easily one of the game’s greatest features.Besides the dumbed down difficulty and scoring system the game is also hindered by its generic level and enemy design. None of the design in the game feels new or fresh; it’s just a bunch of dark, glum, narrow corridors with hordes of the same bland enemies with some fairly enjoyable platforming elements sprinkled in between. Not only are the designs of both the enemies and levels bland, but the main characters themselves are also both predictable, and flat. This isn’t the bias hate rambling of a fan-boy who’s♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥they changed Dante’s hair color, I’m honestly fine with the appearance of all the characters, even the new Emo Dante, but the game does offer plenty of alternative skins for those who are too turned off by the emo vibe.The visuals of the game are another one of the games strong points, offering easily some of the best visual graphics to come out of a Capcom game to date. And the game is certainly a solid PC port, during my playthroughs of the game I managed to stay well over 100fps without any dips that could potentially interfere with the fast paced combo chaining combat.  The soundtrack of the game is honestly a hit or miss based on your view of how you feel about Electronic Body Music, as the soundtrack consists primarily of the band Combichrist, I personally enjoy it however to each their own.After hearing the review thus far you would probably expect me to poorly rate the game, but its actually quite the opposite. Despite all of the complaints and flaws that this game has, it somehow manages to get passed all of that and provide an experience that is genuinely fun. If you look at the game you can easily pick apart the design flaws and nerfed difficulty, but even with all the flaws, DMC Devil May Cry proves to be an excellent game with strong enough legs to stand on its own and not be judged based on the previous entries in the franchise….because that’s the whole point of a reboot, to break away from the past and become something new. So don’t let the look of the game turn you off, pick up a controller and play through the game on the hardest difficulty you can and experience the beauty of the fast paced, stylish, streamlined, chaotic fun that you will have.http://noobsthatplaygames.com/

number of helpful: 45 of 90 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												While I am choosing to not recommend this game, I'd rather this review be seen as a "Meh" or "Average." DmC hits many things really well, and then falls flat on its face in others. I would like to preface by saying that I haven't played the original DMC games, but I have played Hideki Kamiya's Bayonetta, so my comparison will be based a bit around that.By now, it should be well known that this reboot's Dante is a black haired, foul mouthed early twenty-or-something troublemaker. While a big problem is how he compares to the original Dante, for this review I'll mostly be looking at the reboot as its own series separate from Kamiya's. So how does this Dante hold up as his own character? He's not necessarily a bad character. He displays growth, and becomes less bull headed and more concerned for others such as Kat. Some of his lines and actions are actually really good too, with his attitude being a perfect contrast for some of the serious guys there such as Vergil (in one particular scene, he answers Vergil with a shrug and "So what?" when Vergil brings up the idea of freeing the citizens). Dante exemplifies the punk movement, which is what he (and to an extent the society around him) was based off of, and I think he does a good job with it. That isn't to say he's the best character ever written, but he was the best in this game, as all the other character become really boring and flat to follow. Vergil is written awkwardly, with a shallow emotional spectrum to accompany him; essentially, he is our exposition machine. Kat is so flat I don't even know what she was doing in there. She does something action wise, but personality wise I can barely remember what her personality was after finishing the game 10 minutes ago - it's that bad. Mundus and his minions are all stereotypical demonic villains, looking to rule the world. Nothing about the writing sticks out, and many attempts at banter or funny one liners fail and just sound awkward. The voice acting for Dante is the best most of the time, but there are still a few parts when his voice actor seems to be new and they didn't go for a second take.The game does shine when it comes to its art direction, its music, and its combat system. The art, with the contrasts for Limbo and the original city, are great to see, and the music was cool to listen to as I'm slashing away at demons. One thing to note is that, if you don't like punk, or growling vocals, then this soundtrack will not be for you. The combat itself is apparently dumbed down, from what I hear, but it's not a bad thing for new players. I personally don't play much hack-n-slash so this was a good thing for me, I think, but I can see some veterans becoming bored (in which case I recommend playing the hardest difficulties). When I played I never got anything below an A, on medium, so maybe this can indicate how difficult the game is. It was still very satisfying combat, especially when it came to the harder to kill enemies, and getting those combos were awesome. However, I did find that there seemed to be a delay between inputting button commands, as many times I went to strike and wanted to dodge an incoming enemy attack, but I had to wait at least half a second to a second for my input to actually register as dodge. This can be annoying and especially frustrating on harder enemies. Furthermore, this game has a lot of platforming, more than I expected, which can be annoying at times; it also has a lot of cutscenes, sometimes with only a tiny element of gameplay (moving Dante to the next point) involved, which can be annoying as well if you want to get straight into the action. There's also no lock-on button, which can be absolutely bothersome combined with a frozen camera (see below).Some minor gripes: I played on a controller, and often times the camera would lock up and prevent me from spinning it, resulting in me getting hit by enemies. I'm not sure if playing with a KB+M is better, but I heard it is decent. Also, in comparing to the original DMC games, I wish this Dante would flourish his weapons each time he got them, but alas, Ninja Theory did not do that.Overall, DmC is certainly not a bad game gameplay and art wise, but the story is horrid. I recommend purchasing it on sale, and only if you're interested in the combat. If you like story based games, this one is not written well and will possibly disappoint you.

												If you liked the original Devil May Cry series, prepare to be disappointed.Rubbish combat system:1) Hold left trigger or right trigger to use either weapon, just remember to let go of them when you wanna use your UNDERPOWERED ebony and ivory2) No lock on, making combat even more sloppy and more about button tap rhythms3) Specific weapons for specific enemies, have fun using the right and left trigger!4) Despite all the flaws with the combat, you will rack up a high stylish rank with ease!Terrible story/characters:1) Dante is a brooding arrogant teen, not a slightly camp and charmingly arrogant badass.2) Story is REALLY cliché, Dante is now a half angel, half demon (snore)3) THE CORPORATIONS, DEMONS, HURRRR4) Characters take themselves seriously like in every sub-par disaster film from hollywoodDon't buy this game if you have a fondness of the Devil May Cry series, I beg you. If you were born at the end of the nineties or later, you may like this game as you have probably been critical of games for far less time than my cynical self.

												I always liked Devil May Cry games. My play time in DMC4 says it. I have DMC2 on PS2 that I completed on all difficulties as both Dante and Lucia. I didn't play DMC3 because it is buggy and almost impossible to setup. This DMC is a total disappointment for me. - I want to start with color-coded enemies: You know "use blue weapons to kill blue enemies and use red weapons to kill red enemies!" Not only this limits your options at weapons you can use against certain types of enemies, but it also ruins your variety of combos which Devil May Cry is all about. This is the problem which will persist you through the entire game.- I don't know who of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in Ninja Theory or Capcom thought that it would be a good idea to levitate all enemies in the air while going into Devil Trigger mode, either way it's stupid and annoying.- Dante's appearance change.- Lots of references to the past Devil May Cry games.And I am only half way through the game.

												So that's it, fanbase, you almost got me!, really!, your ridiculous butthurts about a reboot almost got my ears and i ALMOST discarded this AWESOME (i'll say it again, AWESOME) game.Talking seriously here, guys, what the heck are you in to blame an entire work for a character? i have to agree, Donte (yes, i refer the new Dante as Donte) , can't be compared with the old Dante, who needs no dirty words, no sexual content or neither pathetic look to earn a legion of fans , but for reals, he ISNT,THAT,BAD, okay? give him a chance, like me, and you'll see the Donte's new look (pfft, really, talk♥♥♥♥♥♥about a game because they re-designed a character...) and personality CHANGES trough the game, im not here to say "hur dur, the DmC is way better than original, hur dur" because it isn't, but its an superb job and has everything that characterizes the DmC's gameplay, the combos, the weapons, the upgrades, the hidden things,  the orbs is here! only little things have changed and for better.The Plot of the game is really amazing, full of Critics to our society (the Virility Drink, the Demons who represents men of extreme influence and power),and its everything well planned , the only thing i have to say here is that Kat can be more explored and developed, though, the Nephalem legend-based story for the Twins really fits the characters (thats MY opinion, i dont care if you agree or not, but if you wont, feel free to talk about it)Graphics , Soundtrack, Dialogues and jokes are really good and add a good temper to the game, everything is beautiful and well designed, the levels of the game have a stunning view, the music is awesome and fits in to the hack'n'slash gameplay, everything here is fine.The game is incredible, but has its issues, the camera is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥sometimes it didn't respond to my right analogic stick and didnt turn left or right, i need to wait a little to turn it,so , i fell often because of this in plataform mini games,  the lack of lock in is a great problem that made me miss almost every long combo i try to did, and i found the game too easy (playing on the Nephalem dificulty) if was compared to the old ones.Yes, i recommend this incredible game, who needs no dante to be good, if you want to be mad at something, talk about the stinky port of the Devil May Cry 3 for the PC, THIS is a thing to be upset with good reasons,  9/10

number of helpful: 41 of 83 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2013
												A game with much controversy surrounding its release due to both the stylistic change and the developer's confrontational and punk-like attitude.The result, while not being the pinnacle of hack and slash/spectacle fighters that one of its predecessors was (DMC3), still comes off as very enjoyable and even addictive at times. Starting with the bad, the fighitng system has been simplified from past releases. Gone are the variety of styles and in their place two new types of weapons are available by holding down each of the triggers. Each weapon type has in turn two sub weapons that behave differently.This doesn't mean that this is a Fisher-Price, nursing school fighter. The game still requires skillful and deliberate actions in order to be able to deliver a standing ovation worthy, class A demon spanking. It's just that, in what i guess was, an attempt to trim some of the franchise's fat the devs cut off some of the meat as well and this in turn hurt both the gameplay factor and the overall longevity of the title.Another drawback is that there is no visual indicator for the targeting system so focusing on different opponents and prioritizing your targets feels more clunky. Finally the point system feels off as it awards more points the more enemies you hit in one blow or the more hits you deliver in a short ammount of time rather than handsomely rewarding precise actions like countering hits.  This in turn makes combat feel more spammy and offense-based rather than the "taunting", bursty type of combat in previous DMCs.From the above you'd guess that i don't like DmC? Well you couldn't be more wrong.First of all the level design in this and level variety in particular is one of the best of the series so far, with levels like Lilith's Club, and the News Network stealing the show.I really liked the punk/pop/street culture based style of the visuals as well. The fighting while simplified as mentioned above is still very satisfying and fun to play and the angel/demon based mechanics, aside from a cool nod to Dante's duality as a character, are well implemented allowing you to pull off every move imaginable on the fly.Opting for including platforming rather than puzzles that slow down the pacing was a solid decision on the dev's part imo. It just keeps the game flowing better.The game's story bears strong similarities to J.Carpenter's "They Live". Personally i found it enjoyable yet nothing groundbreaking given that it's a concept that i was already familiar with through said film.Character performances are solid as well with Mundus's standing out for me.The only sour note in that department was that Dante's one liners come off as forced and "wooden" at times.I also liked the soundtrack as well but i realize that given the niche of the genre (Electro/Industrial) it won't be for everybody.On the technical side of things QLOC have done a terrific job making this game look spectacular while mainting very high fps and motion fluidity on max settings, resulting in this being one of the best uses of UE3 to date imo. Overall, a very fun to play H&S title, excellent for newcomers to the genre as well as those that want to rekindle their interest in spectacle fighters.Recommended.

												[  ขอรีวิวใหม่ทั้งหมด ]ไม่ได้เจอเกม Action ที่ปลุก Adenarine ในตัวมานานแล้วครั้งแรกที่ได้สัมผัส DmC Devil May Cry เพียงแค่วินาทีแรก กดฟันปกติก็ทำให้หลงรักในความมันส์ของเกมได้ ! ภาคนี้เป็นภาครีบูท 2013 ซึ่งจะแยกกับภาคเก่า ถ้าเป็นภาคเก่า ก็จะเป็น DMC ส่วนภาคนี้ DmC เป็นเรื่องราวของดันเต้นักล่าปิศาจ ลูกชายของสปาร์ด้าปีศาจในตำนาน ซึ่งดันเต้ภาคนี้โดนรีบูทจากดันเต้ภาคก่อนๆ และเนื้อเรื่องปรุงแต่งใหม่ทั้งหมด ! ซึ่งแฟนบอยรับไม่ได้เป็นอย่างมาก แต่ถ้าเรามองข้ามเรื่องนั้นไป gameplay ภาคนี้ลื่นไหล เข้าใจง่าย และระบบต่อสู้ การใช้อาวุธต่างๆ ทำออกมาได้ดี เปลี่ยนอาวุธแบบ Real Time ได้ด้วย (ยกตัวอย่าง ฟันดาบ 2 ที เปลี่ยนเคียวต่ออีกคอมโบได้) บรรยกาศในเกมชอบมากดูไปดูมา ทำไมมันคล้ายๆเรื่อง Inception (2010) ฟร่ะะ ส่วนเนื้อเรื่องปานกลาง ไม่ถึงกับดีแต่ก็ไม่ได้แย่อะไร แต่สิ่งที่ภาคนี้หายไปคงจะเป็นความยาก ความกดดัน ในการต่อสู้ เขารีบูทมาใหม่ มันจะเป็นมิตรกับผู้เล่นใหม่ใช้เวลาเรียนรู้ไม่นาน -สรุปแล้ว DmC Devil May Cry เป็นเกม Hack & Slash , Beat'em Up สุดมันส์อีกเกมหนึ่ง ที่ไม่ควรพลาด !!! สำหรับผมแล้วมันคือ My Best Action Game Ever <3 เอาใจผมไปเลย 10/10 GG

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Without touching on the stupid story, cause this isn't the focus:- The combat is weak as hell. At first glance it seems alright and similar enough to classic DMC, but enemies are incredibly easy to juggle forever - playing this game on Son of Sparda difficulty (the one right before Dante Must Die) is equivalent to playing DMC3 on normal. The game tries to create challenge by putting in enemies that can only be hit by one type of weapon (a very annoying mechanic that goes against the basic concept of the game) or facing you up against really annoying enemies that take way too much effort to open up for attacks at all (do the chainsaw guys seriously need to enter a Hyperarmor state every 5 seconds??). Even DMC3 had its enemy design pitfalls but DmC really becomes just annoying- Why is the game so easy?? The encounter design is mostly a joke, the bosses are all gimmicks with nothing interesting to them. DMC3 had a lot of crummy bosses, DMC4 fell short on making them interesting beyond the devilbringer interactions - they're both vastly superior to what this game got. The final boss is a retread of DMC3s final boss except its incredibly pathetic in comparison. Good summary for the game in general- Instead of any sort of interesting level design all this game has is dumb artsy concepts interspersed with copy pasted hallways and floating platforms to spend another hour platforming on. Instead of exploring an ancient demon structure like in 3 you now get to grapple onto blue "press button" prompts while impact fonts get shoved in your face and the game tries to make you go Wow!!! via some or other stupid manner of bombast that just makes the whole fighting arena look like♥♥♥♥♥♥(the disco is especially unreadable and offensive to the eyes)- Constantly breaks up the flow of the game by making you platform. Why so much platforming. What the ♥♥♥♥. Also constantly shoves cutscenes in your face, why is there a shot of dantes eyes every time some demons spawn. DMC usually was nice enough to reserve cutscenes for the start and end of missions, and bossfights.- For how the game trys to be a reboot they doubledown on the devilbringer, except making it far less interesting and forcing you to use it constantly in pointless sequences that are neither challenging nor fun. Using the subweapons and the special property dodges is an annoyance cause you seemingly cant set it to be a toggle, so I hope you like holding down the trigger buttons all gameIt's bad and nothing but dangling keys in front of people who have no clue about the genre (all the visual clutter and the stupidly easy braindead gameplay makes it a normie favorite) and Ninja Theory is a bad developer and I hope they go bankrupt

number of helpful: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												A good game for the non DMC series fanatic (And if you are then you are probably off cursing Ninja Theory and Capcom somewhere on a message board in japan). Most of the negativity for this game comes from previous DmC fans who absolutely refuse change. I have personally been playing Dmc since the original (have a copy in my desk right next to me :cwat:) The only one I haven't played is 2. That being said yeah, It's different, but it is truly an enoyable hack n' slash action game.Pros:-Surprisingly decent storyline, Not Squeenix quality... But good enough.-Combat: Good 8/10, It has a wider range of weapons that can be used creatively and fit better to a play style resulting in enjoyable combat. I have my complaints some of them being that the devil trigger is now a next to useless feature and the guns are even less effective as combat tools as they were... be that as it may, the melee combat is superb.-Gameplay: 7/10 Above average, The smooth gameplay is ridged with average linear level design giving you deja vu 20 times before the end of the mission, and the difficulty is definitely easier (I remember the days when you had to work to get the double jump ability), but overall the gameplay is nice and the interaction and dynamics of the levels make it a positive experience.-Art: 8.75/10 Goodish Great, Grafitti is not really my style, however the art was fantastically done. Much brighter than past games and much more colorful. While some people like the pure gothic artistry of old, I prefer not to stare at grey walls for an entire 31 hr story based game. In game graphics are good quality.Cons-Character Development: Let's just say this dante, while at times can have good character enlightenment, is mostly a 15 year old kid who just filled out his profanity lexicon. The "bad boy" theme is way too overdone to the point that it is a pile of swearing and rude gestures on top of an ego obssessed frat boy. I found myself more interested in the development of the side/main character Kat. I'm not going to start on Virgil because spoilers however potential was lost.Middle Ground:-Music: While not my choice, there was still some death metal battle themes and that's all I expected.tl;dr It's a good game, pick it up on a sale for some good old fashion hack n' slash fun

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I am new to the DmC franchise, so I don't have an opinion on this game as a sequel.  But viewing it as a standalone game and without specific expectations, I'm finding it a joy to play.  I'm not the biggest fan of the popular genre of action games with pretty graphics, but this one really stands out.  The combat, though fairly categorized as "hack-and-slash," is very satisfying.  The responsiveness of the controls and the fluid feel of the combos make for a visceral experience that is more enjoyable than with any other action game I've played. Added to that gameplay element is the artfulness of the story and graphic design.  I was skeptical on this front when I bought the game since I'm not really into Goth or anything like that.  But the artistry on display here just won me over.  You really have to play the game to understand what I mean on this subject.  The cutscenes, the sound, the art style--everything in this game comes together in a way that makes it more than the sum of its parts.  Kudos to Capcom.
