number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												DmCThe Look - The game's visuals are all top notch. The developers were clearly able to put a lot of time and effort into the environments and character designs. Dante and his cohorts all have a unique look and interesting attire. The game received some flack during its reveal for ditching the classic white-haired Dante but I think that there is a strong, fun, and unique visual style that permeates the experience. You will see some recycled enemy designs but there are enough minor differences between types that I never felt bored by their appearance. The main visual treat is the environment, which has a habit of transforming as you move through it. Walls rise and fall and floors will turn into stairs, pits, and stepping stones, as familiar environments often get twisted into a more hellish version of their former selves.The Sound - No real issues with the audio quality. That said, the music tracks might not be for everyone. I don't have prior experience but I felt that the musical stylings of Combichrist had the potential to be somewhat polarizing. If you don't like heavy metal or death metal (or precious metals?) you might not be a fan of the audio tracks. However, I'm not a huge fan of the genre but I was never really put off by it so I think most people will be fine here. Great use of sound effects with some nice visceral slices, slams, and crunches during combat. Additionally, the voice acting, which you'll be exposed to frequently, is very strong on all fronts.The Gameplay - Despite some claims of oversimplification, I think this game is tons of fun to play. It follows the basic 3rd person action trends with all of the combos, dodges, and power moves that you'd expect. What makes DmC stand out a bit is the variety of weapons and the diversity of each. Heavy, Medium, Light, and Ranged weapons are all on display and all offer something fun and new when unlocked. The game's grading system (a genre staple) is also a fun way to compete against others and yourself while trying to unlock things like concept art and new costumes. There are a number of hidden collectibes that can be found in the game, but these often veer into the dangerous territory of tedium when you try to seek them all out. Also, despite the fast and fun combat, there are some levels that feel overly long or overly short so don't expect that each new chapter will take the same amount of time as the last one.The Story - DmC's story is a simple but fun affair. You are Dante, half-angel/half-demon, and you're out for revenge on the demon who orphaned you and is currently trying to take over the world. There are some fun twists and turns along the way but nothing jaw dropping or genre defining. While Dante's brash attitude may seem a bit obnoxious, the character grew on me and by the end of the game I found myself eagerly awaiting his next quip or shocking turn of phrase. The narrative has just enough momentum to keep you interested in learning more about Dante's past and to see what steps he'll take to get his revenge. You'll never be moved to tears, but you'll probably get a few laughs out of this yarn.Other Thoughts - There's not a lot to say here. This is not a game of great thematic depth or complexity. The combat, on the other hand, has both in spades. I think this is a great first chapter in what will hopefully become a new series of games. Oftentimes, 3rd person action games will lose their footing somewhere. The story may be obtuse or boring, the combos may be too tough to pull off, the enemies might be too easy or difficult, etc. DmC does a great job of walking this line and not overstaying its welcome. Score - 4/5 (A solid game. Genre fans should love it, while others will probably really like it. Check it out!)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This new Dante feels like an old friend.I'll admit, I was skeptical of this series re-launch, especially when it was first announced back in 2010 and the first promotional image was this: http://static1.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20120923082161/devilmaycry/images/1/12/Dante_dmc_2010.jpgMy gut reaction to seeing that image back then was "You just ruined Dante and the DMC franchise." and to an extent, that gut reaction sort of stayed with me until I finally had a chance to try the game for myself.Thankfully, the end result was far from my initial fears.DmC does a good job of managing to reinvent the so-called "origin" story of Dante and Vergil, and yet by and large once you manage to get used to the new face and very different attitude (at least at first) of the new Dante, you'll discover that the gameplay itself is nothing short of the classic DMC style you've come to know.Controls have been somewhat re-imagined in a way that neither takes too long to get used to nor feels terribly unfamiliar. By and large they are handled well, and a lot of the familiar signature aspects that the franchise is known for are still here as well.For example, orbs and the time statues for "shopping" are present here. Dante still has Ebony and Ivory and they still get unlimited ammo. Signature abilities like Stinger make their return with a new control schemata. Devil trigger is of course also present, though it works in a slightly different way than in most of the past entries, it nonetheless manages to impress just as it always has.While I did have some initial complaints about Dante's voice acting (the lines seemed really flat early on in the game) once you give it some more time it fleshes itself out better, and that also gives you a chance to get adjusted to the new Dante as well.And it IS an adjustment. Gone is the super confident whimsical and snarky don't-take-life-too-seriously Dante of yore, for the most part. This new Dante is younger, more apathetic and less enthusiastic, but to an extent this new attitude is plot related as well, and for what it's worth I think it is a convincing way to show character growth and progression.Gradually as Dante begins to open his eyes to the situation around him through the plot events, he starts becoming more empathetic, and discovers his own true nature in the process.I won't spoil the details too much, but it was good to see his character maturing over the course of the game. And while I do feel like he never reached the same height on the badass meter that classic Dante manages to capture, by the time all is said and done it's clear to see he's squarely on his way to becoming more like his platinum haired alter ego.Take away from this what you will, but if you're willing to brave the initial storm and wait for the seas to calm, as far as the new Dante goes, you'll see this is another great entry in the DMC series. It takes a bit to get used to the changes, but change can be good sometimes.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												A reboot of the well-known devil may cry series, DmC is a game which takes things to a whole new level, with new weapons with "angel" and "devil" alignments and with different usages and more. The visuals are a huge step-up, the graphics in this game are pleasing to the eyes and the game does not require high-end specs to run, the gameplay is smooth and fun to play around with the different moves and combos you can execute to rack up style points (Side note: The style counter is different from the original games), the story is great as you play a younger dante who is much more reckless and violent who is fighting for mankind and to in turn restore his forgotten memories, soundtrack and ambience is more of a rock and roll, violent kind of world you are thrown into. Overall, it is a really great game (well it is made by ninja theory), 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												On a 10-point scale, DmC is a solid 9. I got into the series some years ago after playing the third game. Comments by DMC purists sparked my interest in this... and they don't know on what they're missing out.I think the story is great, there's some character development, the soundtrack is awesome and the gameplay is very satisfying. I unlocked all 48 main achievements in a three-week span (about 60 hours playing and I have yet to buy the Vergil DLC) and I'm still not tired of playing it. The game is definitely lengthy and it does have replay value. Bloody Palace mode is really fun. While the game's difficulty has been toned down to appeal to less skilled players, it's still DMC to the core, and the higher difficulty levels shouldn't disappoint.On the other hand, almost all bosses are uninspired. Only the first and the last ones felt like true bosses. They're way too static (apart from the aforementioned ones) and humanized. I was hoping for more beast-like ones. All guns are useless and a couple weapons didn't satisfy my inner demon slayer, like Aquila. While Eryx was good, it was the weapon I used the least. Despite the flaws, this kicks♥♥♥♥♥and I can't wait for a sequel. If you buy this, you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I've played this to death on Xbox 360 and took the plunge on PC and notice a huge difference. The graphical difference isn't that noticeable, although the PC version runs in 1080P and does look better than console, it's not a "holy crap!" jump in quality. The real reason to get this again on PC is the fact that it runs 60FPS vs. 30 on the console releases.Simply put, the game is smoother than a baby's♥♥♥♥♥now. The game feels much better to play and this is the only version I will play again. DmC on PC is the definitive version. My only gripe is that this, and other Capcom  games on Steam, are way over priced. If they go on sale, jump on it. I got this during the summer sale along with the DLC for peanuts. I would NOT pay full price for this game if you already own it. Hell, even if you don't, $50 for a game from 2013 is ridiculous when the console versions are in bargain bins at Best Buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Haters gonna hate the new Dante, but nevertheless, this is mechanically far better than it's predecessors. Gone are the stupid resident evil style static cameras, gone is the need to lock-on to foes in order to effectively track them. Gone are the derptastic controls that made this franchise a nightmare to newcomers. Now you can actually CONTROL the camera, dish out the pain in copious amounts, and feel good doing so! So what if the new Dante is a derf at first? This game gets a few things wrong, but gets a lot of things right. Even though DMC5 will feature classic Dante, I certainly hope Capcom takes some notes from DmC, as this is how you do that genre properly; Easy to learn, difficult to master.I also expect classic Dante to have a retort for new Dante's 'white hair' wisecrack... because Dante would totally bash other versions of himself. (That joke really annoyed fans of the series despite that being a very Dante thing to do... which makes me sad)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Don't listen to the haters.DmC is by no means perfect. I don't think anyone will ever recreate the magic that was DMC3, but for all the negative hype that the game received, DmC really does its best to impress.Mechanically, the game is fantastic. For veterans of the series, it is a breath of fresh air. Dante retains all his abilities (similar to his appearance in DMC4), and through five different toggle buttons he's able to quickly access any of his tools. Perhaps most notably, almost all of the tools in DmC are different and useful. Each attack sequence has a unique purpose for which it is best-suited, and while you'll probably come out with some favorites that you rely on, you'll almost certainly use every tool in your kit to play on the harder difficulty modes.Also, DmC is hard! For people just wanting to experience the story, the easier difficulties are quite easy. However, even the Nephilim difficulty is fairly hard on one's first time through the game. Series vets who want a challenge will find it, and unlike DMC3, the DMD difficulty is pretty fun and rewards aggressive play rather than the tedium of DMC3.The story is a mixed bag, but it is two stories in one. The surface story -- the one most people comment on -- is rather contrite. It's a story of revolutionaries fighting against evil governments and corporations, and makes a lot of overt social commentary on modern culture. DmC throws this message in your face over and over, and honestly I was turned off by it. Fortunately, there's another story behind that one.The real story of DmC is its commentary on freedom versus order, or chaos versus slavery. It's also a story about the little people, and not about the godlike characters (Dante, Vergil, Mundus) who move the plot. In the end, even though one side does triumph, it is supposed to be a hollow victory, as though something of great importance was lost. DmC has a lot of message beneath its very blatant and shallow surface, but because the social commentary is so loud and obvious, it tends to be obscured.Perhaps most noteworthy about the story is that, other than his appearance, Dante is still Dante. While he's young and a bit inexperienced -- allowing him to grow as a character  -- he retains all the elements we're used to with Dante. He's a brash, arrogant jerk with a heart of gold, fundamentally the same Dante we've known and loved.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A very enjoyable entry into the Devil May Cry series, even if not as conventionally brow-beating as the rest of the series.Dante's characteristic bravado and wit are somewhat subdued here, and he is much less campy and over-the-top. And yet, I find it an enjoyable break by providing some much-needed character development.While I was very skeptical at first, the gameplay and art style went through a few revamps and I was sold. When I began playing, I was immediately engrossed in the drop-in gameplay and the interesting new mechanics borrowed from DMC4's Nero and his Devil Bringer.While a stark contrast to the previous entries in the serious, I would recommend DmC to fans of the series and newcomers alike, as long as you don't hold your breath for some of the same old.Critiques I do have are mostly based on the style change (which I got over) and the ease of difficulty, which seems less masochistic than the more current entries.

												I have yet to play any of the other Devil May Cry games, but I enjoyed this one quite a bit. DmC: Devil May Cry is similar to METAL GEAR RISING: REVENGEANCE in terms of gameplay.The game is pretty linear with some replay value, there are a lot of hidden keys/rooms/items/ghosts throughout the levels, and there are many difficulty modes as well. content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Not many people are happy at this series getting a reboot, but since Capcom wrote itself into a corner as of DMC4, they don't have a choice. That being said, this game is worth a try. While some of the dorkyness that came to define the series has been toned down, the gameplay remains top notch, matched only by the enchanting Bayonetta. If you played the past DMC games solely for the story, then I don't know what to tell you. BUt if it was the gameplay that kept you coming back, then this game doesn't disappoint.The series needed a reboot, and this is an amazing attempt at that. Its not the DMC we all played back on our PS2s, but it is a refreshing take on the characters with the same classic gameplay that made this series a success. It deserves a chance from any "fan".

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This a rewrite, having spent more time with the game now my opinion of it has changed quite a bit.If you were a fan of the last four Devil May Cry games, you'll probably love this. In this retelling of Dante's origin story, a lot of the combat elements of it's predecessors has been brought here and refined to near perfection, something Ninja Theory is very good at. However the art style and the personality of the protagonist, Dante has been changed dramatically. He is less a facetious, care free, badass demon hunter from DMC 1, 2 and 4 and more the irresponsible punk with demon powers from 3, but somehow more annoying and crass. There is a point early in the game (which I personally do NOT appreciate) where Dante wanders through a circus or fair and through circumstances a wig very similar from the hairstyle and colour the old Dante wore lands on his hair, and he throws it off in disgust. Overall, I would give this an 8/10. It IS a great game, however some of the direct insults thrown at the older games, intentional or not are off putting to me as a fan of the series.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Basically this game, as many have noticed after a few minutes, is just a bad imitation of the Devil May Cry saga. Combos, controls, Devil Tigger, characters, story, level design are all different.Defining it as a bad imitation is not, however, a way of telling that it is, also, a bad game. Despite differences, some gameplay approaches are enjoyable, like the possibility of using the entire arsenal at Dante's disposal. Let's just say it's a decent action game that expected to be dragged to the success through the use of a popular franchise, or at least for the most part. If we pass above all of this we have in our hands a pretty funny 10 hours action game. Gameplay is rough in some ways (automatic lock-on and an awful Devil Trigger, for example) but with good possibilities of being developed in the future in a better game with, let's hope, an own core and soul (and better story/characterization).

content:
Posted: January 2
												Pros: + Easy, yet satisfying Combat. A bit different than in the originals, but good nonetheless.+ Music is fairly good. Gets you in the mood for hacking&slashing. Fits the tone of the level.+ Artwork & Level design is great.+ Great pacing: Platforming introduced and works in between fights.+- Monster Design on bosses: great, normal enemies: meh/alright.  Cons:- Dante and the whole game feels a bit too try-hard. A lot of 'f*ck you's' and 'bigger d*ck' jokes, yet all fall flat.- Seasoned original DMC players breeze through the game on harder difficulties. Went in on hard difficulty, never used one healing item in the playthrough and almost every level i completed on a S-SSS rating.- NO LOCK-ON IN BATTLE!- Story was underwhelming and felt a bit too 'They Live' movie to me(please go watch it, it's a classic). Seems like the team tried to hard to put in a (hidden) message into the story. Establishment vs freedom-fighters-esque.- Few weapons- Camera issues in tight quarters. Sometimes camera would not move 180degrees.- MUNDUS. What a letdown!Still, i recommend the game if you want a fun hack&slasher. But don't expect the same as the originals. I played DMC1, 3 & 4, but they each had better fighting mechanics imo.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												DmC tries too hard. "Dante is cool in this one," it says, "see these girls? He totally had sex with her last night. Sex is cool, right?""And look at the bad guys," it gushes, "they're metaphors for corporate sleazebags who try to keep society dumb and obedient. Enslavement through faux (Fox?) news and sugary drinks! Get it?""You're the Resistance. You're standing up to the demons (corporate overlords) and insulting them in their faces! Ever wanted to say '♥♥♥♥ you' to the Man? Dude, we have you covered, there's so many '♥♥♥♥ you' lines in this game that you're going to feel empowered as all♥♥♥♥♥♥"There's the seed for a good plot in there somewhere, buried beneath piles of awkward dialogue, oversimple characterization and the promotion of social-commentary-that-should-be-subtext into neon-lettered, 50-foot high signage. Dante isn't really likeable, the storytelling is awkward and I was embarrassed several times watching really badly-written dialogue exchanges. Worse, I found myself cheering for Virgil, the more put-together brother who bothers thinking ahead to what's going to happen after he and Dante bring down the Evil Overlord. What's wrong with being the guy in charge of picking up the pieces after the world is turned upside down, again? I guess it's bad because DmC has a very marked punk ideology and becoming the authorities goes against that?So why do I recommend DmC? The gameplay is pretty good, and that should be the main reason for you to buy this. Not as good as Devil May Cry 3, but then what is?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												For a reboot/prequel, DMC checks all the right boxes when it comes to nods from the original series, refresh on game mechanics and overall introduction to those new to the series. I really enjoyed the gameplay but that was not surprising comging from the Ninja Theory team as all of their games have been strong in that department. What I did not care for in this game was the camera controls. There were many instances where the camera was stuck in a corridor or on a wall and I was not able to rotate it without moving my position (which sometimes this was very difficult due to the current camera angle I was in). Overall, not the worst third person camera angle ever, and compared to the rest of the series, it really wasn't unexpected. However, being made in the Unreal engine, I had hoped for better. Ninja Theory did an amazing job uitilizing the rendering power of the Unreal Engine as the levels were not just physically beautiful, but the way the environment reacted to your presence was something that I really had not seen done in previous games. The use of the environment shaders and particle effects in this game were astounding. I really felt like I was playing in an extended scene from Constantine with a heavy metal thrash soundtrack. Definitely recommend this game to those who have enjoyed the other Devil May Cry games, however they should be prepared for Dante's mannerisms to be different than the previous games, but in a fresh sense more inline with modern youth rebellion behavior. New people to the series should also like this game if they like games like God of War or the like. Since it is a prequel/reboot, no knowledge of the previous games stories are necessary to enjoy this game.

												Great spiritual successor to the previous series!  The gameplay is there, but the characters and story are wholly reimagined.  Those who have played the originals will find the gameplay to have familiar control schemes combined with a refreshingly unique angel-demon weapon system.For reference: my personal favorite of the series is DMC4, followed by DMC1.  I hated the remake of Dante, and disapproved of everything I saw in trailers.  However, after playing it, I see why they pursued their creative differences from the original team. While I do not think this exceeds the quality of 4, I do think it's an amazing game and is one of the best in the series, and a great start to a new Dante universe.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Note: Only consider buying it on sale. I barely recommend it and bought it on sale to begin with.I'm a bit on the fence with this one but I don't regret the purchase so I guess it's a recommend. Ultimately, it's a mediocre game with a handful of redeeming qualities. Unfortunately, it's more of a linear, 3rd person adventure game than a hack and slash. In other words, don't expect the normal Devil May Cry.Cons:The story has some political subtext HAMMED into it. The presentation of said story is also pretty bad with some very trashy lines filled with profanity to make it seem edgy or something.If you are the type of person who analyzes games for their design, you'll notice quickly that the game is a compromise between the combat centric design of the first Devil May Cry games and something like Legend of Zelda/God of War. The result is a somewhat run-of-the-mill combat system, somewhat stale exploration, and similarly stale platforming.Jump canceling is easier. This means that you can do stupid stuff like gain infinite height using the hook+JC combo with one enemy. It looks silly/game-breaking and is stupidly easy to pull off.Metal music that doesn't sound that great for metal. It sounds like 2nd rate indie metal. Weapons seem to fit very specific purposes against specific enemies rather than opening up options for player creativity. Furthermore, some of them don't even have that distinct of a behavior, making them mechanical variations of a more limited set of weapons.The lack of a targeting system makes the controls feel pretty awkward.Pros:It tries to experiment with some mechanics to varying degrees of success like how you can pull to and pull in enemies at will unlike Nero's buster which was limited to enemy type.Jump canceling is easier. This is also more welcoming to newer players.The levels look pretty impressive and the color oversaturation is a nice mix up. It does get in the way at times but it wasn't nearly as offensive as some people claim in my experience. I never felt sick or anything and I feel ill if I play CS:GO too much :/Lots of weapons at least keeps it fresh.Lots of secrets to find.Enemies give very clear tells. The dial up combo system that has been standard in Devil May Cry is now aided by a light up effect, letting the player combo more consistently.Story has it's moments that made me chuckle for various reasons.Faster rendering/loading times than Devil May Cry 4. Also, it's a finished game unlike Devil May Cry 4 and not an awful port like Devil May Cry 3.If you're fine with a B-movie story and a decent chunk of optional exploration and mandatory platforming, DMC: Devil May Cry is a game worth picking up considering the amount of content and decent amount of interesting exploration.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Pros:DMC has a fluid combat system that allows you to switch between any of your weapons mid-comboControls are fairly easy to pick upFun platforming sections between Hack and Slash fightsCons:Dante's New look/attitudeNo cut scene where dante surfs on a demon around his office, guns blazing, with a slice of pizza hanging out his mouth and a scythe protruding from his chest.Conclusion:Overall I enjoyed the game, but I hated the new Dante. I grew up with the Devil May Cry series through Junior High and High School and I was looking forward to seeing the pizza loving demon hunter return with his cheesy one liners. Instead I got an angsty, barely-legal, frat boy who lives in a super sketchy looking mobile home who also happens to have Nephilim powers. I feel that the developers tried too hard to make the game appeal to a mature audience by putting the word "f**k" in the dialogue every chance they got. Also the levels are really psychadellic (not sure on the spelling of that).Over all I think they tried to make the game more appealing to a casual western audience instead of the die hard fans of the original series, but I still enjoyed playing the game minus the part where a pregnant woman and her child get shot. Yeah. That's a thing (and it could have totally not been included).

												Fantastic game from start to finish.  Beautiful visuals, good storyline, good voice acting, great playability, good replay potential and music from one of my favorite bands of all time Nosia.  I was a decent fan of the first Devil May Cry, but not enough of one to play any of the other follow up games.  This is not a follow up game, it's a complete reboot and in my opionion absolutely destroys the first one in terms of being a great game.  It's as if God of War and Silent Hill had a baby.  If you're a fan of the God of War or orignal Devil May Cry franchise, this game is must.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												DmC tries too hard. "Dante is cool in this one," it says, "see these girls? He totally had sex with her last night. Sex is cool, right?""And look at the bad guys," it gushes, "they're metaphors for corporate sleazebags who try to keep society dumb and obedient. Enslavement through faux (Fox?) news and sugary drinks! Get it?""You're the Resistance. You're standing up to the demons (corporate overlords) and insulting them in their faces! Ever wanted to say '♥♥♥♥ you' to the Man? Dude, we have you covered, there's so many '♥♥♥♥ you' lines in this game that you're going to feel empowered as all♥♥♥♥♥♥"There's the seed for a good plot in there somewhere, buried beneath piles of awkward dialogue, oversimple characterization and the promotion of social-commentary-that-should-be-subtext into neon-lettered, 50-foot high signage. Dante isn't really likeable, the storytelling is awkward and I was embarrassed several times watching really badly-written dialogue exchanges. Worse, I found myself cheering for Virgil, the more put-together brother who bothers thinking ahead to what's going to happen after he and Dante bring down the Evil Overlord. What's wrong with being the guy in charge of picking up the pieces after the world is turned upside down, again? I guess it's bad because DmC has a very marked punk ideology and becoming the authorities goes against that?So why do I recommend DmC? The gameplay is pretty good, and that should be the main reason for you to buy this. Not as good as Devil May Cry 3, but then what is?

content:
Posted: January 2
												Pros: + Easy, yet satisfying Combat. A bit different than in the originals, but good nonetheless.+ Music is fairly good. Gets you in the mood for hacking&slashing. Fits the tone of the level.+ Artwork & Level design is great.+ Great pacing: Platforming introduced and works in between fights.+- Monster Design on bosses: great, normal enemies: meh/alright.  Cons:- Dante and the whole game feels a bit too try-hard. A lot of 'f*ck you's' and 'bigger d*ck' jokes, yet all fall flat.- Seasoned original DMC players breeze through the game on harder difficulties. Went in on hard difficulty, never used one healing item in the playthrough and almost every level i completed on a S-SSS rating.- NO LOCK-ON IN BATTLE!- Story was underwhelming and felt a bit too 'They Live' movie to me(please go watch it, it's a classic). Seems like the team tried to hard to put in a (hidden) message into the story. Establishment vs freedom-fighters-esque.- Few weapons- Camera issues in tight quarters. Sometimes camera would not move 180degrees.- MUNDUS. What a letdown!Still, i recommend the game if you want a fun hack&slasher. But don't expect the same as the originals. I played DMC1, 3 & 4, but they each had better fighting mechanics imo.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												I enjoy this reboot more than the original series - it plays a lot like Bayonetta, although I personally prefer Bayonetta.Basically the game is about performing stylish combos. In this way it is a lot like a rhythm game or even an extreme sports game like Tony Hawk's Pro Skater in the sense that your main goal (other than beating levels and not dying) is to link together seamless combos.Don't be disheartened if you suck at this game at first - I really did. It makes great use of all of the buttons on the controller (I played with an Xbox 360 controller). You must be constantly messing with the shoulder buttons and using them in tandem with ABXY as the shoulder buttons change your weapons on the fly when you're holding them. It's a system that was difficult for me to get used to, but after about four hours I was handling it pretty well.The main game doesn't take very long to beat, but the fun of it is being able to play the game again on harder difficulties. The main difficulty is not very hard, and I rarely died. But as you get into the higher difficulties that are unlocked as you beat previous difficulties the game tests your ability to quickly think up smart combos and understand how to deal with each enemy. Aside from the gameplay, the game has a fantastic presentation and a decent story. The story is predictable and bland, but it serves the game and it is satisfying when you finally get to take down the games main bad dude. The presentation is wonderful - really cool colors, especially when you take the contrast between the "real world" and "limbo" into consideration, which I think was intentional. The real world is really depressing and bland, but limbo is ridiculous and colorful. Very cool game and I highly recommend it now that it's cheaper.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												An above average hack 'n slash that was marketed so poorly that people thought it was an "edgy and gritty" game that had a message, which resulted in horrible sales and a permanent stain on what should have been another high note in one of the most original series of our time.DMC: Devil May Cry is not a grimdark trek through Dante's psyche, nor is it about him going to prison and becoming emo. This game is a retelling of DMC. This time, instead of a castle filled with enemies that reek of Resident Evil, it's topped to the brim with color, personality, and attitude. Granted, that attitude is extremely childish and on-the-nose, but that adds to it's charm.This is the perfect game to turn your brain off to, plus a great action game to boot, but it's not a DMC game by any means. Vergil is there, Ebony and Ivory are there, and Rebellion is there, but this is no Devil May Cry. If you can get past that and take this game for the goofy, vibrant game that it is, then you'll have a blast.Oh, and it's a little easy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												There is no denying for the fact that the new Dante was not a well established protagonist. Although the developer Ninja Theory might slightly missed their aim for the moon, they definitely landed themselves among the stars. DMC : Devil May Cry is without doubt a game that has been well thought of from its mechanics, all the way to its overall design. This is a reboot done right.DMC : Devil May Cry lets you play as Dante, an angel and demon hybrid that lost his memories from early childhood and possesses the ability to travel in-between worlds called Limbo, a twisted alternatives of the real world. In this world, every secrets, lies and deceit of the powerful, evil (literally) bank CEO that controls the economy are exposed, but only Dante are able to see them. Experience as Dante teams up with a splinter group as they tries to send the devil back into corporate hell (literally. okay I should stop saying that).If the summary of the story sounds somewhat ridiculous to you, trust me when I say that the story was delivered flawlessly in the game. I do not know how the developers able to achieve it, but they did it.Review Summary -You should forgive this game for its :- Majority of the characters in the game are not likeable to some degree, but at least their motives are deep enough to give them a bit of character.- If you ended up hated listening to the new Dante when he is talking, you could always mute the sound. No big deal, come on.- PC controls can be difficult to master, but god bless the option to be able to remap the keys. So you could find the control sets that suits you.You should LOVE this game for its :- EXCELLENT FULL BODY MOCAP. The in game cinematics was well made, and the excellent mocap contributes a lot for its delivery in storytelling. Their facial expressions is extremely lifelike.- EXCELLENT GAMEPLAY AND COMBAT ANIMATIONS - Good job for Ninja Theory that chooses fully keyframed animations  just like the old DMC. Keyframed animations (compared to dynamic animations like Euphoria) allows for a very well translated moves, seeing Dante in combat has never been so realistic and believable. Every swing of Rebellion (the name of the sword) looks realistic and carries inertia with them.- WIDE RANGE OF ENEMY TYPES offers new challenges as you progressing further in the game, so there is no such thing as repetitive combat playstyles.- TRUE DIFFICULTY. Did you know, on higher difficulties, enemies and bosses not only react more quickly, but the also possesses new combat moves when attacking. This ultimately creates new experiences and rewards huge replay value for the players. Cool, right? Some developers went lazy in higher difficulty by raising ONLY the hit points and damage dealt upon the player. So job well done Ninja Theory.- A REBOOT DONE RIGHT. Ninja Theory is daring and strong enough to take this franchise to new directions. Without taking too much from the old material but only the amazing combat play, the developers has made a game worthy for a reboot. Ninja Theory does not rely on the power of nostalgia, but they believed that some originality will still appeal to most gamers out there, and they are right.The unforgiving thing about this :-The final boss fight is a huge disappointment. Enjoy the fight with regular enemies and early bosses as much as you can. Its a damn shame, the combat mechanics can be used exponentially, but they ended up as some gigantic fat♥♥♥♥♥blob for the final boss. urghh.- No DMC sequel. Are you kidding me capcom? Canned the sequel for a reboot? Because the sales did not met expectations? Thats a ♥♥♥♥♥ slap to the fans of the new reboot. Sorry boys.-The only bad thing about this game is only the characters. Thats unfortunate, but If you think you are going to dislike the reboot, there is always the old franchise for you to play. They're not yet extinct, people. There is a franchise for almost everybody out there.Final Verdict"DMC is a game that remains true to the core of classic hack and slash games, while offering new directions in storytelling and dynamic level designs. A game worthy for a reboot. 9/10."

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I wish I didn't like this game, but I can't. DmC is, for better or worse, a really very well done game. Thanks to its engine it enjoys amazing PC compatibility with amazing textures and graphical features, and an immense amount of controller compatibility extending beyond XInput and M/KB. The combat may be less accurate than other DmC's as there's a greater focus on crowd control and aerial combat, and a push for simplicity, but in the process they removed many of the risk/reward systems that flourished in earlier DmC's. The aggrotech soundtrack seems a risky move but pumps you almost as well as any industrial or metal soundtrack from any other game. The art design is peerless too, using bright lights and blue or red tints to highlight the feel of the world you're in.The only down points are the plot - typical ANONYMOOSE bull and a retread of They Live, but retooled for the Xbox-and-self-stimulation crowd and not the fans of DMC yore, the interactions between Dante and Vergil and the inevitable corny shi**y junk jokes, and Dante's failure one-liners.But I've sunk close to 40 hrs into this. For comparison, I've sunk 55 into DMC4 on the 360. So it must be doing something right.Get it if you're craving a different action game with an actually controllable camera (I'm looking at you, Revengeance).

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Okay, so here's the thing about DMC: Devil May Cry; it's not perfect. It's a re-telling of the 1st game, in a whole new light. It takes place in a world where Mundus has taken over all of humanity. He controls the population through the media, as well as other neferious means. Unlike other DMC-games, this one does not take place with an older, experienced, badass Dante. Instead, you take the role of a young, arrogant, and generally, even more immature than normal, black-haired Dante. The gameplay is without a doubt inferior to the fourth installment of the DMC-series. But that shouldn't be a deterrent as to whether or not you'll enjoy the game. I wasn't too thrilled when I saw the trailers for this, as I thought it would be a mediocre experience, but I was wrong, it was pretty awesome. The music is decent, albeit it's more of a techno-dub-steppy sort of music, rather than the usual heavy metal, but it's not half bad. All in all, the game is better than DMC 2, but no as good as DMC 4. Get a controller, because using a keyboard is nigh-impossible.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												I'll preface my review by saying that before this I had only ever played Devil May Cry 4, so I'm certainly not a long-time fan of the series, but I did play dmc4 pretty thoroughly. Anyway, on to the review! --Compared to Devil May Cry 4-- DmC: Devil May Cry reimagines the series from the bottom up, and essentially chronicles Dante's transformation from an edgy dude who can see demons and enjoys killing them when he finds them, but doesn't quite understand who he is, into the full-blown Nephelim badass who is now killing demons with understanding (perhaps that he's not just crazy?) and purpose. The game in a smaller part also basically tells the story of Vergil and Dante's relationship develops (I'll leave it at that), and how the world becomes a place where a demon hunter would be necessary. The story really doesn't take itself too seriously, for better or worse. Dante, especially during the earlier parts of the game, is an angsty hot-head, which definitely rubs many people the wrong way, but there's defenitely a level of character development that takes place in which he becomes more of the Dante I remember seeing in dmc4, both in attitude and appearance. I don't understand all of the hatred on Dante's look. Dante's hair starts turning white as he realizes his true potential, when he first starts devil triggering his hair starts turning white. Beat the game and you can play through with white hair. I personally thought this was a nice touch, as when you start the game Dante doesn't know that he isn't human, hasn't realized his demonic powers, etc.Gameplay is (in my opinion) far improved upon from devil may cry 4, there's about the same variety of combos and weapons (not including the variety presented by pandora) but the difference is in the ability to chain combos and attacks together between weapons. This was certainly possible before, but now it feels like almost every combo and attack can be chained together to create a lot of potential variety in how you approach each battle. Also, love them or hate them, this game has zero quick time events --As it's own game-- This has quickly become one of my favorite hack and slash games to date, the story has pretty consistently good voice acting (crazy from a Capcom game) and an entertaining story that's funny, full of over the top action and told well with the help of the aformentioned voice acting but also fairly organic movement and gestures from the characters within the game. The main game took me about 20 hours to beat playing on the hardest difficulty that you initially have unlocked, but I started a new game+ the second I beat it, and the next difficulty up gives all of the enemies new and remixed move sets that have kept the game fresh and have forced me to develop new strategies to deal with old enemies. All in all, I would highly recommend this game. Oop also I played with a controller, I don't know how the combat would be using mouse and keyboard, but I can imagine it wouldn't work as well.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Definitely my BEST BUY OF 2013. Would purchase at full price of $50. A must buy for 3D.Pros:*Superb soundtrack.*Actually, the soundtrack is brilliant. I don't even like the genre of music, but it just "fits". Perfectly.*Graphics that would make a PS4 blush. And go home to change its pants.*Amazing lighting effects.*Fast, fun melee fight centered gameplay.*Gratifying button mashing too -But not so fast that your fingers bleed.*Unintrusive, mature story. It's an RPG that grabs your attention, but mostly stays out of your way so you can enjoy playing. FYI, if you want to skip the cutscenes, simply hit the back button on your controller when they are playing. *Uncomparable experience in 3D. Even Batman didn't look or feel this good.Cons:*I feel remorseful for having got this game on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												This is my favorite brawler game I've ever played, hands down. Game is well developed and runs at very high frame rate with everything max'd out on my medium-spec laptop, and is absolutely gorgeous. Level design is unlike anything else, the map feels alive and responsive to your every move, seeking to find you and kill you. Enemies are relentless and well designed to challenge you. Through out the game you get several weapons that you replace on the fly with the d-pad, and each one has its own large set of skills and upgrades to train yourself through. The game rewards you for using style, and this is one of the first games I've played where it's actually fun to change up your style and try new ways to get through hordes on a map. The reboot is great, the story is fantastic for a brawler, and I'm excited for the sequel.

With various sick weapons you gather along the way you can use, there is a HUGE playground for combos and styles. I never stopped toying around with the different things you can come up with. No QTEs (Thank god), the bossfight are ♥♥♥♥ing badass. Period. As if the game is not hard enough for you... you have various modes, each taking more extreme hops in impossibility. (Highest mode: Dante Must Die mode, oh don't even start...)10/10Story:I may not have played the other DmC, but I have many cousins who are huge fans, therefore influence being indirect. Cannot say I dig the particular personality they stuck to the new Dante. (Pessimistic, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, failed attempt at swagger.) Storyline was mediocre. For this type of game, story isn't emphasized. But, it was good overall. 7/10Visuals:Very ecstatic. The world design they have done with Limbo is almost mesmerizing. Level design was also very good, pertaining to your regular action game genre expectations. With a little height of difficulty of course. (Getting around with the angel snitch and the demon pull sometimes) For the new decade, these graphics are very adequate.9/10Music:MMMMMMMMMM. HELL YES.10/10Overall: 9/10This game was awesome. Get it, unless you don't want to deal with the new Dante. (Justin Bieber look-alike?!?!)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
DmC: Devil May Cry suffered some hate even before launch because of its departure from previous DMC games. The combat is revamped and the protagonist is aged down and punked up (also people really seemed to care what color Dante's hair was. Because that really influences the game experience).DmC is a shining example of the hack-and-slash genre. The combat is complex, dividing attacks into three categories (standard, angelic, and demonic), but this organization makes it easy to master. The more you play, the more competent you become with the system and the more complex and satisfying the combos become. The story is a bit hit-or-miss, but honestly all Devil May Cry games have had lackluster stories. The ridiculousness of the series has been dampered, so you won't be skateboarding on demons and eating pizza with blades sticking out of you, and honestly it makes the game better for it. It's a much more serious take on what always should have been a serious game.Aside from combat, the soundtrack is the best part of the game. Noisia and Combichrist provide heart-pounding beats to compliment your demon crusade. The music is well integrated into the flow of combat but is also pleasant to listen to on its own.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												They clearly attempted to round up a new audience for this game. The Humor is even more  immature than in the older ones, and taken to gringy levels far beyond reason.The Game has plenty of bugs and glitches, and it's only few saving graces are pretty smooth animations and decent enough graphics. The Game also has minor performance issues. Fighting mechanics are incredibly generic: all the weapons are one and the same, and most things blocking you're path have a retundant replica of another weapon needed to open the path.  Most of the combat involves hitting the enemies with the correct type of weapon and... Well, that's it. That's all the combat is.Plot is like something out of a 10 year olds daydream. All in all, it's a pretty bad game since it doesen't do anything interesting, and it just lacks the feel of a DMC game. 5/10.I can't say I recommend this game to anyone...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												An above average hack 'n slash that was marketed so poorly that people thought it was an "edgy and gritty" game that had a message, which resulted in horrible sales and a permanent stain on what should have been another high note in one of the most original series of our time.DMC: Devil May Cry is not a grimdark trek through Dante's psyche, nor is it about him going to prison and becoming emo. This game is a retelling of DMC. This time, instead of a castle filled with enemies that reek of Resident Evil, it's topped to the brim with color, personality, and attitude. Granted, that attitude is extremely childish and on-the-nose, but that adds to it's charm.This is the perfect game to turn your brain off to, plus a great action game to boot, but it's not a DMC game by any means. Vergil is there, Ebony and Ivory are there, and Rebellion is there, but this is no Devil May Cry. If you can get past that and take this game for the goofy, vibrant game that it is, then you'll have a blast.Oh, and it's a little easy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2013
												It's worth noting here that I can't speak to difficulty. I'm not good at fighting games, and that seems to translate here. i played this on 'Human' difficulty, and still had a few deaths. This is also my first DMC, so I can't speak to the fans of the series, just to people who like good games. This is a good game.The plot is definitely 'B' rank, but it's the good sort of 'B', Army of Darkness sort of thing. (Actually, it's probably less silly.)I enjoyed the fighting, even if I can't combo to save my life, and the system felt very well done. There was a nice variety of enemies, so you can't just use the same attack over and over and have it work well. There is also plenty of replayability, between the collectables, challenges, and trying to get a better rank for the levels. There's a decent upgrade system too, so you can get more out of the weapons you enjoy, but it's nowhere near deep enough to even say 'RPG elements' I should also mention, the visuals are great. Lots of weird and interesting areas to fight in, and they all look pretty damn good. My issues with the game: The majority of the boss fights sucked. They were about a 6 on a scale that goes from 1 to Deus Ex: HR. "Dodge this annoying and lengthy attack pattern! Now hit the obvious weak spot! Lather! Rinse! Repeat!"Also, I had some weird pauses in the game. My system can handle games pretty well, so I'm not sure what was causing them, but I kept having the whole game freeze for a few seconds in the middle of battles or platforming (which is not a fun place for that to happen). Dunno if this was my fault or if the game's buggy, but there you go.oh, and here's a hint: Eryx uppercuts on the Dreamwalkers. Those guys can go to hell. Uh, pun not intended.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Overall this is a great game.  I bought it for $20 on sale and it is very much worth that.  I don't know if I would pay a full $50 for it but I am a brok grad student so to each there own.  Here are my pros and cons and odds.Pros-Awsome combo system.  It is not overly complex but it lends it self well to being able to do easy combos very early on and letting you make your own combos later by builing off of the fast past combat.-Great story.  The story isn't very complicated but it is fun and well done, adding to this really awesome cut scenes and good transition from cut scenes to action and its a major boon to this game-7 difficulty settings.  If you aren't good at these types of games that's OK set it on the lowest and you will learn and progress fine, if you are awesome at them you can unlock difficulties that boggle the mind.-Fights are lots of fun and there are many ways to win.  They tend to go with large amounts of enemies over one mini boss type almost all the time.  Usually when you are fighting only one enemies it is the first time you have scene it and the game is giving you a chance to get you strategy down about it which leads to-Good difficulty progression, this game gets much harder as it progresses but it prepares you for it so you never feel like "where the hell did that come from"-Lots of fun weapons and powers-Fun jumping puzzles-Great level design, there fun, have environmental factors that hurt you and the enemies, hard to get lost in and are aesthetic pleasingCons-Not fun jumping puzzles (seriously some are great some are terrible)-The camera angles hate you, its not game breaking but it is annoying.  The camera tries to center it self to whatever it thinks you are attacking and while it usually does a fine job when it doesn't its pretty bad-One of the main way it hides collectibles is via the camera automatically turning in a way you don't see it, this leads to forcing the camera to do things it doesn't want to often which wouldn't be bad except how many collectibles you get and how long it takes you affects your xp-You can't get all the collectibles on the first run through.  Its not that as a human you will miss some its that they will require abilities you cannot posses yet.  This isn't bad exactly but it leads to trying to get something till you get frustrated and move on only to realize that when you go back to the level later its not even a challenge to collect it.-Short, took me about 8 hours, would have been 7 if I didn't constantly force the camera to odd places.  This game assumes you will replay it.Odd-The boss fights are the easiest levels.  There not bad they just follow a much slower progression.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												DMC: Devil May Cry is a reboot of the old Devil May Cry series. Lots of controversy has been had over Dante's new look, but I personally never really cared since I have never played any other DMC game (even though I eventually planned to since the  Spectacle fighter sub-genre is my favorite game genre). Now this game is a very fun spectacle fighter that lasts about 8-10 hours with the Vergil DLC adding another hour or two. Now the story in this game isnt very strong, but it is good enough to keep you invested. The combat in this game is amazing and very different to that of other spectacle fighters like Ninja Gaiden or God of War. You can switch weapons mid swing from a sword to an axe to a scythe. There are a total of 8 weapons and they are all very fun to use. The bosses are also a ton of fun to fight and can give you a challenge, especially the final boss. In my opinion the final boss in this game is one of the best final bosses in any game I've played so far. He legitimately feels like you equal and the area around you changes as you fight him and he is not easy, but not hard either. More games should take notes and make bosses more like DMC's final boss. Overall this game gets a 9/10 and is very fun and the story is decent and I highly recommend you play it if you like hack and slash games.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												DMC Fan through and through.Check my Steam.  DMC3. DMC4, DMC4:SE  DmC:DmCPlayed the orginal on PS2, and even played the 2nd game which we shall never speak of.I cannot begin to explain how good of a game this really is.  To Start the theme.  An american city, A demon lord that has more less taken over the world.  This of course cannot be the same games as the previous ones.  While the orginals are amazing.  This game too is amazing for the evenviorment that it is set in.  This refreashing twist to DmC could make for a great duel layer franchise, as well as reboots of plenty of characters.  Which I would find interesting.Does this game give you the standard hack and slash of the other Devil may cry games?  NONow, Hold that thought.  Many of the enemys in this one are more of a tactical thing.  Dodging, Avoiding, Smashing.  Not the normal, Oh look they have that purble haze on them, better hit them with strong attack.  The controls are just as roubust as the old games.  Rather then using the triggers scroll though weapons it activates your angelic and demonic weapons.  I found myself switching through various weapons causing massive mayham just as I would with other games.So is this a real DMC game?  To me, yes.  Buy it, Play it, Kill everything.  Trust me.......... It is worth it.  Just remove the old storys from you minds and go with the flow.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Wow! I really wanted to be able to sit here and say that I loved this game. Having not played other games in the series I was not blinded by nostalgia or a bias for the older versions of the characters, and I genuinly found it, as a property in its own right, to have characters and plot that, whilst not original, was developed well enough and satisfying and I genuinly looked forward to coming back and seeing what would happen to them next. The combat was fun and surprisingly deep and challenging and I enjoyed all the weapons and combos and unlocking new abilities.The enemies are well designed for the most part, varied, interesting, and exciting to fight. Some are better than others, of course, but by all counts its a solid show. The exception are the boss fights, where both design and mechanics are sadly incredibly tired and cliched for the most part with only a couple of exceptions.The level designs are pretty standout, with amazing skyboxes and interesting secret areas and agility trials. There are not really enough puzzles for my taste, but oh well. That is not a big thing really. There are a couple of very memorable levels, including one in the opening sequence of a TV News programme, and that was clever and appropriate, and original too. Unfortunately I don't think enough was done with it really. The graphics are good, considering, although the textures do sometimes take a long time to load, especially in cut scenes (and this is running on a machine at least three times as powerful as it needs to be).Now we get to the big point...the negative...the thing that ruined the whole deal for me...the one issue, so large, that it singlehandedly earned the game this negative review and my undying hatred after a considerable amount of swearing.The final, piece of a*** bossfight.It started off interesting enough. For the record, to challenge the fanboy morons who would say "You just cannot play the game", I lost less than a quarter health before I got to the final, last stand, part of the boss' routine. So clearly I can manage well enough. This last stand consists of summoning a double who defends from all attacks. The boss is crouching, healing, and is totally untouchable due to their double's defence and attacks. I expended all my healing and regeneration items on trying to figure out the secret, only to have to reload. And guess what. Your items do not reload with you. What kind of shoddy, dreadful, gut-wrenching design is that! But I managed. But I could not figure out the secret. I was getting really cross and fed up with this lazy repetitive nonsense, and I finally broke my sacred rule and looked up a walkthrough.The secret? A contrived use of an ability that, at no point before, had been used for this use, nor said to be useful for this use, nor hinted at in the bossfight. I would NEVER have worked that out on my own, and perhaps that makes me thick, but I maintain it is lazy and shoddy game design to introduce a new gameplay mechanic, which in essence it is, in the last boss fight as the only way to make it tough, because otherwise it was not.And even WITH that advice, it was a matter of sheer luck as to whether or not the ability, which requires items or grinding attacks to build up to a useable level, would actually perform as needed when activated and drained far too fast!I cannot begin to describe the amount of bad language I used and how close I came to rage quitting, which is rare for me. Every example of poor design in a boss fight is present in this final, extrenuous encounter.And if that wasn't bad enough, the ending afterwards was not even worth the effort.I am genuinly upset that I cannot recommend this game, but it would be hypocritical of me to recommend a game with so many flaws even in just one fight that I would crucify any other game on.Disagree with me if you want. Say I cannot play it if you want. I can play it. I did play it. I was playing it on medium difficulty (ok, so not the toughest, but it wasn't the easiest either!) and I managed to achieve a lot of high scores in other levels and as I said I did really well to begin with against this final boss and did not find it hard to hit them, dodge their attacks, or otherwise fight them. It was purely this execrably poor mechanic that foiled me, and at the same time sapped all my goodwill for an otherwise enjoyable game. Play it, don't play - it is your choice. It has its fun moments, but the plot ended up lamely and the final boss fight was a joke of bad design. I would recommend DANTE'S INFERNO as a game before this!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Let me just start this by saying: I'm having fun with this game. Well, I was, anyway. The system requirements are questionable as to whether they'll get you a working 640x480 or a stuttering mess at times. The game can be cheap as hell. It requiring fine responses from you but it can be a flip of a coin at times whether it will accept important dodge moves or just ignore them. Hit detection can be all over the place, with a chainsaw holding enemy managing to hit without their weapon making contact, or miss while the chainsaw goes through Dante. The level design can be confusing, with times all I could think was "What do you want from me?" as I try to determine where the next neatly disguised platform has been hidden, resulting in not even realising which order the game was after. The method of accessing platforms (one grappling hook for pulling them out, one for pulling Dante to them) seems confusing as to when it will decide to acknowledge Dante is in a suitable place. And the sections where Dante has to outrun walls closing in can be nightmarish in its' ignoring attempts to jump and furthering the need for good reaction times. The end result is a game that takes your health for its' inability to follow through on jumping (a fall "off the map" costs Dante health) and dodging, then penalises you for using items to heal that health. A game that confuses with poorly designed platforming sections and things to hit on the wall, then takes away score for taking a while to work out what comes next. A game that makes some enemies a chore (the afforementioned chainsaw weilding ones, anything in the air that requires a lock on that ends with the game focusing Dante on the wrong enemies), then you lose score if you shoot at them because it's the only way the game won't play cheap and steal health and cause frustration through making it far more dangerous to Dante's health than actually fighting against them would be without all the issues mentioned here. That's saying nothing for the maybe 15 frames per second I'm getting or the 5 seconds where the game will just stop in some areas (I think when it's trying to do pop-in of partially transparent character models in a wide space), including during battle.The game can be fun, at times. It's a lot more whimsical than previous entries and feels more enjoyable (as someone who has played previous Devil May Cry games), with a plot that helps keep up the interest. But it's getting more of a chore than it may be worth for me now, what with the unfair mess it has turned into.Not recommended.(game played with Xbox 360 wireless controller, computer meets and/or exceeds system requirements)

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												The game is pretty good for the first 9 levels, but when you hit the 10th you end up fighting game mechanics instead of enemies.  Just trying to get to the tower sees the camera getting fixed at a weird angle about midway through making falling highly likely requiring you to start over.  Fighting the boss sees more issues with screwed up camera angles that leave you fighting the mechanics to even get to the crystals you need to break instead of fighting the boss or evading his attacks.You'll also never get full completion without going back to replay earlier missions over again once you have the right tools.  In mission 9 you'll never complete it without going through the mission multiple times as you need the gold key and the only way to get it is during a fight by using the enemies to help get you to the upper ledge.The story is intriguing, so it's a real shame the developers decided it would be a good idea to have the player fight the game mechanics--a real no-no in game design.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												DmC is not a bad game. Its got great graphics, good music, well done voice acting, and smooth gameplay. So why am I not recommending it? For a couple reasons.1. Super repetitive. Everything from the areas you are in, to the challenges you must do, to the fights, and overall graphics. Oh look, its another part of the city thats getting mutated into a chaos realm. Joy. Hardly any variation. Levels in this game are what those special "Artistic" levels in other games do as that one time side mission. Only, these are EVERY part of the game. The gameplay in each is always the same too, with the game going through the same sets of scripted events over and over again. "Oh, think you made it to the end of the level, NOPE, here are more enemies, or here's a roadblock that suddenly forms causing you to find another way." Rinse, repeat. I kept hoping for even one level that didnt have that "you've done way too many drugs" look to it, and it hasnt yet happened. Overall, just playing through these levels and the gameplay, is dull.2. Too many combos. Sounds silly right? There comes a point when the 8+ buttons your fingers have to manage on a controller have surpassed the insane when it comes to various combinations they must learn and use. Its good for a game to have combos. Games like God of War showed this, Combos gives you that extra bit of exciting "oomph" to combat beyond bland button mashing. However, this game goes to the extreme with the amount of buton combinations you have to use, enough to tie your fingers in knots. It then scores you based on how many of these seemingly infinite combos you can do. The irony is, many of the enemies DIE before you can manage to do enough combos to often get a good combo rating.  This game is litterally like "Twister" for your fingers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												DMC: Devil May Cry is the fifth part of the entire series of Devil May Cry. Being the latest of all, the graphics, gameplay and the sound quality is naturally far superior than its predecessors. This is the first time I played a DMC, and I am awed with it. I can write a thousand enthusiastic lines that will flatter the game throughout; that's not at all why I am writing this. What has really surprised me is the HATE that this piece of art is facing from the fans of its predecessors. Comparisons have arose particularly from the 3rd and 4th part players. They have simply fallen in love with the characters and its the CHARACTERS of the game that really interests them, nothing else. Though I didn't play its predecessors but I watched the walkthroughs of all of them. My conclusion: every game has its own unique features that makes it popular,for this one they are :-1. THE COMBAT.2. THE MUSIC.3. THE WEAPONS RANGE (8 in numbers).People are going far enough asking to play M**** G*** R***** while these two are completely different; not to mention that it also requires a very high end PC and quite a few bucks to fulfill their choice. For the Predecessor Fans (P Fans), my only request is please find a person who has:-1. played the latest DMC first in the whole series,2. hated it,3. purchased any of its prefecessors, and4. prefers it over the latest version.Also to add, there are tons of fans who, though played the prequels, didn't hold back to say that this one quite impressed them.This game is a masterpiece at a modest price requiring almost a moderate specification to help it run and guarantees satisfaction at least for a few months. All the hack and slash games really fade out in comparison to this.To come accross such a fluid stylish gameplay, this is certainly staying in my PC forever. For people who have not yet played this game, it will surely quench your thirst.Can't wait for the Sequel.Warning : YOU WILL PLAY THIS GAME AGAIN & AGAIN & AGAIN...

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Overrated.  The game starts out with BOOM! and grabs your attention with arresting visual style, great graphics and cool take on the DmC universe.  Unfortunately, the game slowly layers more and more complexity onto the proceedings until it's a giant muddle of "hold this button while pushing this other button while holding the stick up to do so-and-so".  The combat becomes tedious because enemies further along in the game can only be dealt with effectively using certain pre-ordained moves, which eliminates your license as a player and makes the game inflexible and repetitive.  While the ideas of demons running the world's companies and media outlets, etc. is intrigueing, the game is often crass and tasteless for no reason at all.  The death metal soundtrack, while appropriate, becomes grating after awhile also.  In short, it's fun until about halfway through when you say "enough is enough".

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												The story sucks and a completely plagiarized hack job at that. If you watched 'They Live' you don't have to experience the drivel this game provides. There is no message in the satire. All the characters in the story bore me to tears. The supporting cast spout nothing but exposition and add very little to the narrative. Dante and Vergil are as interesting as a moldy peanuts. Dante feels like a Justin Bieber knock off and has as much charisma. Vergil is a massive D-bag and that's about for him. The only thing good about the story is the chemistry between Kat and Dante, but their relationship is left unresolved.The gameplay is neutered beyond belief.The style points is given so generously that a random button mash can get S rankings and above.The lack of a Style-system means Dante's move set is also streamlined. Theoretically allowing smoother, flashier combos. Realistically, it means the skill ceiling/ skill floor is so low that you can find everything you can do in the game very quickly. Resulting a game that has nothing new to offer once you finish the campaign.You can no longer lock on to an enemy so making the camera focus on a certain target is more difficult then it should be. (trivial for keyboard and mouse users, annoying for gamepad users)The boss fights are pathetic and the difficulty curve might as well be a Jackson Pollock painting.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Where to begin? It's a decent game, but not one that belongs in the Devil May Cry universe. it has anice aesthetic but that's about it. The story is somewhat of a carbon coby from DCM3, which is imo a much much better game.The combatd is flawed, too slow, and you can't combo because there are color coded enemies on which only 1 of your weapons will work, so a scoring a long combo to get points is out of the question, not that it matters anyway.The combat "style" meter you see, is tied to how much damage you do and really easy to maintain. There's no challenge in it what so ever and makes the game uber easy. Alsotaking hints from GoW, your weapons range goes accros the screen. This is not how DMC should be.Devil trigger is absolutely useless because for some reason it launches all your enemies in the air. It's forcing you to go aerial, which is neat, but in other DMC games you had the CHOICE to do that and i was not a thing forcibly pushing mechanics.ALso where other DMC guys are riddled which exceptionally well designed boss battles, this one has only ONE memorable one, the bob bardas fight, and even that is way too easy.Conclusion: the levels and general aestethic look really nice, but it's gameplay that this game is lacking, a game needs more then just eyecandy to be good. It's like all other Ninja Theory games: they show promise but it's that "Almost good, but not quite there yet" why their games are so mediocre.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I remember being pretty upset when this game came out, I hated the design choices, the dumbing down of the game, and all the other changes. I finally did pick up the game for $7.50, and I have to say, it's really good. I'll break everything down:The gameplay: Despite dumbed down, the gameplay is very fun. Everything feels really polished and smooth, and still allows you to do really cool looking combos, but it is a lot easier and feels less rewarding.  This really isn't that much of a deal, as it is nice to just sit back, and enjoy a game casually. The boss fights are fantastic, each feel really creative and intense, but lack depth, and are pretty easy.  This game also features a little bit of 3D platforming, while it is very simple and does a lot of hand holding, it still looks pretty cool, and isn't terrible. The level design is really good, but it gets al little annoying towards the end, but some levels just are pure magic in this game, fitting the syle of the game, and accommodating for fighting excellently The gameplay is definitely really good though, everything feels great, despite being a lot simpler.The graphics/aesthetic: The game has a very flashy, bright, and hyperactive style to it, kind of like it was designed by someone with ADD. Don't view that as a bad thing, because the art style works really well for this type of game. The way the environments contort and change, is incredible, it's easily the best part about the game visually, it's some really impressive stuff. The one thing I was on the fence about, was the design of Dante. His design isn't super great, there's just something off about his appearance in the game, but this can be easily changed by getting the costume pack and using the classic Dante skin, it makes him look much better.The writing: This is definitely the weakest point of any hack and slash game, but I have to say, it's not bad in this. The story is okay, it works, and I was intrigued. The one liners are okay, they're certainly not as intelligent, but I liked them. The dialogue is a little weak though, some exchanges between characters feel awkward and forced. It's okay most of the time, but sometimes it can get pretty bad.The music: While all the previous games did a more instrumental type of metal, DMC: Devil May Cry, went more a much more electronic metal. It's great, but it fits the style of the game, and does its job. I didn't mind it, but it can feel a little overbearing at times, and tries a little to hard to be edgy.DMC: Devil May Cry may have a dumb title, and a few issues, but if you're looking to have some classic hack and slash action, and not much of a challenge, I'd definitely recommend this game. It's really good, and while I don't agree with some design choices, I had a fantastic time playing this game, it's just so good.

												This isnt as deep or long an experience as even DMC4, but it's a decent beat-em-up. Its not terribly difficult at the highest initially unlocked difficulty and the story isn't all that engaging. It looks okay, but is by no means the best looking or ugliest game out there.They tried way too hard to make Dante be an aloof jackass-turned-caring good guy, but the game wasn't long enough to allow you to care all that much.Despite all that, I enjoyed it for what it was worth. I don't think the gameplay could sustain my interest for much longer than it did, so the timing of the ending was very good, it did no overstay its welcome just in order to be longer. I'd say only buy this at a $10 or lower pricepoint.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Where to begin? It's a decent game, but not one that belongs in the Devil May Cry universe. it has anice aesthetic but that's about it. The story is somewhat of a carbon coby from DCM3, which is imo a much much better game.The combatd is flawed, too slow, and you can't combo because there are color coded enemies on which only 1 of your weapons will work, so a scoring a long combo to get points is out of the question, not that it matters anyway.The combat "style" meter you see, is tied to how much damage you do and really easy to maintain. There's no challenge in it what so ever and makes the game uber easy. Alsotaking hints from GoW, your weapons range goes accros the screen. This is not how DMC should be.Devil trigger is absolutely useless because for some reason it launches all your enemies in the air. It's forcing you to go aerial, which is neat, but in other DMC games you had the CHOICE to do that and i was not a thing forcibly pushing mechanics.ALso where other DMC guys are riddled which exceptionally well designed boss battles, this one has only ONE memorable one, the bob bardas fight, and even that is way too easy.Conclusion: the levels and general aestethic look really nice, but it's gameplay that this game is lacking, a game needs more then just eyecandy to be good. It's like all other Ninja Theory games: they show promise but it's that "Almost good, but not quite there yet" why their games are so mediocre.
