number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
ProsGameplayMusic is really, really great and totally fits the actionDialog can be fantastic at timesColorful scenariosCharacter's style: From Dante to the bosses, pretty much all characters look really stylish and greatTons of combos to perform, if you account all the different weaponsConsLow variety of enemies: there are lots of reskins with different characteristics and thats it, I guessGraphicsThe world looks gorgeous and colorful even though you mainly play in the Limbo, which is a similar world to the real world, just more red-ish coloredThe characters look fantastic. TBH I wasn't even a fan of how Dante looked before I played and always felt CAPCOM tried to make him look as edgy as possible but honestly, pretty soon into the game, you'll feel that Dante looks really badass and his looks really fit himMOCAP was greatly usedGameplayAlright, so this is pretty much a DMC gameplay mechanics, if you're already familiarized with them. If not, you can expect a pretty much flawless gameplay for this kind of game, only second to (IMO) BayonettaYou get quite a few weapons but the thing I felt was that the ones you unlock later tend to be better AND cooler. Maybe it just fit my playstyle but I prefered those ones. You'll still need to use the ones you unlocked first in some areas thoughOverall you can expect a very, very solid gameplay with tons of combos and with each weapon feeling quite unique in gameplay. Maybe the best DMC game gameplay-wiseAudioFantastic, fantastic OST. Perfect for DMCI loved some of the dialogs, specially one with a boss. The voiceovers are very good and, again, Dante is a really cocky badass. Fits the character's age very wellFinal ThoughtsKinda jumped into the game not so sure with Dante's edgy looks but was blown away with how great CAPCOM made him look, speak and act. A very pleasant surprise.The pace of the game is high, the gameplay is pretty much flawless with the tools and mobility Dante has and it and it's just a blast to play. You'll have a great time!Rock solid game and probably my favourite DMC.Higly recommended!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Let me just start this by saying: I'm having fun with this game. Well, I was, anyway. The system requirements are questionable as to whether they'll get you a working 640x480 or a stuttering mess at times. The game can be cheap as hell. It requiring fine responses from you but it can be a flip of a coin at times whether it will accept important dodge moves or just ignore them. Hit detection can be all over the place, with a chainsaw holding enemy managing to hit without their weapon making contact, or miss while the chainsaw goes through Dante. The level design can be confusing, with times all I could think was "What do you want from me?" as I try to determine where the next neatly disguised platform has been hidden, resulting in not even realising which order the game was after. The method of accessing platforms (one grappling hook for pulling them out, one for pulling Dante to them) seems confusing as to when it will decide to acknowledge Dante is in a suitable place. And the sections where Dante has to outrun walls closing in can be nightmarish in its' ignoring attempts to jump and furthering the need for good reaction times. The end result is a game that takes your health for its' inability to follow through on jumping (a fall "off the map" costs Dante health) and dodging, then penalises you for using items to heal that health. A game that confuses with poorly designed platforming sections and things to hit on the wall, then takes away score for taking a while to work out what comes next. A game that makes some enemies a chore (the afforementioned chainsaw weilding ones, anything in the air that requires a lock on that ends with the game focusing Dante on the wrong enemies), then you lose score if you shoot at them because it's the only way the game won't play cheap and steal health and cause frustration through making it far more dangerous to Dante's health than actually fighting against them would be without all the issues mentioned here. That's saying nothing for the maybe 15 frames per second I'm getting or the 5 seconds where the game will just stop in some areas (I think when it's trying to do pop-in of partially transparent character models in a wide space), including during battle.The game can be fun, at times. It's a lot more whimsical than previous entries and feels more enjoyable (as someone who has played previous Devil May Cry games), with a plot that helps keep up the interest. But it's getting more of a chore than it may be worth for me now, what with the unfair mess it has turned into.Not recommended.(game played with Xbox 360 wireless controller, computer meets and/or exceeds system requirements)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												DmC: Devil May Cry, the "reboot" of the original Devil May Cry games set in a more contemporary setting.Just a basic run-down of my relationship with the franchise and with this game:I've played DMC2 and 3 to completion and only bits and pieces of DMC4. As for this game, I got it for 9$ as part of a Humble Bundle and personally that's the only way I'd be able to recommend this game to anybody, at the time of me writing this, I have 7 hours on the game. A little less than 6 of those hours were a complete playthrough of the game on Demon Hunter (Normal) and the rest were me being afk so needless to say I stand to give a review of the game. As for Pros and Cons,Pros:-The Combat System feels great as it should in a hack and slash type game, it seems that even though the game was made by a different studio than normal, they definitely captured the Devil May Cry feel in the gameplay.-The music is amazing, extremely blood pumping, encouraging players to want to do better in the game and overall makes combat 10x more enjoyable.-Tons of replayablity with numerous collectables, unlockables, and the variety of difficulty settings going all the way to "Hell to Hell" mode where Dante dies in one hit but everybody else is significantly stronger.-Great Social CommentaryCons:-The story is trash, even by Devil May Cry standards. I totally understand that they were trying to make the story more "modern" if that makes any sense, but they blew it, big time. One of the more popular reviews on Steam explains it beautifully:"The story of a man and his brother who dream of destroying Mountain Dew and Fox News just so they can kill the owner of Bank of America." -stikasThat's the whole story, take it or leave it.- The game really cheaply tries to force players to use/mix up their combos by incorporating the other weapons. This is a bit of a tough one to explain because you really have to play the game to comprehend how bad a solid half of the weapons are, yet they still try to force you to use them. "Dante" (I use that name VERY loosely) has 9 weapons he can use, only about 4 of them are actually useful.Rebellion, the default sword, Eryx the second demon weapon you get (huge fists), Aquila, the second angel weapon you get (some glave shuriken type things... they just stun people), and Kablooey, the third gun you get toward the end game (stops enrage). Idk where I'm going with this, but if you buy the game for whatever reason, trust me you'll agree with me- The characters (Dante and Vergil) and watered down hollow shells of their former selves. To put it bluntly, Dante is an annoying prick that's gotta make a stupid remark about everything, now that's pretty much the old Dante, except imagine if it was a 7 year old and his vast vocabulary doing it. Vergil on the other hand is pretty close to the original, except for the fact that he throws honor completely out the window and just does what he wants.- Boss Battles are lackluster, idk what more I need to say.In Conclusion, the only way I can possibly recommend this game is if you get it on sale or part of a bundle, as there are plenty of other hack and slashes (like the original games) that do what DmC: Devil May Cry does, but extremely better.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												The game is pretty good for the first 9 levels, but when you hit the 10th you end up fighting game mechanics instead of enemies.  Just trying to get to the tower sees the camera getting fixed at a weird angle about midway through making falling highly likely requiring you to start over.  Fighting the boss sees more issues with screwed up camera angles that leave you fighting the mechanics to even get to the crystals you need to break instead of fighting the boss or evading his attacks.You'll also never get full completion without going back to replay earlier missions over again once you have the right tools.  In mission 9 you'll never complete it without going through the mission multiple times as you need the gold key and the only way to get it is during a fight by using the enemies to help get you to the upper ledge.The story is intriguing, so it's a real shame the developers decided it would be a good idea to have the player fight the game mechanics--a real no-no in game design.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												DMC: Devil May Cry is the fifth part of the entire series of Devil May Cry. Being the latest of all, the graphics, gameplay and the sound quality is naturally far superior than its predecessors. This is the first time I played a DMC, and I am awed with it. I can write a thousand enthusiastic lines that will flatter the game throughout; that's not at all why I am writing this. What has really surprised me is the HATE that this piece of art is facing from the fans of its predecessors. Comparisons have arose particularly from the 3rd and 4th part players. They have simply fallen in love with the characters and its the CHARACTERS of the game that really interests them, nothing else. Though I didn't play its predecessors but I watched the walkthroughs of all of them. My conclusion: every game has its own unique features that makes it popular,for this one they are :-1. THE COMBAT.2. THE MUSIC.3. THE WEAPONS RANGE (8 in numbers).People are going far enough asking to play M**** G*** R***** while these two are completely different; not to mention that it also requires a very high end PC and quite a few bucks to fulfill their choice. For the Predecessor Fans (P Fans), my only request is please find a person who has:-1. played the latest DMC first in the whole series,2. hated it,3. purchased any of its prefecessors, and4. prefers it over the latest version.Also to add, there are tons of fans who, though played the prequels, didn't hold back to say that this one quite impressed them.This game is a masterpiece at a modest price requiring almost a moderate specification to help it run and guarantees satisfaction at least for a few months. All the hack and slash games really fade out in comparison to this.To come accross such a fluid stylish gameplay, this is certainly staying in my PC forever. For people who have not yet played this game, it will surely quench your thirst.Can't wait for the Sequel.Warning : YOU WILL PLAY THIS GAME AGAIN & AGAIN & AGAIN...

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I wish I didn't like this game, but I can't. DmC is, for better or worse, a really very well done game. Thanks to its engine it enjoys amazing PC compatibility with amazing textures and graphical features, and an immense amount of controller compatibility extending beyond XInput and M/KB. The combat may be less accurate than other DmC's as there's a greater focus on crowd control and aerial combat, and a push for simplicity, but in the process they removed many of the risk/reward systems that flourished in earlier DmC's. The aggrotech soundtrack seems a risky move but pumps you almost as well as any industrial or metal soundtrack from any other game. The art design is peerless too, using bright lights and blue or red tints to highlight the feel of the world you're in.The only down points are the plot - typical ANONYMOOSE bull and a retread of They Live, but retooled for the Xbox-and-self-stimulation crowd and not the fans of DMC yore, the interactions between Dante and Vergil and the inevitable corny shi**y junk jokes, and Dante's failure one-liners.But I've sunk close to 40 hrs into this. For comparison, I've sunk 55 into DMC4 on the 360. So it must be doing something right.Get it if you're craving a different action game with an actually controllable camera (I'm looking at you, Revengeance).

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												I wish I didn't like this game, but I can't. DmC is, for better or worse, a really very well done game. Thanks to its engine it enjoys amazing PC compatibility with amazing textures and graphical features, and an immense amount of controller compatibility extending beyond XInput and M/KB. The combat may be less accurate than other DmC's as there's a greater focus on crowd control and aerial combat, and a push for simplicity, but in the process they removed many of the risk/reward systems that flourished in earlier DmC's. The aggrotech soundtrack seems a risky move but pumps you almost as well as any industrial or metal soundtrack from any other game. The art design is peerless too, using bright lights and blue or red tints to highlight the feel of the world you're in.The only down points are the plot - typical ANONYMOOSE bull and a retread of They Live, but retooled for the Xbox-and-self-stimulation crowd and not the fans of DMC yore, the interactions between Dante and Vergil and the inevitable corny shi**y junk jokes, and Dante's failure one-liners.But I've sunk close to 40 hrs into this. For comparison, I've sunk 55 into DMC4 on the 360. So it must be doing something right.Get it if you're craving a different action game with an actually controllable camera (I'm looking at you, Revengeance).

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I already played DmC: Devil May Cry on consoles, so this review is coming from someone who knows the difference between both that version and the PC version. I'm also a DMC veteran who has played all the previous DMC games.The PC version definitely benefits alot as far as ports of fast action games go. Meaning that you get the 60 FPS gameplay that previous DMC games hold up for the more dexterous veterans. If nothing else, the Unreal Engine 3 visuals on PC still hold up nicely.However, few pre-rendered cutscenes will feel jarring to look at. Gameplay-wise, I still have an issue with the dumbed down Style Ranking and the red/blue enemies that force me to use only Angel/Demon weapons. If you're just in this visuals and spectacle, this game is worth checking out.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												In one sentence : they noobified the series.The new controls are not that bad, it's more fluid than the original and you can have multiple weapons to use at the same time, but they removed the targetting system and this makes the game a mess when you are fighting many enemies and you won't attack the one you want to. The stylish points are not awarded properly, you just need to do a lot of damage and you will get top score, this happens even at the hardest difficulty and makes the game too easy. The story tries to be different and it's ok if it isn't for the fact that has nothing to do with devil may cry, they just took the characters from the original series, made them look similar, gave them completely different personalities and made a complete different story, sorry, this is not how you do a reboot.The new Dante is a really badly characterised character, it wants to be cool and edgy, but it's never a badass, and that's all the original Dante needed to be. Too many scripts during the levels and the platform sections become boring after a while.I cannot recomend this over the classics, get devil may cry 4 on steam, it's great, this one is not.

												First, I won't call this a port since realease date is nearly the same with PS3/X360 version.It was built from Unreal Engine 3, which is (I think) very lightweight even for my old laptop (i3 2.33GHz, 4GBs RAM, nVIDIA 520MX 1GB).- Great controller support, I recommend using x360ce for the best performance on any gamepads.- I haven't played any DMC games before, so this one for me is a blast. Various combo styles and significant number of weapons.- Newbie-friendly. Why? The game saves itself in certain checkpoints, the story is divided into 20 chapters. If you completed the game and want to play it again, you can choose which chapter to do so within main menu.- Badass characters.- High replay value.- You should get Vergil's Downfall too. Very good DLC at a so-so price.Well, that's it. The only downside is that there're not many options for graphic and sound.

												Never before have I played a game where I actively hated every single character in it with such passion.  While the core gameplay may be good, the context in which it was delivered was so soul-wrechingly awful that I had to ignore it.  I got this game during the CAPCOM anniversary sale, and it was the worst thing I've ever spent $12 on that didn't give me a venerial disease.If you think that My Chemical Romance is the epitome of thrash metal, or are sixteen years old, or have a psychological disorder  that makes you unable to feel basic human emotions such as rage, you may be immune to this garbage.There are not enough words in the English language to describe how truly, truly awful the script and characters in DMC are.  I want to punch the faces of every single person on the writing team.  The writng for this game reads like Japanese "visual kei" artist Gackt squatted over a stack of Twilight fan fiction and let loose the most horrific, vile, psyche-destroying diarrhea ever known to man.  If this game had a smell, it would be that of a rotten egg stuffed inside a dead cat's♥♥♥♥♥♥  If it were an ice cream flavor, it would be "poop."Mild recommendation to avoid.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Remember when combos required stringing moves together, juggling enemies, and employing every move in your arsenal? This game doesn't. Red and blue enemies are a cheap way of forcing you to only use half of your moves, and there is no combo timer. That's right! You can hit an enemy, run and hide in a corner for two hours, then hit him again, and it counts as a combo as long as you didn't get hit in between. This renders the whole combo system refined throughout the series pointless, and rewards slow methodical gameplay in a fast paced action game. Moreover, the developer said he redesigned Dante because the old one "would get laughed out of modern bars". What, he thinks edgelord the steel donut wouldn't?*teleports behind you*/10

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Hi people keep asking why DmC's combat is bad compared to the old ones.- The grapples make the Stinger basically worthless.- Every gun except Kablooey is useless.- Combo meter is based on damage instead of style now, which means that angel weapons are useless as the meter decays faster than they can cause damage, and everything is about demon weapons. And by "demon weapons" I mean "the Defiler" because Eryx requires charge moves to be good and even then they don't do much damage.- The controls are really badly designed. Mapping "modes" to the triggers means there needs to be two dodge buttons (that both do the same thing) or else reaching the dodge button (which you basically need to be accessible at all times) would be a horrible cluster♥♥♥♥. In order to have two dodge buttons,- they got rid of the lock-on button- It's pathetically easy. I went through my first time on the "Hard" equivalent (Nephilim?) and died three times throughout the entire campaign. Twice because they wanted me to jump onto red platforms in a red room with a floor made of red lava and grapple onto red points. The third time was because when I tried to grapple onto an enemy flying above one charging into me, and grappled into the charger instead, because they got rid of the lock-on button.- Man speaking of which, there is a ♥♥♥♥ton of platforming in this game about stylish action.- Color-coded enemies are a dumb gimmick, especially the ones you can only use angel weapons on, because they don't adjust the HP to match, so you just sit there wailing away on one guy forever.But nah, DMC fans are just mad about Dante's hair lol

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												Honestly, this game is overrated, not just a little bit but a LOT overrated. I'm not saying it's a bad game, but it's not a great game that all critics claim either. It's just above average by a small margin. Ninja Theory took everything that made DMC series great, threw it out of the window and went with their own version and ideas instead. That's not necessarily a bad thing, if the game we got could live up to expectations. Sadly it doesn't in my opinion, and it's inferior to previous installments in every possible way. They took our most favorite DMC characters, Dante & Vergil and turned them into the most despicable morons on the planet. The new characters aren't likable at all, Kat is just laughable and Mundus's "wife" is ridiculous. However, it still is on its own worth a purchase, but that's mainly because there's not many other games like this available on PC.Pros: Art design is amazing, the setting and locations are beautiful The combo system is somewhat enjoyable Enemy design and bosses are appealing aesthetically  Platforming sections are fun and exciting Checkpoint system works great and is balancedCons: Character design is god-awful, they're all forgettable and uninteresting Music took a HUGE step backwards with the new industrial/electronic metal crap There's no lock-on system, hitting flying enemies is a nightmare Devil trigger is worthless, except for regenerating health The game is too easy on the highest default difficulty, there's no challenge at all Color-coded enemies that only take damage from specific weapons Boss battles are too short and repetitive Dialog is just ridiculous and plain nonsenseGameplay = 8.5/10 ; Visuals = 8/10 ; Audio = 7/10 ; Music 7/10 ; Story = 5.5/10Verdict: 6.5/10 - Above AverageUnfortunately, I can only recommend this game to hardcore Beat 'Em Up fans because there is not much this game can offer in terms of visuals, story or soundtrack. There's just no reason to play this game if you don't like this genre, story provides zero incentive and the character design is god-awful.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Worst game in the DMC game franchise by far, somehow even beating out the "Press Square to win" DMC2. The plot is bad, even by DMC standards in addition to a somehow even more bland and unlikable Dante. That aside, as plot and character development has never been one of the franchise's noted high points, the combat is dull and uninteresting with each of the new weapons you get being more or less completely identical to Rebellion (except being less fun) and I almost never used them unless forced to by a color coded enemy that required me to fight them with an unupgraded weapon I didn't want to use (yay). I had additional complaints in mind but they seem to have escaped me as this calzone I just finished eating appears to not be agreeing well with my belly organs. To fans of either the DMC series or those of action badass games, such as God of War or Darksiders kinda, I recommend purchasing either DMC3 or 4 instead of this steaming pile of demon-angel♥♥♥♥♥♥ Oh yeah that's right, this game also hops on the nephilim edgelord preteen angst bandwagon.Overall Rating: 4/10

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Devilishly good game. The controls are the best I've used out of any DMC series. They make sense with the story and are smooth as butter with syncing combos together. The weapons are also cool, allowing you to get creative with your attack. I also loved the soundtrack, which went well with the game. I'd strongly suggest picking up a controller and using that instead of a keyboard. At first I didn't get the game because I didn't like the look of Dante, but trust me, there's other skins  and the game is always just so damn fun. It was so good that I was kinda sad when it was over, because I just wanted to play more. I'd definitely recommend this, even for first time DMC players.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Looking through my reviews I noticed this one and realized it was not very good. I only offered a few of the many issues I had with the game. I feel as though I can do better explaining my issues with this game now.---As a fan of this series I was quite heavily disappointed by this game. As a stand alone it would've been okay, at least tolerable. There was no reason to slap Devil May Cry onto the game. Leaving such big shoes to fill and then completely failing to fulfill expectations is like a punch to the face.Story and Characters:The DMC story and lore is quite interesting. It is a world where one of the strongest Demons, Sparda forced all demons back to their world and then seperated the two worlds with his power. In the process he lost his powers and even then continued to fight for justice for humanity until his eventual death. Before his death, having two sons- Vergil and Dante.This reboot throws that interesting story out of the window. DmC took one of the most important characters and ruined him. Sparda in this story is a wimpy demon who had kids with an angel. When Mundus finds out he locks up and humiliates Sparda for the rest of eternity. How could Ninja Theory do this? This is such a huge shift in character and a major issue. In the previous games Dante had the power to take on Mundus because his relation to Sparda and the power he had. However this wimpy Sparda could never hope to stand up to Mundus. Where does DmC Dante get the power to defeat Mundus? Don't try to say that his demon/angel combination of blood made him stronger. Because even if that were true there would be nothing special about Sparda's blood if he's so utterly weaker than Mundus. There is really no reason for Dante to be strong other than Ninja Theory just stating that "Nephilim are strong". No setup as to why Nephilim are so great, it's just stated.DmC Dante is another character issue. Ninja Theory went complete opposite of DMC Dante. DMC Dante was fun loving, wild, witty, and over the top. DmC Dante is what happens when game devs ask what a 10 year old CoD player thinks is cool. Edgy, vulgar and boring. Most dialogue goes as follows: "♥♥♥♥ you" "No, ♥♥♥♥ you", repeat.Vergil is the worst part. Where as DMC Vergil is an honorable warrior who does not use firearms, never attacks from behind, and never fights dirty. Ninja Theory threw all that out the window. DmC Vergil does sniper rifle abortions from a hiding spot on demon mothers. Even after bargaining for peace. Really Ninja Theory? Really? Couldn't think of a way to get any edgier? So you moved to Vergil killing unborn demon babies? Kills me to see them do this to the series. Even if it is a reboot. Also that ending was really unexplained. Vergil suddenly loses it, says that he wants to rule over humanity in Mundus' place and then fights Dante. At least DMC3 explained why Vergil did all he did. Vergil suddenly does a 180 within the last 5 minutes of the game.Kat is Kat. The game would have been the same if she hadn't been in it, she brought almost nothing to the table but semi forced Dante romance and weird Vergil idolization.Mundus is the only decent character in the game. Biggest issue is him is that why is he trying to take over the world using economics and brainwashing? Why doesn't he use his extremely powerful demon powers to force everyone and everything to his will. Really absurd.Dialogue is terrifying, almost as if it was written by a really edgy preteen. Dropping vulgarities like it's going out of style does not make a game cool. Really fun drinking game- take a shot every time Dante or someone else curses. Proceed to die of alcohol poisoning.Gameplay:Extremely important aspect of a third person hack and slash, also the key point of the entire DMC series. DMC gameplay has always been smooth, combo oriented, style heavy, and complex.DmC is none of this. Combos are often broken up by angel/demon enemies. These enemies require you to use angel/demon weapons on them. You'll be in a combo fighting an enemy and suddenly one of these guys will jump in front of you, you'll hit them with the wrong weapon since you're in the middle of doing a move against the original standard enemy and your combo will break. In a game about combos this is not good. It breaks the flow of combat to be required to use a specific weapon against a specific enemy.Combat has been "dumbed down". Lack of a lock on contributes. Ninja Theory expected that just hitting the nearest enemy would be good enough and that lock on wouldn't be necessary. Ha ha ha ha... Yeah... No... Achieving high style levels are easier than ever. In prior DMC games you had to introduce variety to your combos in order to get high ranks. You couldn't spam "YYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY+" to get SSS. But you bet you can do that in DmC, I tried. It worked. Got to SSS by spamming standard attack.DT is also extremely silly. In old DMC games DT changed the characters appearance, made their attacks stronger and faster, evasive moves more effective while maintaining the enemy's strength. DmC DT just nerfs the enemy. It doesn't buff you, make your attacks stronger or faster. It stops time and throws the enemies into the air making them defenseless. How is that a challenge or fun? When DT'd in DMC you still had to keep an eye out for enemies because no matter how awesome DT made you, the enemies were still putting up a fight.Where are the projectile weapons? All you get are Ebony+Ivory. Where's my shotgun? Where's Pandora?No Turbo mode is just depressing. Don't tell me to buy Definitive Edition because it contains all the garbage that should've been in the original game. Funny how Definitive Edition adds mechanics that DMC games had. HMMMMMMMM.....?This game is just so easy. Even the hardest difficulty of DmC barely touches Dante Must Die or normal mode in the other DMC games. Boss fights were the most disappointing part, they barely put up a fight.Optimization:Game worked fine, looked fine and even had beautiful backgrounds in some places. That's the only compliment I can give this game. Looks beautiful in places. Shame the story and gameplay sours it.Overall:Ninja Theory searched for ways to be drastically different from the old DMC games and in their pursuit to be drastically different they forgot the reason the other games were so great. They lost sight of the original material and made a mess of this reboot. I'd be completely okay if I never saw a sequel for this game.I recommend no fan of the DMC series purchase this game. This is not for you.I'd give this game a 1/10.

												I love the original Devil may cry games, especially the first three, grew up on them and i know there not the greatest, but i always thought they had a lot of potentional if done right. content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												If you don't read plot, can't speak any language the game offers, have never played the DMC series before, think the previous DMC games are too hard, hate Dante, hate Vergil even more, or hate mtn dew, then this is the game for you.Props to its optimization and graphics/environment design. Very smooth to play and some scenes are really cool. But still.***Edit: I want to take some time to recommend DMC4 (SE) here. If you are like me, who read reviews of all games in a series and usually end up getting the one with highest review, you will probably end up getting DmC, which has the best review, but hardly seen as the best game in the series.Now, DmC gets better review than DMC3, DMC4, and DMC4SE on Steam, because 1. DMC3 PC port is actually pretty bad, even though it is arguably the best game of the series, 2. DMC4 players would recommend DMC4SE, which has more content, and 3. DMC4SE's extra content is relatively thin, and old fans don't appreciate that. None of these are actually game issues. DmC, on the other hand, doesn't have these issues, and is an above average ACT game if you compare it to the market. But the plot is just so bad and the gameplay is way under par for a DMC game. I finished it because I'm a DMC fan, and I can't recommend it because I'm a DMC fan.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Okay so let us get right down to it. I bought this game for a friend so that they could play it on my computer when they come over. I never had any intention on playing this game myself. However I did finally end up playing it.Things I like;-Simple combat system once you know the controls, although depending on who is playing they may not like it because all you have to do is mash a few buttons until everything is dead.-The story is fine, I have yet to finish the game I still don't mind the story that much.-The frame rate, a game that doesn't have a locked frame rate will always make me a little happier. My GTX 970 runs the game at a respectable 150-200 FPS.-The music, might be a turn off for some, but doesn't bother me.Things I don't like;-The camera, it has a weird tendency to just stop moving and get stuck in one place at random times, happens in combat a lot.-The hit boxes are extremly large and I also noticed that you don't actually touch the floor.-The stock controls. Now this may just be my copy that for some reason had weird controls or just the fact that I am used to WASD, but that was not the control scheme once I had first intalled the game.-The enemies, they just recycle models and change some small things like colours and what they can do.-The story telling can sometimes be a bit compy.So over all reading those lists some of them are pretty small things like the enemies' models. However things like the camera getting stuck in combat and the jumps sometimes be difficult to land (Could be just me). These are things that break a game for me. Well no the game itself is not the most broken game every, many others have that honour. The game itself is just not very playable for me. I will still continue to play the game until I finish and it is certainly a good time waster, however unless you get the game on sale I personally just don't think that it is worth 34.99$

												Unbelievablely FUN. Well I should be saying, thank you Steam! I love the sales you offer every few months This was money well spent. content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
Visually appealing, yet some game design choices make the game suffer as a wholeGame was good, until you start fighting enemies that need to be DAMAGED and KILLED with only specific weapons, and most of the time you get multiple enemies with different "weaknesses". Breaks the game flow completely and makes a fun game frustrating with it's poor enemy design choices. Flying enemies with shields I can forgive, but something that fundamentally undermines why DmC is fun in the first place (combat flow), I just can't bring myself to finish the game, because those damn elemental enemies kill the extremely fun combat the game had before introducing one of the worst game design choices EVER.PROS:- Sleek visuals- Great combat flow (until you start meeting "elemental" enemies)- Vergil- Interesting take on a story with lots of social commentary on modern society- Quality level design- Replay valueCONS: - Elemental enemies- Dante is uninteresting and lacks his charm from previous games. His new look didn't bother me.- Soundtrack is a very mixed bag. Mostly just annoying dubsteb with a little bit of metal in-between- Too much emphasis on the weird pull/get pulled hook mechanic.- Easy bossesConclusion:It's definitely not as bad, as the series "fans" make it to be, however there's lots of justifiable hatred towards it, especially when it comes to the enemy design. I really liked the game, until those freaking elemental enemies just killed my interest in this game. What a shame.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I like the game, it has an atractive look and the story, it's however not without flaw.  The combat could have been smoother with the character stuttering between combos, especially the dodge roll.  I also feel the combat was needlessly complex splitting what could have easilly been a couple weapons/tools into multiple weapons that required constant switching durring the game notably havving two grappling hooks... why did there need to be litteraly two or more of each wapon type?  The games combat mechanics encourgae the player to avoid speciallizing in any one combat style and instead use every weapon available on a rotation, which I found to be clumsy and anoying, breaking my imersion in the fight while I desperatly tried to remember the different combos of each weapon and how best to use them.  The game goes for something similar to God of War in it's play style but misses the mark in a painful way.  If you are a fan of the DMC series you'll probably like this game, but for me I think I would say wait for a sale before jumping in to this reboot.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Unfortunately I can't recommend this, coming from someone who loved DMC3, 4, and Bayonetta, so I'm no newcomer to the franchise.I'll keep it brief. The biggest issue getting in the way of enjoyment is that there is NO. MANUAL. TARGETING. This leads to incredibly frustrating and unwieldy combat, and makes something as basic as target prioritization nearly impossible with more than a handful of enemies on screen.There was a newer version released for consoles which added a manual targeting mode, but which unfortunately never made its way to PC. Being forced to reduce difficulty due to a sloppy control scheme which is a huge step back makes this game very disappointing overall. Very disappointing experience for a series veteran.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												It has always been a worry of mine whenever a different dev takes over one of my favorite game series. I'll start out by saying, even though there were a few things taken out in this DmC game that are unlike other DmC games, you still have a very nice and fun DmC experience. The combos feel very satisfying to nail and they look absolutely great. They feel great, they look absolutely stunning, and they give you a very very satisfying feel. The combos that are even tougher to hit are the ones that feel even better when you actually do get them. The style of the game is great as well. Just like the various other DmC games, this one really hit the nail on the spot when capturing the same style that other titles had. The world is very convincing, and the visuals within the world are amazing. The graphics are superb and the controls feel very nice and responsive as well. But the upgrade system that allows you to get further combos are still there. The game is shorter compared to the others in the series, and although this is no Devil May Cry 4, it is still a compelling experience. There is also no lock on feature, at least from what i've seen. Which is kind of a shame but still, It is a ton of fun to jump into and start killing some baddies, and even though the new Dante is a complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you play the game you start to see his more sensitive side and you can kind of become more attached to him.TLDR; +Sick combos+Superb style+Spectacular visuals-No lock-on-Campaign is a little shortOverall:8.9/10

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												Huge fan of the DMC series and I have to say I have never understood the hate for this game. What this was advertised as was a reboot, and one that would make some stylistic changes so that a new company didn't try to just replicate an old formula. My favorite DMC game was the first, and the darker side of this game felt more in line with that. I love the level design, the combat system is fun, and the boss fights were varied enough that they never felt the same. I would definetely recommend this to anyone who can look past its differences and just enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												80 % of the game you will go from A to B using series of predefined grappling points and hit stuff on walls for in game currency, while you bump into cinematics more often than not which just completely breaks the game flow. On top of it most of these are absolute cringe-worthy ones. The main character is, as other reviewers described well, a rebellious little brat who tries to act tough, cool and edgy all the time. The amount of cliche you will be drowned in is incredible. From the villain to dantes family to dante himself.Occasionally you also fight a few enemies. And the only challenging thing about them is the extremely annoying shield that forces you to pick a particular weapon to break it before being able to damage them. They made individual enemies just excessively complex whereas the older DMCs would throw a lot of them at you, but with more freedom in your choice on how to deal with them, catering to your own demands for particular combat styles. Some had weaknesses towards a particular firearm, but they wouldn't just interrupt your flow so abruptly if you tried to hit them with something else.

content:
Posted: April 15
												This is a great game if you're looking for something that has no difficulty. Once you get the Aquila, you can just use the move round trip to spam infinites. The axe makes any other weapon useless since it outputs too much damage, and once you get the grenade gun, there's never a reason to use any other gun. The game has 2 dodge buttons instead of one dodge, and one lock on. This was fixed in the definitive edition.... which is console only, so that doesn't apply for the PC version. The story is a blatant ripoff of They Live. Do yourself a favor and watch that instead. The dialog from all of the characters in this game is just cringey, and Dante comes off as creepy in some parts.Overall, I'd give the game a 4/10. Play DMC1, DMC3, DMC4, Bayonetta 1, Bayonetta 2, Nier: Automata. Even Bayonetta on PS3 is more worth it than playing DmC.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												I must start by saying that I thought I would like it more than I did just because I was expecting it to be a bit more open/fresh.  That being said, I did however have a pretty good time with the 7 hour single player game.Its main drawback is that it really didn't grow since the previous Devil May Cry games.  The game length, gameplay, combat, and map design are all the same basic idea/concept.  The only major changes are in the graphics, story line, and voiceacting.  The actors/charactors say a lot of cliche things but it still comes out as funny and cheeky.The basic idea - go through short, straight stages while collecting items from monsters and the enviroment.  You use the items to unlock doors or purchase upgrades.  There is a ton of weapons and upgrades... so many weapons to upgrade you get them through the whole game and some near the end of the game.  Most of the upgrades are not major but noticable.With so many mechanics and weapon juggling - it can get a bit confusing at times.  Using a Xbox360 controller I would suggest as a requirement.I had a good time and kept thinking... I'll just play one more stage and ended up playing three more.  I'd recommend it to folks who love third person beat em up games.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												In my opinion, this is a fun take on the traditional hack-and-slash. While very much unlike the original Devil May Cry's, Ninja Theory provided an eyeful graphics wise while CombiChrist and Noisia give your ears plenty of chew on. Cheesy lines abound, the story in this game is engaging (if not one we may have heard before in other games). The Son of Sparda has an actual conscience in this game. Goths rejoice at the soundtrack, graphics. Take yourself back to the time when you enjoyed going to the underground clubs because this will definitely do that for you. Low, mid or high settings! It doesn't matter. It all looks good, in my opinion. If you are like me, however, the replayability is somewhat low unless you absolutely must do the challenges which are fun in their own right. Otherwise, you can play it once and come back later to remember why you enjoyed this game.Second time I've played through this game and I love it still.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Now I know why this game was practically canned. I thought they were just overplaying his twilight-esque jacob style hair, or his rather moody looking jacket.But no. They managed to ♥♥♥♥ up dante. HOW CAN YOU ♥♥♥♥ UP DANTE. By making him a whiney, pessemistic,♥♥♥♥♥♥ant of a person, that's how. That's exactly what he is in this game. I've literally taken to just skipping story segments in order to get to the "decent" part which is the combat. And speaking of the combat....It's not DMC either, really. No game will ever personify DMC more than DMC 3: Special edition in my eyes, and for good reason. It's the dante that made dante a lovable character and had GOOD weapons and movesets, which was what CHARACTERIZED the genre, rather than making him look like a sub-par peasant like in 4, or a moody ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like in 1 and 2.Or like a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥like this in DmC: Devil May Cry - Wana be in twilight but I got rejected edition.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
An entertaining hack-and-slash game.You're a demon/angel hybrid that fights demons to try and avenge your family.The music keeps the fighting intense as it plays screamo music, with an insane amount of moves, weapons, and perfect gameplay mechanics that give you freedom to move and kill in the way you want much like Kingdom Hearts.The reason why this DmC game is so hard is that your health does not regenerate. Unless you either beat the level entirely, buy potions (which affect your score AND get more expensive every purchase), or finding a RARE red skull for one bar of health. So not taking any damage is key which makes it very challenging.Being sucked into limbo and fighting the same things over and over does get very tedious though. Still, it is a fun game.8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												If you're not buying this classic cause the main character doesn't have white hair than you're an idiot. This game does so much justise for the dying series that it blows my mind the feedback it received due to Dante having black hair (Angry Joe logic). Capcom's community is too stubborn already. It's sad this game didn't get the amazing respect it deserved for it's refined combat, and awesome boss fights. Not to mention their is actually a story this time in the series that's perfect for a hack 'n slash game like this. In general if you're looking for probably the BEST hack 'n slash game on steam currently it's hand's down DMC. (For me anyways since I've searched constantly for a better hack 'n slash game that can be on the same level as DMC & Metal Gear Rising for steam) It's pretty upsetting that this masterpiece will never get the sequel it deserves. Atleast Ninja Theory is still kicking and working on other games.

												The refreshed Devil May Cry game is back and better than ever in my opinion. It is a hack'n slash game with rpg elements and 20 missions. During missions there are a lot of hidden items (lost solus, secret keys and doors) to be found for achievements and rewards. You get style points during combat, the nore badass you are the more points you get. At the end of a mission your final score is calculated and uploaded to the leaderboard. Secret missoins are only available if you find the hidden keys and doors. Enemies are diverse, and sometimes difficult to defeat. Boss fight are excellent. Recommended game for players who like hack and slash games. 8/10.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												This game is both a blessing and a curse, and here's why.First of all, let me say that this is "Devil May Cry" for casual gamers. This is basically how DMC2 was, and is probably a lot of the reason behind the hate for this game. You will earn style easily by spamming a couple of moves or even by shooting, there is not much freedom of style later on due to specific enemies all having to die with specific movesets/grabs in specific ways, it's slow, and it all sort of falls apart from there. This is its curse.Don't even get me started on the platforming, the simplified bosses, and that god awful camera.Now before you !TRIGGER! and hit that NO button, please read further first.From all the crap that they smashed together and ended up making another DMC2/Darksiders with, there is some diamond within the ashes. First of all, the combat is definitely more cinematic. I'm not talking about the bosses. I'm talking about when you're finished killing someone, the scene closes up on (Vergil/Dante) quickly glancing behind him, and bam, more demons. Cinematic transitions like that are just awesome. While the acting behind basically every main character was virtually garbage, the cutscenes were actually pretty great. The city felt fleshed out, the antagonist (both of them) did things in rather creative ways, and it was a breath of fresh air from the "Demon becomes God, then dies" plot that virtually every other DMC had.The DLC (Vergil's Downfall) was a nice "return to roots" with a lot of the old Vergil's moveset, refining itself so well that even Capcom couldn't deny it when they used a lot of it for DMC4:SE's Vergil. ♥♥♥♥ Devil Mode, though.As much as I hate this game and its cushiony, casual feel to it, I'm still going to recommend it for the same reason I'd recommend someone to play DMC2. It's not a gem in the series, but the mechanics implemented bring a lot of ideas that have and will evolve later entries, and it's worth taking a look at it for that reason.Also because Combichrist is in it.7/10. For anyone that is well aware of how difficult DMC games are and wants to start somewhere easier.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												The hardest thing about replaying the game on higher difficulties settings is the boredom. So many unskippable scenes! There's also parts where the game caps your running speed because shame on you for trying run away from dialogue you've heard before!In addition to unskippable scenes, the game has the ridiculous habit of letting things "go on" as you wait for your screen to return from black. Repeatedly on mission 10, I kept coming out the cutscene only to find Danta having walked off a ledge. I don't know how they let that in. To a new player, it'd feel like they'd spawned you only to kill you. As to a single playhrough, the voice acting or writing is just painfully awful at parts. (Things are either over-acted or have a unnatural word choice for a modern setting). The platforming is also a very annoying chore since Dante doesn't have much ups for being part angel, and his grapples (Demonic Pull/Angelic Lift) have odd targeting delays as you try to chain grapple movements together during platforming.The controls on keyboard+mouse do not feel good, and the default gamepad controls go against the "standard" in actions games. (The left button is your gun instead of your standard melee, and the top button is basic melee instead of alt melee. Also, there's two evade buttons, down on the D-pad does nothing by default, and  the Angelic mode (LT) vs Demonic (RT) mode mechanic does not feel as well implemented as that of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow's Light mode vs Dark mode, which is a game that came earlier than this one.)As for the combat, it's alright; not terrible, but it's no where close to the most fun I've ever had. The enemy desigin is a bit boring since a lot of enemies are re-skins of others and have a broken doll motif; (it's very lackluster for a game where demons and angels are real.) Mentioned earlier, the binary mode mechanic feels better done in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. As for how the game fits in the action-adventure genre, I would recommend Castlevania: Lords of Shadow or God of War over this.UPDATE: Got all the achievements in the Vergil's Downfall DLC. It's even less fun than the main game since: ■ There's a bug where Vergil can't perform a regular rising strike. ■ His Devil Triggers offer less security than Dante's Devil Trigger.■ The targetting on his projectiles is subpar since it can literally pick the wrong platform to materialize during platforming.■ On the subject of platforming, Vergil doesn't have a regular double jump; (he still has a way to get high, but I don't know why they made it less intuitive).■ A lot of his attack animations are slow and long compared to Dante equivalents; (it's especially bad for his standard melee).■ His dodging is just awful compared to Dante's. The immunity window seems even shorter than Dante's regular dodge, and Vergil's dodge can be cut short if there's an enemy in his path.■ You will take hits from enemies outside of your view. This happens sometimes in the main game (especially against harpies), but it's more common in Vergil's downfail since there's more harpies and enemies that like perfoming 2-hit combos.■ The main boss fight in the DLC (mission 5), is a lot cheaper than any of the bosses in the main game. He has 2 attacks that are extremely hard to dodge; projectile swords which you can't destroy with your projectiles, and a dive bomb kick that interrupts Vergil's dodge and forces Vergil to take damage. There's also this annoying bit where he teleports away and you need to repeatedly have great timing in dodge a ring of projectile swords; it's a lot less forgiving than anything in the main game.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Take my playtime with a grain of salt, I was initially playing a nonsteam version of the game.Prejudice kept me from playing this game for 2 years.I love the "Stylin' Dante" of the old games, but my god was I being a ♥♥♥♥ing numbskull. "New Dante" or "Edgy Dante" shouldn't really be compared to Stylin' Dante because he's much, much younger. This Dante isn't sure who he is yet, so many of his jokes fall flat or come off like he's trying too hard. I feel that was intentional.They also reworked the design for him based on fan feedback, which makes the poor sales of this game even sadder in my opinion. Its clear Ninja Theory adores the original franchise, as so much of this plays like a love letter to those games. They listened to the fans as much as they could, and people still bash this game without even playing it.Admittedly, I was the same way until a good friend promised me I would like it, so I "borrowed" it, and was blown away. The story is better than folks say, and is decently engaging. I found the reason the world viewed Dante as a threat far more interesting than the previous games, and the visuals are very different than any urbanesque game I had played before. It shares the feeling of Brutal Legend "Am I playing through an Album Cover?"I felt that a lot of events in this game kept me guessing, either through new enemy types of plot twists. Overall it was just a really fun experience.Recommended Price - 15-25 dollarsOverall Story - 7/10Gameplay - 9/10Visuals -  10/10Writing - 6/10 (-2 points for judicious use of ♥♥♥♥ you instead of clever quips)Enemy Variety - 10/10Vergil's Downfall Review - Its alright.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												I was expecting to hate this. I've heard about how on rails it is, I've heard about how little choice there is.Screw that.This is an amazing game - it's like an interactive movie.It's a rarity that a game does this well on the empowerment fantasy.I felt like a badass almost every step of the way, from mission 1 to the end, I felt like I was kickass, nothing could stop me, and all the baddies could do was slow me down (which they did).I played on easy mode, because my goal was to have fun, and fun was to be had!I never had to resort to a guide for the next step - it's not a puzzle oriented game, although you could immerse for more time hunting down achievements, of whcih there are plenty.Good, old fashioned smash the baddies fun.No guilt tripping.Great game, solid graphics, corfe mechanics are well executed.(The DLC is kind of meh - Dante(main game) has a depth of tools and fighting styles that makes him fun. Virgil(DLC) lacks that depth, he requires a lot more finesse to do well with, but I finished both and don't regret the purchases.)

Posted: September 29, 2014
												20% spiderman + 20%portal + 50% hack'n slash + 10% capcom = DmCthe gameplay is cool , but the story isn't but i like its idea a little bit  , this is the easiest DMC game i've ever played , i've finished it in 9 hours ( nephilim mode ) .. they removed the style changing system and replaced it with a demon and angel mode which gives options to new combos . the secret missions are now accessible just from the main menu , you just need to visit them in-level for the first time and they are repetetive , they just differ in the level/atmosphere/ennemies unlike the secret missions in the original  games , this is one of the reasons why i think its the easiest devil may cry game ....the graphics are beautiful , the soundtrack fits with its scene/moment ingame , and it also offers a new mode : the training mode , where you can train combos in it  without entering a mission , also , i liked the idea about letting you : trying a move before upgrading/buying it from the shop , so see if you like/dislike it and to avoid some cases like if you find it difficult to be inputed :)7.5/10

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Well first off it's poorly optimized, I have a brand new PC and could only run the game on low settings without getting FPS drops and lagging/stuttering, secondly it's next to impossible to play this with a PS4 controller. It claims that it offers "Full Controller Support" but I had an impossible time re-binding the keys to the PS4 controller in-game, whenever I had them re-binded they wouldn't stay and would automatically reset to default. For example the jump button was binded to the square button and the shoot button was binded to the circle button, if I tried binding the jump button to the cross button it wouldn't stick.It seems I'm part of a small majority as most people didn't have trouble with the controllers or the game, not sure if it's my processor or what. I've heard some games run poorly if you have certain processors, but my MAIN issue was the HORRIBLE CONTROLS, "Full Controller Support" my butt. Though it seems that the error lies with me since most people didn't seem to have a problem playing the game, either way the controls in the game are terribly optimized and the game itself seems poorly optimized as well. And another thing I noticed is the controller sensitive was entirely too high, I couldn't navigate menus properly because the sensitivity was set so high it'd skip over certain options if I moved the control stick.

												DMC is a game released in january 2013 as a prequel to the DEVIL MAY CRY series in which you get to play as a teenage Dante .DMC is a 3rd person hack & slash / platformer that introduces a concept completly new to the genere and it is AEREAL COMBAT ,many games enable the player to perform aereal combos but in DMC you can not only perform aereal combos but move from enemy to enemy and avoid or counter incoming attack in midair .There're eight different weapons you can wield the rebellion sword ,two angel weapons and two demon weapons in addition to your firearms "ebony and ivory" a shotgun and en explosive darts gun

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Ah, DMC.  First of all, let's just get this out of the way.  This game should not have been called DMC or Devil May Cry.  If it wasn't, it probably would have sold more and wouldn't have gotten such bad press.I could see this working if this was more of a side story to DMC, but by rebooting the series and taking it into this direction I can clearly see why the fanbase went ballistic.  Dante looks TERRIBLE (in my opinion) and just way to EMO!  Virgil, Dante's brother is also just... out of place from the original.  BUT! Ignoring all that, the game is quite solid.  I will admit it is fun to play and it runs like a dream on a PC due to having that smooth 60FPS action.  The keyboard and mouse work quite favorably as does using a joypad.I recommend this game more for its gameplay rather then story.  If you can just ignore the fact that it's supposed to be a DMC game you may find it enjoyable.  It really didn't help that the designer of this game (Tameemi Antoniades) insulted the fan base.  Hopefully Capcom/Ninja Theory will be a little wiser with their PR in the future.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2013
												DMC: Devil May Cry is a reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise, following an original storyline, with essentially a similar cast of characters and general premise. The game is an action slash and shoot style game where you will spend the majority of your time in senseless combat. The combat system in this game is actually quite good, there are several weapons which can be used and you can toggle between them almost instantly for insane combos. The combat feels fluid and the controls are solid when you are using a controller, yet the keyboard and mouse controls are less than stellar. There is however almost too much variety and you will sometimes struggle to perform the correct action as you fly from button to button mid combat. The cinematics are actually well done, and although the story is poorly written and predictable at best, the cinematics give it a movie-esque feel. The game is relatively short but offers a decent amount of gameplay and variety of enemies. Overall it is a decent buy if purchased on sale, and one of the better DMC games.

content:

												This game is kinda reflects my world view I believe in.Other than that, it's a perfect game. Never played the previous DMC's, but this one got me when I first saw it's trailer. And why do I think it's perfect?-The combat system is exemplary, no other similar game can reach this quality and fluency. Tons of weapons, even more combos, and it's so badass I can't even compare to other games. -The graphic, design and details are amazing. There are more ideas and creativity in this game than in all the CoD and Battlefield series together.-11-15 hours isn't that long, but the story keeps some twists and definitely worth your attention. -Never faced any bugs. -The fights are challenging, I started on hard (nephilim) but had to change back to an easier mode during two bossfights. And there are many other hard and ultra hard modes for the hardcore.- This game was built for re-playability. There are secret rooms on the first maps what you can only open with unique weapons you'll get later in the game.  You can't unlock many comcept arts simply because you can't kill enough through one walkthrough. And I must mention those certain achievements as well. F*** all the haters, this game is absolutely great, go buy it now!

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												DmC: Devil May Cry is a reboot of the famous Devil May Cry series. It stars Dante, son of Sparda, who is the son of a demonic father and an angelic mother. You will see how demons and angels merge as the story progresses. Dante’s lifestyle is that of a playboy, living a life of booze, parties, and sex. The story centers around two other characters: Kat, the psychic, and Vergil, Dante’s brother. The story truly evolves when Kat and Vergil meet up with Dante in place called Limbo.The combat in the game is generally about the use of melee weapons and your ability to use combos against the various demons. The combat is entertaining enough that it makes DmC: Devil May Cry a fun reboot in the aggregate. You begin to learn the basics of melee combat with the Rebellion sword. Melee turns into learning so many different moves so that you can score style points under the game’s scoring system. Eventually, other melee weapons come into play and they are demon based as wells as angel based. This is when combat becomes even more important since some demons are vulnerable only to demonic weapons and other demons are vulnerable only to angelic weapons.The story includes world domination, evil, love and conspiracy theories. The characters are pretty good because their voiceovers are excellent. The cutscenes display drama and the characters tend to walk a fine line between good and evil as the plot is well detailed.The missions are quite linear, but they are never boring since they are diverse enough and lack tedium. In one mission you are fighting demon hordes in a city that appears to be crumbling. In another mission you are inside the offices of a TV network where you must face groups of demons as you go from one office to another. The melee weapons eventually include a Rebellion and Osiris. The Rebellion is a demonic axe with plenty of power, but at the expense of speed. The Osiris is an angelic weapon with plenty of speed. Both weapons can be used to lift demons in the air and you can jump into the air to score major chain combos for the most style points. The idea of the scoring system is to vary your attacks, chain your combos, and finish off the demons in short order. The style points are displayed on the screen while you are in the heat of battle with SSS being the highest possible grade for your combat performance. I used the mouse/keyboard controls throughout the game and they were smooth. I got used to the controls pretty quickly, but it takes time to master the moves, including platforming. There is a lot of jumping from platform to platform and that includes angel lifts and angel boosts. Angel lifting is the jumping from platform to platform using Dante’s grappling hook on blue circles. Angel boosting is jumping and flying/boosting above large gaps to reach a faraway platform. One interesting weapon that Dante acquires later in the game is the Aquila, an angelic weapon that can be used for melee and can be thrown to cut through vines.Completionists will always find something to do in each mission. To complete 100% of each mission you will have to return to a mission to collect keys that will open doors to secret missions and free lost souls waiting to be liberated. The secret missions require keys that reflect the difficulty of each secret mission. Copper keys are keys that open doors to the easiest secret missions. Argent keys open doors to more challenging secret missions. Gold keys are for the hardest secret missions. The secret missions are short and can help you practice your moves. I learned from the secret missions that Dante’s combat moves are easy to learn, hard to master. Some challenges include killing all demons without taking a hit and scoring hits only by using demon evade, a well-timed way of evading demon attacks while armed only with a demonic weapon such as the Arbiter.The boss fights are entertaining in their own right, although they are formulaic. You fight bosses while learning their moves so that you figure out how to defeat them. One boss near the end of the story, Mundus, is quite convincing as a mean monster since the voiceover is superb. The one minor problem with combat against either bosses or other demons is that sometimes the camera angles can get in the way, preventing you from seeing everything in the spur of the moment. However, this problem is so minor it doesn’t take much away from the entertainment value of the combat. I think DmC: Devil May Cry is worth your time since the combat is well choreographed and the controls are excellent. If there are problems with combat it is usually because the timing of the combos is not right. It takes plenty of practice to master the different combos. The varied missions are entertaining and will never bore you. The game has more replay value if you decide to play Vergil’s Downfall DLC, which stars Dante’s brother Vergil.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Out of all the DMC games I would say that this one is my second favourite underneathe the first original game on PS2. I think the reboot is a nice, modern, western take on a very cool and mythical story. The new characters a very likeable, the graphics are great, and on PC the frame rate is a non-issue (some people disliked the console version being locked to 30 fps, though having played this game on both consoles and PC I can safely say that while 60 fps+ is the better experience, 30 fps is still enjoyable).No multiplayer to speak of but a satisfying, decently sized single player campaign with a decent story and addictingly fun combat with good controls (keyboard & mouse do just fine but a gamepad is more preferable in my personal opinion) make this game worth it in my opinion. I'd definitely recommend this to people who like hack & slash games.

												Played nearly every game this year that was high rated, none comes close to the visual feast that this game provides, if you like skillshot hack and slash then this game is the best of its kind. One of my top picks for 2013 and a game that is so underrated its not funny. i played it with a controller and it was a blast, when you start to link together complex combos the feeling of satisfaction that you will gain is immense. this game is an amazing hidden gem.Story - 9Gameplay - 10Visuals - 10Replay - 9A solid game, much better than its predecessors and a game worthy of being titled best in its class and also one of the best releases of 2013.Ed Note-I understand the community is split over this game, half think this game is too easy, combos are to easy and pretty much hate it, the other half loves it. Well, heres my opinion as someone who played all games, the previous dmc games wernt that good, backtracking, horrid story, cheesy dialogue and overtly japanese themes. Yes, they had a great combat system, but thats what the game was known for anyway, This reboot helps to streamline combat and fix up the obvious lackings of the previous series. Consider this game an americanized reboot, i think its much better.

												As a Character Action fan, and a fan of the Devil May Cry series, of course I am clearly torn on the existence of this game.  Of course it isn't as awful as DMC2, but honestly I prefer it over DMC4, which I found abysmal.Pros-PC Version is a locked 60FPS.-Fast, Responsive gameplay-Training Room, which a lot of action games don't have.-Fantastic art direction.-Quality Sound Mixing.-Content packed.Cons-Possibly the slowest DMC Game, in regards to combat speed.-Possibly the easiest DMC game in terms of difficulty and enemy AI design-Color coded enemies are stupid.-Removal of auto-lock in replacement for soft locking.-Awful story.Still, I recommend the game.  It's not a good DMC game, but it's not the worst DMC game.  It is however the best western action game available.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
DmC Devil May Cry may not have lived up to the hopes from a lot of long time fans of the series but the reboot in my honest opinion is still a fantastic game. There are some problems with the gameplay but overall the game is fantastic and is a must own in anyone's library.DmC is a combo based Hack and Slash, Action Adventure game that is a reboot of the long running series Devil May Cry. In this game you play as Dante, a half demon/half angel Nephilim that while learning about his origins fights his way through demons to get to the demon king. As stated since DmC is a hack and slash combo game you must master combos of various weapons in order to kill waves of demons and get a higher combo score. This Combo score is scored on a lettering system which is in the order of Dirty, Cruel, Brutal, Anarchic, Savage!, SSadistic!! and SSSensational!!!. The higher the combo score the more XP you get in order to upgrade Dante's weapons which include his sword, Rebellion, his demon weapons Arbiter (Axe) and Eryx (Gloves), his angel weapons Osiris (Scythe) and Aquila (Shuriken) and his ranged weapons Ebony & Ivory, Revenant and Kablooey. Along with upgrading these weapons you have the ability to unlock new combos that you can use to more effectively kill demons and get a higher combo score. In order to get a higher combo score you must mix up combos and weapons without getting hit by an enemy. Despite it being a bit complex it is nowhere near the complexity of the original Devil May Cry games which is a big reason a lot of long time fans were not happy about the reboot. Along with the dumbing down of the combat it is also a lot easier to get a SSS rank which takes a lot of the challenge out of a hack and slash combo game. Another quirk that was a problem with this game was the color coded enemies. This severely limited your options of what weapons you could use against an enemy. Though it added a little layer of complexity to the combat it was more of an irritant that something enjoyable. Otherwise the combat was a lot of fun and I got a huge satisfaction of killing enemies and using various combos while fighting.One more thing to add is that in the original Devil May Cry series, the player was forced to go through very monotonous jumping puzzles that really served no purpose being in the game. DmC improved on this greatly and despite it still having the jumping puzzles they are a lot more satisfying. For example, at one point you are in limbo mode while Vergil and Kat are in the real world. All during this time the world around you is falling apart and while jumping around and fighting enemies you have to help them avoid obstructions that would kill them. Just seeing the world crumble and try to defeat you itself is fascinating and a lot more fun than the puzzles in the original series. As I mentioned before you play as Dante, a half demon/half angel Nephilim, who was pulled into a Limbo one day after he met Kat. Limbo is a parallel world to the real world where the demons live. This is the only place that Dante can actively fight the demons and use his powers to stop them. After his initial fight he is brought before Vergil who informs him that he is a Nephilim and that Vergil is his twin brother who runs an organization called "The Order". Vergil explains that their ultimate goal is to bring down the demons ore more specifically the Demon King Mundus who has been searching for Dante because he knew Dante was a Nephilim. The reboot did a great job of bringing back the characters and giving them a whole different spin. In the original series Dante was an egocentric maniac that was overconfident and used to fighting demons. In the reboot, they show him in his younger more naive state that is just learning about his origins and what it means to him to be a Nephilim. I found the story absolutely fascinating and was quite engaging especially the character development of Dante himself. He started out as someone who only cared about himself, drank and partied all the time and changed into someone that began to find compassion for his friends and for others.  Now this game being a couple years old doesn't have the best graphics but they are still very good. On top of that, Ninja Theory did an absolutely fantastic job differentiating between the living world and Limbo. When you are out in the living world, it is very dull, dark, grey and boring. It represents how many in the living world are stuck doing the same monotonous tasks over and over again because they have been under control the entire time. When you play in Limbo the world is colorful, unique, full of amazing looking scenery and level designs.  You can really feel the passion that went into making Limbo as great looking as they can.On top of that the soundtrack is absolutely fantastic. It has a great mix of electronic, rock, classical and many other genres that just compliment each level and scenario you are playing in. A soundtrack can absolutely make or break a game/movie. You watch Star Wars without any of the background music from John Williams and you lose a lot of emotional appeal of what is going on, especially that scene where Luke finds his Aunt and Uncle dead.  It just complimented the scene so well and the soundtrack in DmC does the same. Along with the music the voice acting is also superb. They really made it sound like their characters were engaged and made them more believable.  Overall, DmC is one of my favorite games and a must play in my opinion. The gameplay may have been dumbed down from the original series but that isn't to say it isn't still a lot of fun to just destroy the various demons. It helps that Ninja Theory wrote a great story and did a fantastic job with differentiating between the two worlds. The game may be a single player game however it isn't without a bit of replay value thanks to unlocking new game+ and being able to go back and get all the collectables.Story - 8Gameplay - 7Presentation - 9Music/Sound - 9Fun - 9Replay Value - 7
