content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												"You are dead to me." This quote came from a friend at work when I informed him I was playing Devil May Cry 2013. Why did he feel so strongly? Because he, like many others, thought the new look of Dante was somehow sacriligious to past Devil May Cry games. Well after finishing the game, all I can say is he and the others are missing out. DMC is everything that is great about the series only with a fresh coat of paint. Let's examine what this game is. This is a reboot of an origin story for a very bad♥♥♥♥♥character.I won't lie and say I am a die hard fan. I have only played DMC 1 and 4.DMC 1 was good but did not have a lasting impact on me. DMC 4 was the first game I purchased for my PS3 years ago and I thouroughly enjoyed the (at the time) stunning visuals and breakneck gameplay. The opening sequence was what hooked me and the gameplay was spectacular. Thanks to the many amazing games on the PS3 (and so little time), DMC 2013 came and past without a purchase and I thought it would be just one more DMC game I would never play.Fast forward to October 2014 steam sale in which I purchased my first gaming laptop and saw DMC 2013 for $17.00. DMC 4 had been a worthwhile purchase back on the PS3 so I bought DMC 2013 and I am very pleased that I did. Let's talk about that fresh coat of paint. This is a modern twist on the DMC formula. The story gives us a look at a young Dante and his transformation from a selfish punk to the world's hope amongst the demons. This story will not apeal to everyone, but it is well writtenand I laughed a few times at Dante's sense of humor. The characters are very likeable (a special nod to Virgil) including Dante by the end of the tale. What about the gameplay you ask? After all this is the real reason someone would play any game. I am happy to report this is the DMC action we all know and love. The gameplay is fun and chaotic. The levels are beautiful and makes exploring a pleasure. Keep in mind this is DMC so don't use too much time exploring unless you want a lower rating. On the default normal difficulty, the game is challenging but not cheap. Every time I died it was my own fault for getting carried away hacking at an enemy. The enemies get re-used but in different configurations over the course of the game. Two minor gripes would be the camera angle sometimes gets in the way and how deep the combo system can be. The problem I have with the combo system is that it can be difficult in the heat of battle to remember all the diffirent attacks you can do. This is not a deal breaker though because it also makes for some very exciting battles. I will finally also mention one of the most underrated aspects of gaming these days and that is the excellent checkpoint system. Again this is my own opinion, but a good checkpoint system is really important (losing loads of progress when you have so little time to play is not ideal).So in conclusion, despite my untimely death in the eyes of my co-worker, this game is completely worth your attention. Despite the reboot menatlity (Dante's new look, the modern setting, the backstory) and the few flaws (wonky camera at times, overwhelming combo system) this game is amazing. I would highly recommend that any action game or Devil May Cry enthusiast check it out. I had such a good time with this game and I am happy that it was my first game I purchased and beat on my new laptop.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.This was the first game I bought that was more of a meelee fighting game and damn I really liked it. Even though my PC wasnt the best, and I still wanted to play in high res., it was a bit laggy/buggy, however in the game as a whole, it was a great experience.Storyline: in my opinion, storyline is a really big thing. Not a good storyline =♥♥♥♥♥♥game.This a really good one, as you play as Dante, who is a skilled fighter etc. You automaticly get into the storyline, as you early understand it, and in the second mission you actually get Dante's backround and the other side characters.(spoiler alert)Characters: I find all the characters really interesting, Dante as a whole, is a great guy and fun to play as. Vergil is the one I found really cool, as he always seems calm, smart and skilled. Although you never truly gets his backround, which I find is one of the worst things, you dont loose any interest. Kat is the "main" side character as she does alot of brave stuff. She is REALLY interesting as you dont get her backstory untill a bit later into the game. Which is kind of great, as if you get bored of Dante, you will imediately get into what she's all about.Enemies: you will encounter new enemies later into the game, but it is usually all the same. The first one you meet, is weak and easy to kill. The later enemies, which are harder to kill, brings a bit of variation into the game. Boss fights are allright, not too great, but not entirely bad. They are easy once you figure out what they do and counter it.Combat styles: as it was the first game I played I expected the controls to be♥♥♥♥♥♥ Like, how could they be good? But I was wrong. It was easy to learn, all of the controls made sense, easy to do combos etc.Bad: not alot to write, but the number one thing is pretty clear: enemies. They only varies if you get really far into the game. It can take alot of time, which I find annoying. The witches is the most annoying. They're easy to take if they're alone, but with other enemies they are so hard to kill. If you focus her, the other enemies will damage you, if you focus the enemies, she shields them. They are just there to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, and they do good.But a solid 8/10, great combat, interesting story. Only gets dragged down by the enemies.

												DmC:DMC is the reboot of the Devil May Cry games that I really like so I must of course like the reboot, no...I could make a 6 paragraph review on why I hate this game but that requires effort and me being able to write cohesive sentences so I'm just going to bullet point my issues.♥♥♥♥♥♥story that is both edgy and boring at the same time♥♥♥♥♥♥controls that feel uncomfortable thanks to how you switch between weapons-Annoying enemies-Annoying enemies that can only take damage from one type of weapon-No hard lock-on system so you'll sometimes grab the enemy you don't want to and end up taking damage in the process-Easy combat-Boring bosses-THE WORST CAMERA I'VE SEEN IN A GAME LIKE THISAnd that's only half of my complaints. content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Before I start my review for this game I would to like to say that Devil May Cry is one of my favourite's franchise ever, one of the most stylish, cool, and entertaining title ever made. DmC as you should know it's a reboot from the franchise, it made alot of people argue and complain about it, the reason ? Dante new look, yes ... young and reckless Dante. I completly understand it, Dante is the coolest character ever made imo. But is not a good reason to say the game is bad, in fact the game is REALLY well done, apart from the dante look. The gameplay is awesome and makes you enjoy and merge into the action. Cool weapons, moves, even to story is good. Absolutely no reason to say the game is bad. I've finished more than 4x times on XBOX 360. Now playing on PC port once again !The reboot was necessary because the franchise was moving torwards to an end, with Dante getting old and no more story to be add. But now things are different, the reboot brings alot of new possibilities to the game. New powers, creatures, characters, will give tons of story to be told.Carrying the DmC title is not an easy task, but Ninja Theory did a good job, and I believe that my beloved DmC is in good hands. Forget those haters that says the game is this and that, they know nothing... DmC was always about it's stylish and coold gameplay. Which DmC still have that essence and feeling.

												Platforming is beyond garbage as you lose momentum from swinging and jumping. The times I thought I could make a jump  just throws me off the edge. Collectables are fine in a DMC game, but having it as a way to rank your missions is absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Orbs kinda made sense, but collectables still confuse me. Why?Combat is alright. Weapon matching against enemies is god awful and annoying. Devil trigger sucks and the grappling hooks feels kinda "cheesy" to use during combat.If this game was called something else, then it would be an "average" game I could probably recommend. But because it is "related" to this series, all my inputs from the older games sneaks its way into my brain and my nostalgia just brings it down  yeah, I know its bad	7/10 too much ♥♥♥♥ you

												I played through the first half of the game on the highest difficulty without getting hit by any enemies, but the camera is so horrible that I couldn't get past the forced pseudo-quick action platforming segment with my controller without switching back to keyboard and mouse, because it was a constant struggle between pressing 5 different triggers and readjusting the camera with the right analog stick.Also, this game has some of the strangest framerate issues I've ever seen. content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												In this retelling of Dante's origin story which is set against a contemporary backdrop, DmC Devil May Cry™ retains the stylish action, fluid combat and self-assured protagonist that have defined the iconic series but inject a more brutal and visceral edge.The Dante of DmC is a young man who has no respect for authority or indeed society in general. Dante knows that he is not human, but also that he is not like the demons that have tormented him throughout his life. Caught between worlds, he feels like an outcast. Thanks to his twin brother Vergil, leader of the anti-establishment group called “The Order”, Dante is now discovering and coming to terms with what it means to be the child of a demon and an angel. This split personality has a real impact on gameplay with Dante being able to call upon angel and demon abilities at will, transforming his Rebellion sword on the fly to dramatically affect both combat and movement. For DmC Capcom has teamed up with UK development studio, Ninja Theory, renown for delivering action titles with compelling characters and narrative coupled with high production values. The combination of Ninja Theory’s expertise and Capcom’s unrivalled heritage in producing combat focused action titles will ensure that this latest addition to the over 11-million selling series will remain true to the Devil May Cry DNA so cherished by the fans, while bringing a new level of cinematic quality to the title.

												Basically a HD Remix of DMC3. Seems like for every one thing this game does right there are two things it does wrong. No lock-on button? Inexcusable. Two buttons that do the same thing? Why? Story and writing: Terrible.  Not that it matters, but don't tell me the game has Shakespearean feel/elements to it when it's just pulling concepts from todays popular Shonen mangas. The music is fitting and some of the set pieces for the action are fun. Sad that you have to play through the game on a dumbed down difficulty before you can actually start to enjoy the game. The move list for the weapons is lacking to say the least, but at least they have all the basics covered. If NT gets their head out of their♥♥♥♥♥and stop writing jokes that are basically a giant '♥♥♥♥ You' to the fans of the game maybe they can get something right with a sequel (if they're allowed to).If only DMC and DmC could co-exist, I'd be ok with that. But if this is what we're stuck with, RIP Dante. I can always revisit you on my PS2.

												I don't understand how this game got such high praise. Maybe it's because the keyboard controls suck and I'm not great with a controller, maybe it's some problem with my PC, or maybe it's just something that doesn't line up with my personal tastes. But this game is so damn boring. The controls are unresponsive, the camera is terrible, the characters are dull and uninteresting carboard cutouts. I'm going to try it a couple more times, see if something clicks. But damn. I don't get it.Update Jan 13: So I've now played the game enough that I have the controls figured out. It's still just not fun. I've just beat chapter ten, and appearently there's twenty, so I'm giving up on it. I find that there's a lot of weird animation delay issues. There have been a couple of times where I would hit the dodge button, get hit, and then the dodge goes off after the hit animation. The difficulty is weird, where I feel like I'm constantly ♥♥♥♥ing up, but I'm also never really afraid I'm going to fail. It just doesn't feel good to play the game.It it's benefit, the combat is varied, the sound effects are good. It has some cool design choices, like the big floating angry words. It's compitent. It's just not fun. It's a chore. Eh.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												The combat is fun, it never gets stale because you are consistently given new ways to open up your combos. The scoring system is fair and gives you a fantastic sense of achievement when you get that SSS rank. The highlight of the game for me was everything surrounding the gameplay however. The characters' facial animations are spot on and the voice acting is some of the best in modern gaming. Topped off by a fantastic script, the characters and their motivations seem refreshingly believable. The humour is subtle, not forced, which made it that much funnier. There are numerous references to other games, films, and real people which are quite amusing. You WILL enjoy this game if you haven't played it before.

I wouldn't personally recommend this but I can see why people may enjoy it.

number of helpful: 13 of 42 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												"This game has some bad bits, but even Dante was half demon"The Devil May Cry series first released on the PS2  more than a decade ago. The series was a great collection of action games (though Devil May Cry 2 fell far short of the other three games) and have influenced other games since then. For the fifth game however, Capcom decided it was time to start over, and so we get this reboot from a different developer. The new Dante has a different attitude and tell anyone willing to fight him "**** you".  It got a bit of flack from fans of the series, but since I was gifted this, I decided to give it a try and see how it compared. StoryRight, even here has a number of changes. At the start of the game, Dante is someone who just doesn't really give a damn for others. Later, he will get closer to people fighting against the demons and will help them free the humans from their control. His brother makes a return as well, this time as an ally and someone else working to help the humans. The story is decent enough, even if I didn't like the cursing that was common in some parts of the story. PresentationThe game looks nice. While the reboot resulted in character redesigns, the important characters and the random enemies you will fight look pretty good. I'm not a big fan of the changes here, but they aren't ugly. The music is suitable for the action. Can't say much more about it. Nothing really memorable. It does what it needs to. Sound effects are suitable for what is happening. It works. The voice acting is much the same. Its there, its okay, but I'm not really impressed by it. ControlsA gamepad is the preferred choice of control for this game. While the keyboard can be used, I didn't find it as nice to use for certain actions as I did with a gamepad. Still, if you are someone unwilling to buy a gamepad for whatever reason, you can still play the game, your experience just won't be as smooth. GameplayI'm mixed on the gameplay. I miss some of the combat options from previous games, like the Styles and classic Devil Trigger. However, the combat is still great, and Dante now has access to grappling using angelic or demonic weapons, which allows some other combat methods. It is impressive enough to keep you busy through the 20 missions that make the game. You will be smashing enemies away, pulling them back to you, sending them into the air to pull of a chain of hits and finishing them with a slam into the ground. You have access to several different weapons once your collection is complete, and can easily switch between them in moments, rather than being restricted to only a couple. Each of them have certain enemies they are best suited for, but other than a handful of enemies that can only be harmed by only one type of weapon, you can play with your favourites all you like. The Devil Trigger is no longer as impressive. In this game, you won't be changing into another form with extra combat abilities, you instead just get a period of time where your health regenerates and you can beat on the enemies suspended in the air. I only rarely used this ability myself, though if you have trouble with mobs, this would allow you to beat on them for a short while your health builds back up. Outside of combat, you will be running around locations, using your various talents to move around the dangerous areas that make the world of Devil May Cry. You will frequently be flying through the air grappling to items and pulling others out of your way, or gliding across pits. And you might jump up a few ledges. LifespanThere are a number of features to keep you busy with the game after beating the story. Each of the levels contains a number of secrets to find, including Lost Souls which drop more souls for buying items, and a number of hidden keys and doors. Each door unlocks an area with a special challenge to complete it. Each challenge will give you an upgrade item, so finding these will enhance your chances of surviving the enemies ahead. As well as that, there are a number of difficulty settings to unlock, as well as attempting to get a SSS rank in each of the levels for each difficulty, and you could be playing this game for a very long time. The free Bloody Palace arena combat DLC should also add a significant amount of time to your gameplay. The last bit to extend the gameplay is a paid DLC which gives a bit of post game story for Virgil, though I found this less impressive than the main game, as Virgil has access to less combat options, though his Devil Trigger ability is more impressive, since it calls a doppelganger to help you fight enemies. Still, if you can get it cheap, it adds 6 more missions to beat as well as some different combat to try out. All in all, I can only say this is an okay game. The combat in the older games was more fun, and that is the main focus of the Devil May Cry games. However, it is still a suitable game for the series, and even if I prefer most of the classic games over this, I can't just say its the worst of the series either. It still comes ahead of Devil May Cry 2. Thats something. Last note, the original title I had planned for this review was "Dante says **** You". But then decided to not put a spoiler in the title. 7 / 10

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Terrible soundtrack, awful writing, and just all around not worth your time. The only redeeming feature of this bland action game is the set pieces in which the color coded fights take place. It's clear ninja theory doesn't really have any idea what makes a game fun and have some very backwards ideas about what constitutes a "cool" character. Between the dumbed down combat which as mentioned before is just matching the colors of your weapons to the colors of the enemies and the constant barrage of edgy "adult" themes this game borderlines as a parody of the genre from which it came. The most offending part is that while the color matching combat is at least serviceable for lower skilled players to mash their way through the game, it limits player's ability to create combos by mixing up what weapons they want to use and when. This creates a very low and shallow experience that seasoned players will come to find themselves bored of quickly and then have to suffer through what amounts to some teenager's fan fiction tier story writing. The highpoint of this game is a few platforming areas that are actually quite decent. In fact the only value this game has comes from the pretty scenery you can explore in between boring waves of recolored enemies. The world around you will shift into a demon land and alter itself in fairly surprising ways. What was once just a roadway will break apart and become an interesting segment where you must use your abilities and equipment to move from place to place. This is a welcome distraction from the terrible combat and story. Speaking of story, here's the worst part of this game by far. No exaggeration, this game has a scene in which one character shoots a pregnant woman through the stomach killing her child and then they shoot her. This is played out as a good thing as said woman and child were demons; however, as this scene takes place neither are in any way portrayed as such. Now these characters are a boss fight in the game, but this scene isn't in anyway connected to this boss fight and it amounts to a distasteful scene of a pregnant woman being shot. The main character even taunts the final boss about it after they ask why it was done. It's this tone deaf writing throughout this game that shows how little ninja theory understand what it takes to make a compelling story/character. I'd say pick this game up only to laugh at as it is basically garbage in electronic form.PROS:It's unintentionally funny. BONUS: Has a Spanish language mod that increases how hilarious it is.Decent platformingExcellent set pieces and scenery.Competent developers from Capcom did try to fix this mess with the definitive edition. So there are some tweaks improving it such as 60fps and more.CONS:Terrible soundtrackTerrible writingWeak combatIf you don't want to read this review the entire game can be summed up with this video.
